PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: I inform the Senate that Senator Baume will be absent from the chamber today on ministerial council duties. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Baume in relation to his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to me.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Has the Government made a contribution towards a subsidy for air transport in western Queensland? If so, what is the level of the subsidy, to whom is it paid and does the proposed reduction of air services for Winton and Longreach from 1 May this year accord with the conditions attaching to it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the general question of subsidies for western Queensland air services, Trans Australia Airlines is presently unable to continue to meet the substantial losses it is incurring on inland Queensland F27 services. This has caused considerable concern to residents, the Commonwealth and, of course, the State Government of Queensland. I believe this has been a matter of concern to Senator Bjelke-Petersen who asked several questions on this matter during the last session. Of course, those losses are not able to be continued or to be met by cross-subsidisation from other passengers using other routes in Queensland. I understand the Minister for Transport has visited these regions to discuss the problem with residents. The Prime Minister has also discussed the matter with the Premier of Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: The Queensland Government has announced that it would be prepared to contribute $1m for each of the next two years to subsidise part of TAA's losses on operations in western Queensland. The Commonwealth is still currently considering its options on the future of air services and the provision of a subsidy to TAA, I understand, along similar lines to that which the State Government has in mind. I understand that no decision has been taken on that matter. I will need to refer to the Minister the details which Senator Colston seeks in regard to Longreach and Winton to get a specific reply.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Did the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Sir Billy Snedden, on television this morning say that there was an arrangement with the Prime Minister that estimates for Parliament would not be altered without consultation between himself and the Leader of the House and between the President and the Leader of the Government in the Senate? Did Sir Billy say that in drawing up its last Budget the Government ignored this arrangement? Did he further say that after this incident the Leader of the House, Mr Sinclair, said the lack of consultation would not occur again? Did Sir Billy tell the interviewer this morning that the Government again had failed to consult the Presiding Officers about reduced spending between now and the end of the financial year? Does the Minister agree with the Speaker's comment that Parliament has to reassert itself to ensure that this Government does not go unsupervised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the last part of the question, the answer is no. Parliament does not have to reassert itself. I did not see or hear Mr Speaker on television this morning, but I would be happy to respond to the facts of the matter. The arrangement-it is one that we will adhere to-has been that from time to time there should be consultations between the two Presiding Officers and the two chamber leaders, Mr Sinclair and myself. That we are quite willing to do and the Minister--
—That is because you got caught.

—Let me explain how we got caught. The night before last we had agreed to meet Mr Speaker but he asked us to postpone the meeting. Mr President, without involving you in this matter, I inform the Senate that it is true that Mr Sinclair and I were ready to meet Mr Speaker and yourself the night before last, when we would have had those discussions. We set aside time to discuss the matter last night but Cabinet overran our time. My understanding is that there is an intention to find time today to discuss the matter. As leaders of the two Houses we are quite eager and willing to have those discussions and they will take place before final decisions are made. If there has been any awkwardness in the arrangements it is not from lack of good will. We are determined to attempt to make them work.

—Did the Minister for National Development and Energy see a feature show on the Australian Broadcasting Commission on Monday night which showed Mr Landa opening a solar village at Bonnyrigg in New South Wales? Mr Landa claimed that the design techniques which had been employed in this project of his Government could save up to 50 per cent on home heating costs. Can the Minister comment on this figure claimed by Mr Landa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I did not see the television appearance of the State Minister--
—What do you watch?

—What I watch is the business of the Senate and also the functions that I am now about to describe. It so happens that the project that Mr Landa opened is one that is financed substantially by my Department and this Government. I did not see the show on television but I am very familiar with the Bonnyrigg Village project. It is a co-operative venture between the Commonwealth, the New South Wales Government and the University of New South Wales. Without seeing the project, I am aware that so far over $100,000 has been provided by the Commonwealth through the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council for this specific project.

ANSWER.PARA: Certain claims were referred to. The project involves a series of concepts. There is a solar concept and also a major conservation concept in the building construction and special designs of windows, walls and roofing. Senator Lajovic would know that this Government has provided special tax concessions for insulation of roofing. He will know that this Government has had discussions with the States and local government to try to get a common building code that will conserve energy. He will know that in the speech I made in this chamber some days ago on uranium enrichment, I pointed out that it was believed generally that an energy conservation of 20 per cent to 30 per cent could be achieved by general means, including these kinds of means, throughout the developed world without any loss of living standards.

This combined project is a village of 15 houses divided into three types of construction-standard New South Wales Housing Commission design, an improved standard public housing design, and new designs incorporating novel passive solar energy techniques. A number of similar projects are being supported by the Commonwealth Government, for example, in Tasmania and in Canberra. I think the important message is that in all aspects of conservation, whether it is in the use of natural energy, insulation, or housing or building design there is a capacity to save at least 30 per cent of energy. I commend that to all Australians.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TRADING ARRANGEMENTS BETWEEN AUSTRALIA AND NEW ZEALAND

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry this question. In view of the agreement reportedly reached by the dairy industries of Australia and New Zealand in the development of stabilised trading arrangments, can the Minister confirm that similar agreements will be concluded for vegetables? Can an assurance be given that no new arrangements will be made unless and until vegetable industry representatives of both countries have agreed on all proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has assured the relevant industries on a number of occasions that it will not enter into new trading arrangements with New Zealand except on the basis of equality of trading opportunities, and that it will not allow Australian industries to be adversely affected by unfair competition or, in the case of primary industries, disruption of the domestic marketing and pricing arrangements. The Government has also said that final decisions by the Government on a closer economic relationship will not be taken until there has been full consultation with all interested parties, including the States and industries.

ANSWER.PARA: It is implicit in the question asked by the honourable senator that industry involvement is clearly essential to the development of proposals for a closer economic relationship with New Zealand. I agree with that view. Officials have been consulting with industry in this respect. Formal industry to industry discussions have been taking place on wine and dairy products. There has also been contact between Australian and New Zealand vegetable growers. General agreement on the treatment of wine has, I believe, been reached at industry level. The basis on which dairy products will be brought into a closer economic relationship with New Zealand is still under discussion between the two industries. I expect that Australian vegetable growers will wish to talk further with their New Zealand counterparts about the implications of their relationship with the trans-Tasman trade in vegetable products.

In conclusion, let me re-emphasise the Government's assurance that no final decisions will be taken on the closer economic relationship before there has been full consultation with the States and the relevant industries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware that youth homelessness is one of the major and growing problems in our society? In particular, is he aware of a report in the Melbourne Age of 5 August 1981 that it was estimated that there were 15,000 young homeless people in Victoria alone? In that context, can the Minister provide any information on the evaluation results of the pilot youth accommodation services program now nearing completion ? Can he advise whether the services provided under the pilot program will be discontinued at the end of the three-year period, that is to say, at the end of this financial year, thus withdrawing much needed support for homeless young people? If this is not intended, what arrangements are being made for a bridging period?

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister aware that this year's funding arrangements have been inadequate to meet escalating wage and operating costs for a number of projects? In particular, the Westernport youth refuge in Victoria is facing closure well before the end of the pilot period unless bridging funds are provided. In view of reports that the Victorian Minister of Community Welfare Services, Mr Jona, is prepared to provide additional assistance to match any Commonwealth funds made available, will the Minister for Social Security give an assurance that he will provide funds to enable this service to continue until the end of the year? In the light of additional Commonwealth funds being the only resource required to continue the services offered under this highly valued and desperately needed program, should the Minister decline to match Mr Jona's offer will he accept responsibility for the closure of such places and for forcing more young Australians to live on the streets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem of youth homelessness is one which has emerged over recent years. There were expressions of concern about it about three or four years ago at meetings of the ministerial council which were attended by my predecessor, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. Following those expressions of concern and the discussion among Ministers, it was agreed that the Commonwealth and the States would undertake a pilot project to examine the problem, to fund some purported solutions to the problem and to subject that process to evaluation with a view to having better guidelines for future policy action in that area. That process has occurred and we are now in the final half year of the three-year period.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact that there is a problem in this area was acknowledged by the Government at the time of the last elections when it was indicated that part of the funding commitment which was made under the Homeless Persons Assistance Program would be expressly directed towards youth homelessness. That was in addition to the commitment which was given to the Youth Support Scheme which was the subject of the honourable senator's question. That Scheme has been subject to evaluation. To date I have received only a preliminary report of that evaluation, but there was further discussion about the program at the Council of Welfare Ministers which took place in New Zealand just prior to Parliament resuming. In light of the then available information, the Council of Welfare Ministers requested the Commonwealth to extend further the funding of the Youth Support Scheme into 1982-83 with a view to providing sufficient time for the results of the evaluation survey to be studied and for governments to take decisions as to the future directions of the program. I have to put before the Government a proposal to get a commitment for funding for next year. I am in the process of doing that.

At the same time, I emphasise that this is an area in which I think policy directions are still subject to some uncertainty. There are aspects of the problem which are not fully understood, and the approaches to it are not fully agreed by the people who are involved in the field. Our own Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare is conducting an inquiry in this area. I had a preliminary discussion with members of that Committee when they met in Perth some months ago with a view to getting their early views. They have travelled around Australia and had extensive discussions with people who are concerned with this field. I am sure that their report will be a valuable contribution to our knowledge in this area. I think I can fairly say that they would not be promoting the idea of opening a whole lot of new or additional refuges. They are concerned that the sorts of services provided will take young people back into independent and self-sustaining life and not merely have the effect of providing shelters which perform no useful function other than to keep people out of the cold and the wet. So there are quite substantial policy questions to be addressed by the Government. I propose to address those questions in the context of the evaluation of the three-year scheme which is just coming to a conclusion and in the context of the Senate Committee report which I understand may well be received in the next month or two.

I move on to the specific problem about the Westernport refuge which was raised by the honourable senator in his question. The body responsible for the refuge has made representations because it says that it cannot continue for the balance of this year on the funding which has been provided. Recently some additional funding was provided by agreement between Mr Jona and myself from the uncommitted funds in that program. There is a whole series of programs right around Australia funded under the Youth Support Scheme. All of them have been provided with budgeted amounts for this financial year. In response to requests from the States the people involved in the Scheme have been asked to live within the Budget figure which has been provided. I saw some representatives from the Westernport refuge yesterday. They put their case to me and I undertook to examine it in light of the representations I had received. Needless to say, I have not yet given it that examination as I saw them only yesterday. The request they make has implications not merely for the Westernport refuge but for all the other centres which also have indicated that they would like additional funding but which have been told that they have to manage within their budgets.

The problem with respect to the Westernport scheme, in common with the problems of some other schemes, is that there have been substantial award increases and the budgeted amounts for salaries have hence been exceeded. That is a problem often faced in subsidy programs funded by the Commonwealth Government. But the fact is that the funds which were offered have been made available. The people who are being paid are now in receipt of much higher wages than was anticipated at the time the funding was provided. The Westernport scheme, so I have been advised, provides round-the-clock manning of the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Bring it to an end.

—I have been asked a question and I intend to give an appropriate answer. The Westernport scheme provides round-the-clock manning. It may be that if the full amount of funds wanted is not available the people involved will have to look to pruning some of their manning requirements, but that matter will get careful consideration also.

—I address a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to the unusually high rate of power generation required from the Snowy River scheme which has been made necessary to provide power to bolster the flagging electricity supplies in New South Wales. Can the Minister assure me that the Snowy's other major role-that is, to provide control and provision of irrigation water to the Murray River and Murrumbidgee River-will not be neglected as a result of this additional power requirement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can appreciate Senator Jessop's very real interest in this matter. The water from the Snowy River plays a very significant part in irrigation not only in Victoria but also in South Australia. I can assure Senator Jessop that the important role of the Snowy in irrigation has not been forgotten and I acknowledge that the year to year vagaries of rainfall make any increases in electricity generation a matter for considerable care. I believe that the Snowy Mountains Council, which is chaired by an officer of my Department, is being particularly careful in this matter. The situation is, as I understand it, that for the operating year ending 30 April 1982 the Snowy scheme is expected to generate about 5,400 gigawatt hours, which is almost 40 per cent greater than envisaged in the operating plan of the commencement of the year. These arrangements include provision for pay-back in the winter of 1982 so that, unless there are unusually wet conditions in the Snowy region in the next few months, up to 15 per cent less electricity will be available from the scheme than would otherwise be obtained.

ANSWER.PARA: From this Senator Jessop will see that the situation in New South Wales is bad because it has deliberately, in summer, borrowed against its future to prevent a breakdown of supplies in New South Wales. In particular, it made a decision to forgo summer maintenance which could put its generating system in peril. But as to irrigation water, the Snowy Mountains Council and this Government are very conscious of the need for the agreement to be fully implemented, and we will do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that the document read from by the Minister be tabled.
—I am perfectly happy to do so.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I follow up the question I asked Senator Sir John Carrick on Wednesday, 17 February. Then Senator Sir John Carrick did not know whether a report to the Government suggesting that 444 staff are employed by Federal departments and statutory authorities for the purposes of public relations and dissemination of information existed. I now refer to an article in the most recent edition of the National Times headed 'Task Force Wants Review of $23m Promotions' which again refers to this report to the Government and which claims that the report says that $35m to $40m was spent on government advertising in the years 1979 and 1980 . I now ask: Is the Minister able to confirm the existence of this report? If so , how long has it been in the hands of the Government? Will the Government take steps to respond to the report's alleged comments that many government advertising campaigns are of doubtful effectiveness?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not personally aware of the report. I will seek out the information and see what can be supplied to Senator Gietzelt.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONVERSION OF NATURAL GAS TO METHANOL

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for National Development and Energy aware that overseas several plants are operating or about to come into operation to convert natural gas to methanol for use as a creative energy alternative to oil? Can the Minister state whether the conversion method has been shown to be viable? Given our huge reserves of natural gas, is Australia closely monitoring these overseas developments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that Senator Walters posed is important because if in the decades ahead oil supplies should diminish as is predicted and we find more gas the ability to convert natural gas into automotive fuel will be of great importance. The production of methanol from natural gas is a well established technology. It has been undertaken overseas on a commercial scale for many years primarily for use in the chemical industry and, in fact, in the making of fertilisers. The use of methanol as a fuel or for conversion to gasolene is being examined in a number of countries. An automotive vehicle can be run on pure methanol. If this were to be done in Australia there would need to be some adaptation of parts because methanol does not like plastics and would damage plastic parts. But it can be done. I have seen a vehicle in Perth operating on pure methanol.

ANSWER.PARA: The most advanced look at the conversion from natural gas to methanol to gasolene is the New Zealand natural gas to methanol process known as the Maui gas process and also as the Mobil experiment. We are closely monitoring these overseas developments. As honourable senators know, we have commissioned a series of studies to investigate the use of methanol as a gas extender in Australia. The results of the first of these studies on methanol production from coal and natural gas were released in 1981 and are available to honourable senators. Quite apart from the technology and the cost feasibility of the matter one of the other questions concerns whether, in the journey from natural gas to methanol and from methanol to gasolene, there is a very significant consumption of energy and whether the net gain of energy in the end might not be great. All these are very significant problems. Australia looks as though it is finding more significant gas fields. Therefore, the use of methanol and its conversion to gasolene could be of very great significance to us in the future. We are closely studying the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs is in the form of a plea for compassion for an Australian named Fraser; but it is John, not Malcolm. Fraser married a Zimbabwean girl in London. When they returned to her homeland the Zimbabwean Government implemented its immigration policy which forced Fraser to separate from his family and return here. Accepting the sovereign rights of a country, the fact that Fraser is an Australian and not a South African and that there should not be animosity, have we pointed out to Zimbabwe that our role in helping this fledgling nation in conjunction with our broadly humanitarian attitude on family reunion might justify an exception in this case?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am aware of the case of Mr John Fraser mentioned by Senator Mulvihill. I understand that an officer of the Australian High Commission in Salisbury has spoken with Mr Fraser. It seems there is little that the Australian Government can do in cases of this nature. Of course, Australia is bound by international law and practice regarding non-interference in the internal processes of other governments. It is the right of each government to decide who shall and who shall not enter into work in the country. There are difficulties in particular for Mr John Fraser who is an Australian citizen and wishes to remain in Zimbabwe with his Zimbabwean wife and his daughter. However, I think there is little that we could do. I am not aware whether we have spoken with the authorities. I take that point from Senator Mulvihill's question. I will refer it to the Minister to see whether I can get a response on that aspect.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. I refer him to an answer that Mr Anthony gave in the House of Representatives on 23 February wherein he said that he was aware that the Ashton Joint Venture partners would be valuing diamonds mined by the partners and that the Western Australian Government would also be making independent assessments of the value of the diamonds; however, while he did not want to duplicate the Western Australian Government's work he believed that the Commonwealth also had a responsibility to check the value of the diamonds before they leave Australia.

QUESTION.PARA: I ask: Does this mean that the Federal Government either does not have confidence in the competence of the Western Australian Government or does not trust it, or is it a case of duplication by Federal Government bureaucracy not able to keep out of matters which are best managed by State governments? I further ask: Can the Minister give one tangible example of Australian companies attracting a higher price for their metals or minerals as a result of the threat of export controls by a Federal Government, as is claimed by Mr Anthony? Finally , does he really believe that negotiating companies, either buyers or sellers, are intimidated or influenced in their commercial arrangements by such threats?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the importance of the proper valuation of diamonds is recognised quite specifically in the agreement between the AJV and the Western Australian Government. I note that. The agreement states :

ANSWER.PARA: The Joint Venturers shall . . . take all reasonable steps to satisfy the Minister for Mines as to the adequacy of its valuation and auditing procedures.
It goes on:

Nothing in this sub-clause shall limit the power of the Minister for Mines to appoint independent valuers and auditors, after consultation with the Joint Venturers, to carry out further valuations and audits.

That defines the Western Australian situation. In addition to the safeguards contained in that agreement it has been made clear by the Deputy Prime Minister that the Commonwealth Government will put in place additional safeguards to ensure that Australian diamonds are correctly valued. That I do not take as a reflection on the ability of the Western Australian Government. I shall elaborate on that. The Commonwealth will engage an independent valuer who from time to time will make what might be called check valuations to ensure that the valuations arrived at by the Joint Venturers and the Western Australian valuer are correct. It might be suggested that the Commonwealth will be merely duplicating the actions of the Western Australian Government. However, the Commonwealth believes it essential, when the national interest is so involved, that we make quite certain that our diamonds are marketed at the correct market price. The Deputy Prime Minister has discussed this matter with the Western Australian Minister and there is an acceptance that the proposed arrangements are appropriate in Australia's national interest.

The fact of the matter is that this Parliament and this Government have a constitutional responsibility with regard to overseas trade and therefore have a responsibility of their own to ensure that what is happening is giving full value to the people of Australia. It must be able of its own accord, whilst being fully co-operative with State governments, to say that it justifies its actions. I will refer to the Minister for Trade and Resources the question concerning examples of export controls having a certain effect. It relates more properly to his journey in life than to mine. I will seek that further information.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, my question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy-quite appropriately, because it also concerns the Argyle diamonds. In the context of current discussions about the sale of diamonds from the Argyle diamond mine, can the Minister confirm that there is no effective State or Federal legislation to protect the interests of the Aboriginal traditional owners in the area of the mine? Can the Minister explain why the Federal Government has ignored submissions from Aboriginal communities in the Argyle area for the establishment of an independent study into the social impact of mining and exploration on Aborigines living in that area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware that the matters as stated by Senator Ryan are so. That is no reflection on the nature of her question. Because I do not have first-hand information and because the matter does not concern my portfolio directly, I will put the question to the relevant Ministers-I think several are involved, including those in the State Government-and seek the information for Senator Ryan.

—My question is directed to the Minister who today is representing the Minister for Communications. Could Australia Post give consideration to the issuing in Australia of regional postage stamps, similar to a practice in the United Kingdom, aimed at promoting certain regions of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer the suggestion to my colleague the Minister for Communications in another place.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a report in the Melbourne Age on 1 January 1982 claiming that a person had embezzled $583,000 from the Australian Embassy in Washington. Can the Minister say what further developments have occurred in this case? Is it a fact that $35,000 had previously been embezzled from the Australian Embassy in Tehran ? If so, what action was taken on that matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I would need to get an up to date report on the first matter referred to. Investigations were being undertaken by police and I am not quite sure as to their status. However, I will provide early information on that. With regard to the second matter, I would need to seek information from the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I will do that as soon as possible.

—I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy, who today is representing the Minister for Communications, and ask him to refer this matter to that Minister. I refer the Minister to the Joint Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works report concerning the upgrading and reconstruction of Radio Australia at Cox Peninsula, Northern Territory, and particularly to evidence that there were firm plans to establish high frequency inland transmitters to service the north and outback Australia with a reliable radio service. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the present situation in regard to this shortwave radio proposal which was to be positioned in the Darwin area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will certainly refer the question to the appropriate Minister. However, I have a brief which may be related to this matter. I think it was a project which was first approved in 1974 but deferred following cyclone Tracy. If I could get some indication that that is the nature of Senator Kilgariff's question, I could add that my understanding is that in 1980 the Joint Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works recommended that facilities be provided as soon as possible. A motion by the House of Representatives in May 1980 supported this view and the Minister for Communications has had very strong representations from the Northern Territory Government.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1981 overseas studies by a departmental engineer confirmed that operation from three sites in the Northern Territory rather than a single site is the most effective method of operation. The Government is considering in principle the provision of such a service together with funding for this service. It has been suggested that an interim Aboriginal broadcasting service could also be provided in the first three years of this project. If, in fact, that is not a complete response to Senator Kilgariff, I will have his question studied and referred to the Minister concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. It may also relate to his own portfolio as Minister for National Development and Energy. It follows the two questions asked this week by Senator Crichton-Browne relating to the Argyle diamond deposit. I remind the Minister of his answer on Tuesday to Senator Crichton-Browne in which he said that commercial interests' securing profits and the Western Australian Government's securing royalties would give sufficient protection to Australia's interest in getting the proper value for the diamonds from the Ashton Joint Venture. Did the Minister for Trade and Resources in another place at the same time inform that House of the projected appointment of a Commonwealth valuer for those diamonds?

QUESTION.PARA: What is the ministerial or administrative responsibility or competence of the Minister for National Development and Energy in the area of diamond production in Australia? Were the two different answers the result of a demarcation dispute between his Ministry and that of the Minister for Trade and Resources? In other words, who was telling the truth at the time? Finally-I seek clarification on this point because I think both the Minister for Trade and Resources and the Minister in this place are relying on an ambiguity in relation to the valuing of those diamonds-is the role of the Commonwealth valuer simply to assess the colour, quality and carat rating of the diamonds to see that contractual terms are properly met or is he to go further and suggest the overall contractual terms by which the national interests of Australia can be protected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The response that I gave the other day was a brief from the Department of Trade and Resources and not from my Department. It was a part of the dialogue that I continued today from a brief from the Department of Trade and Resources. My Department has, through the Bureau of Mineral Resources, a responsibility for the location and definition of resources. It makes recommendations on their accessibility, their value in general terms to the economy and also to conservation. It has no responsibility in the area of exploitation for trade. In this situation, the matter having passed to the developmental and trade stage, it is not within the specific responsibility of my Department. I see no conflict but simply a development of the theme by the Minister in another place. I will seek specific information on the precise role of the valuer in the terms which Senator Tate requested and let him have it.

—I ask a supplementary question. It is extremely unsatisfactory that the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources in this place, having had two days notice of the answer given in the other place, does not grasp the role of the Commonwealth valuer. I will repeat the question because there may have been some misunderstanding of it on the Minister's part. Is the role of the valuer merely to keep the parties honest-in other words, to check the colour, quality and carat rating of the diamonds-or is it to set or suggest the overall parameters within which the valuation should take place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave a response today in terms of my understanding of the situation. That response related specifically to the concept of ensuring that the people of Australia will obtain fair value for the diamonds. Senator Tate raised some other aspects and, as I said, I will seek further information. Because I am not the Minister concerned, I feel that my answer might not be as precise as the value of his question deserves. I will seek the information requested.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that shortly the hunting and killing of baby harp seals will recommence in Newfoundland, Canada? In view of public repugnance in Australia and other parts of the world at this slaughter, has the Australian Government made any approaches to the Canadian Government to urge it to stop the killing of these beautiful and harmless animals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that the Australian Government has informally on a number of occasions discussed this matter with the Canadian authorities. It needs to be said that Canada has an enlightened and active conservation policy. We regard the Canadian Government as being fully competent to deal with this matter. However, as I have said, we have discussed the matter informally. I do not know what information I can provide on the matter. If there is anything that is of interest, I will see that Senator Martin is advised.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer to the Repatriation Review Tribunal's decision to set aside the Repatriation Commission's decision in the case of Colin Simpson. In the light of that decision linking the death of the applicant to his exposure to toxic chemicals during his Army service in South Vietnam, will the Minister investigate whether a class of ex-service men and women now exists that could be given automatic entitlements rather than each and every person suffering from exposure to chemicals in South Vietnam continuing to be put through the Commission's full procedures and probably through a Repatriation Review Tribunal hearing as well?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two days ago I was asked a question along similar lines to this one in connection with the meaning of the decision of the Repatriation Review Tribunal in the case of Mrs Simpson. On that occasion I said that, in fact, the decision indicated nowhere that there was any link between the unfortunate death of Mr Simpson and his exposure to herbicides. I did say then that, because of the onus of proof in the repatriation legislation, the Repatriation Commission was unable to prove that there was not such a connection. Accordingly, as I have stated on many occasions in the past, it is open for any ex-serviceman to test his eligibility for repatriation compensation through the system. I have encouraged ex-servicemen to do so and I do that now. Accordingly, each ex- serviceman would be required to put forward his case in individual circumstances . I point out that individual circumstances applying to individual cases are quite different from those applying in other cases.

ANSWER.PARA: It would be very difficult to assess some kind of general condition as a result of this decision or any of the evidence that was given at that hearing of Mr Simpson's case. Accordingly, it is not possible to establish any kind of class, as Senator Macklin puts it, whereby such a series of hearings might be heard en bloc. However, I point out that the Repatriation Commission is currently examining, as a matter of some urgency, all those cases which are outstanding and which have some reference to chemical exposure. No doubt it will be dealing with those expeditiously in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer to the entry into Australia in June 1980 of 34 Laotian refugees. I ask: Was this group the first of three pilot groups organised to come to the Northern Territory to test the viability of the establishment of subsistence farms for refugees from Indo-China? Were complaints made to government departments by members of the first group as early as March 1981? If so, what was the substance of these complaints and what action was taken by the departments involved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of this rather large extended family group of 30-odd Laotian refugees referred to by Senator Robertson has been the subject of a good deal of interest and, I think, support by not only the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs but also other departments. They came here under sponsorship of a gentleman living near Darwin in the Northern Territory. In the first place they had been living on his property, but I understand a large number of them have now been resettled. However, in relation to the specific details that Senator Robertson has sought, I will refer those matters to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to obtain an answer.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Transport advise the Senate of the current state of progress in the sealing of the Stuart Highway and particularly whether the works are on schedule? Is it still the Government's first priority for works on national highways in South Australia to complete the sealing of the Stuart Highway between Port Augusta and the Northern Territory border by 1987 as stated in a Press release by the Minister for Transport on 2 December 1981? Will current rates of funding, if maintained in real terms, be adequate to complete the project by 1987?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth and South Australian governments made a joint commitment in 1979 to complete the sealing of this section of road in South Australia which is, of course, of major interest to South Australian senators and to Senator Kilgariff in the Northern Territory. In accordance with the priority--
—And the rest of us.

—I take it that Senator Robertson would have some interest too. Expenditure on the road has accelerated from less than $1m in 1978-79 to some $ 10m in 1981-82. Work is currently in progress to seal from Pimba, north of Woomera, to Gosses. When that work is completed later this year some 580 kilometres or up to 63 per cent of the whole distance of the road will remain to be sealed. That sealing is expected to be completed by 1987. The last advice received from the South Australian Minister of Transport was that the 1987 target can be achieved without detriment to other priority works, provided the 1980-81 national roads grant to South Australia is maintained in real terms. The present rate of sealing of the road is the maximum amount of progress that can be achieved, having regard to the very real physical constraints in constructing roads in remote areas and the priorities for other national highway works in South Australia and in other States.

—I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Is it a fact that the Australian Government is being accused by the media and others of caving in to pressures from the Japanese Government over safeguard provisions in the uranium sale agreements with that country? These agreements were initialled by both countries in January this year. Has Australia abandoned the requirement of a buyer country to get Australia's approval before it can resell uranium to a third country? Has Australia also abandoned the requirement of a buyer country to get Australia's approval before it enriches or reprocesses uranium bought from Australia? Will the Minister tell the Senate when the Australian people can expect to see a copy of the agreements? Will the Parliament get the opportunity to debate the issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that the arrangements on uranium between the Japanese Government and Australia are, in principle, precisely those that have been made with other countries. There is no significant deviation from that. Certainly there is no concession that would in any way weaken Australia's attitude towards its responsibility to the International Atomic Energy Agency or to the nuclear safeguards agreements. I am not aware of the practice of the publication of such agreements. I will ask the Minister concerned to study that part of the question and to let me have his comment.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Finance both in her own capacity and as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, is about budgetary restraints. Is it a fact that last week a rear- admiral and four senior public servants proceeded overseas to examine the staffing levels of our diplomatic missions in Washington, London and Paris? What is the estimated cost of this mission? Why was it not possible for such a staffing review to be carried out without the need for the physical presence of such a team in these places overseas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to get information on whether those people have gone overseas and the cost involved. I will perhaps have to check through the Public Service Board about whether it is possible to examine staffing levels without a personal visit. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH AND MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to a matter close to the hearts of all Australians, the universal Australian affection for a man's best friend, the family dog. Has it been drawn to the Minister's attention that the Opposition has vilified and scandalously misrepresented Droopy, the Prime Minister's dog? Is it true that the Springer Spaniel Association has condemned this attack and called for Droopy 's good breeding and appealing good looks to be involved in the campaigns for victory in Lowe and Victoria? Will the Government take up this request and thereby show all of us ordinary Australians that the Government has no part in the Opposition's lack of judgment about Droopy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —One could not have escaped reading this morning in the Australian the letter which was a feature presentation by, I think, Mr Sisley, a member of the English Springer Spaniel Association. He went on to suggest that Opposition members should concentrate on the jobs that they are paid to do and-in his words-'not piddle with and pontificate about petty matters , lest Droopy takes it into his own paws to mess with them'. QUESTION.PARA: The multiplied form filling and explaining of what we are meant to be doing actually prevents us from doing what we are meant to be doing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the matter to which Senator Ray refers was raised yesterday in a supplementary question by Senator Button. He referred to an article, I think, in the Australian Financial Review which I have not yet had an opportunity to catch up with. —Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware that, between April 1976 and June 1981, 27,000 square kilometres of Queensland rural land was involved in approval proposals for foreign investors and that this area represents 1.6 per cent of Queensland, which is more than the 1.2 per cent presently being sought by my fellow Aborigines in that State? Is the Minister aware also of the grave concern that is being expressed by the rural population and other interested organisations such as the Returned Services League? Has the Commonwealth any powers to prevent this foreign takeover and in particular prevent certain foreign nationals from acquiring this land under the Queensland Government's patronage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a number of occasions I have responded to questions asked in the Senate concerning foreign investment and foreign acquisition of land. In general terms I have indicated that where it involves a State the primary responsibility for land is a State matter. I say none of these things defensively. I have indicated also that foreign investment, as it passes through the Commonwealth and through the Foreign Investment Review Board, may be for a particular purpose but subsequently may involve land after the money has been reprocessed. I repeat that essentially the matter would be a State one. Sovereignty over land, its ownership and title, is a State matter. I am not aware of the figures referred to by the honourable senator. I am aware of some concern by a number of people and organisations in Australia that there should not be undue foreign ownership of land. My recollection is that the Treasurer, in conjunction with the Foreign Investment Review Board, was looking at this matter in recent times in terms of whether the Commonwealth had any powers. I will refer that aspect of the question to the Treasurer and seek further information.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN EMBASSY IN WASHINGTON: SECURITY CHECKS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, refers also to the arrest of a former employee of the Australian Embassy in Washington on charges of stealing. What security checks are applied to prospective employees before they are granted employment with our Washington Embassy? Have the staff cutbacks resulting from the razor gang's decision led to a breakdown in security arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will need to get some details on what security checks are applied to locally engaged people in our departments overseas and to check with the Foreign Minister or the Public Service Board with regard to any changes in staffing levels and the effects that they may have had.

ANSWER.PARA: I take this opportunity to respond to a question asked earlier by Senator Primmer with regard to the fraud in the Australian Embassy in Washington. I advise the Senate that an investigation has been conducted by officers of the Department of Finance, the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Australian Federal Police into a fraud in the Australian Embassy involving $US671,802. The report of the investigating team indicates that the fraud occurred on 7 December 1981 in the Department of Finance's accounting office in the Embassy.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation was called in when the fraud was detected on 23 December. As a result of the FBI investigation a warrant was issued in Washington on 28 December for the arrest of Mr J. I. Cowling. Mr Cowling, an Englishman, was a member of the locally engaged staff of the Embassy at the time of the fraud but he resigned and ceased duty on 11 December. There was no suggestion that other losses had occurred. The basic accounting system within the accounting office was considered sound and was adhered to by the staff. Mr Cowling was arrested in Greece on 24 January 1982. Action is in hand for his extradition to the United States of America to stand trial on three charges relating to the fraud. It is expected that the greater part of the loss will be recovered. The FBI has since advised that an accomplice has been arrested and that this accomplice has pleaded guilty as an accessory after the fact. The honourable senator asked a further question with regard to Tehran. I have no record of that matter but I will see whether I can obtain any information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ryan asked me a question earlier today concerning the Ashton Joint Venture, and specifically whether there had been consultation with Aboriginal groups. I think it was her suggestion that there had not been any consultation. On that aspect of her question, my advice is that in 1980 and subsequently the Ashton Joint Venture reached private agreements with the three local Aboriginal groups, the Mandangala, the Warmun and the Woolah communities. The company undertook to fund capital works programs and to commit itself to future consultations with local Aboriginals. It has been the understanding of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that the local Aboriginal communities welcome the company initiative and the agreements. Officers of the Minister's Department have discussed the matter with the community adviser who, I understand, states that he did not comment on specific issues to the Press and that his general comments on company-community relations have been misconstrued. If any further information is necessary on that question, I will seek it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I want to speak very briefly to this matter. Telecom Australia had a very big profit this year. I think it is important that that be put in some perspective. The Telecom report records a 13 per cent growth in business-that is the strongest yet experienced-a productivity gain of 7 per cent, which ought to be kept in mind when considering the efficiency of Telecom, and a total profit of $ 230m, most of which was made on the coastal strip from Adelaide to Brisbane in respect of subscriber trunk dialling calls. This is a matter I draw to the attention of National Country Party senators. They should keep it in mind when looking in the future at the question of cross-subsidisation of country telephone calls.

The Press, of course, always leads with the profit figure of Telecom which sounds enormous, but I remind the Senate that that profit is ploughed back into services and development of the telephone system. There are, of course, problems with loans, and attention is drawn to them by the report. Telecom is anxious to raise more money in loans, otherwise it will progressively have to rely on internal funding. If that happens as the report says, the rate of achievement in the country upgrading program to which we in the Opposition attach a lot of importance will be dependent on the availability of funds. I ask Government senators to think carefully about upsetting the present scheme of telecommunications in this country which provides an essential cross- subsidisation for the non-profitable routes in country areas. This matter was drawn to the attention of the Government by the McKinsey report on Capital and Policy Requirements for the 1980s. For that reason it is important that Telecom be allowed to develop into new profitable high technology areas such as videotex . That is something which the Government has denied it the right to do. I therefore ask honourable senators to apprise themselves of this report with care because it bears widely on a number of other issues.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
