Senator Chipp-I ask for the indulgence of the Senate to defer this matter for a little while. I am very interested in it. For the last hour this morning I have been addressing a local government meeting and I have not had time to prepare notes. I am in the hands of the Senate. If other senators want to speak to this matter I realise we may lose the chance because other matters might catch up with us, but I wonder whether it could be delayed or deferred for about a quarter of an hour.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask, without putting any formal motion, whether the Senate is willing to have this matter deferred?

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick-No worries.
Senator Walsh-I want to speak to the Foreign Investment Review Board report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh, I suggest that you move to take note of the report . You or Senator Chipp could move for the adjournment until a later hour of the day if no other senator wishes to speak. That is one way it could be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

There is very deep and well merited concern about the loss of economic sovereignty, the losses both actual and potential; for example, through transfer pricing, which can accrue through foreign domination of industry. There is also concern among the community about the threat, either ultimate or actual, posed to our political independence as well as our economic independence. So strong is this concern that even the present Government has been compelled to appear to be doing something to control it, and the main mechanism for exercising that control over foreign investment has been and is the Foreign Investment Review Board.

The Board is probably better than nothing, but in our view it has been and remains inadequate for a number of reasons. First, it can be overruled by a government which is, for whatever reason, of a mind to overrule it, providing the government exercises political discretion about the timing of overruling FIRB decisions or specific foreign investment projects. We had one example of the manipulation of foreign investment procedures before and after the last Federal election. On 24 September 1980 the Treasurer (Mr Howard) announced with a great fanfare that the Oaky Creek coal project, because of its proposed equity structure, was unacceptable and breached the foreign investment guidelines. With the election safely out of the way, on 5 December-10 weeks later-the Treasurer announced that the project could go ahead. That is one way in which the existing procedures are inadequate, because a cynical government can overrule them without a great deal of political risk providing it times its actions carefully, as they were timed in 1980.

The other inadequacy which I shall mention relates to the foreign purchase of land. The present restrictions provide that any purchase above $350,000 has to be subject to the scrutiny of the FIRB. But that scrutiny can be surreptitiously evaded, as Ralph Willis pointed out in a Press statement on 21 January this year , by foreigners buying land through nominees or from earnings by foreign companies and foreign people retained in Australia, or by dividing a specific and larger parcel of land into sub-parcels of land of less than $350,000 in value.

Another severe problem is the fact that some State governments are stacked with economic quislings or worse, the prime examples, of course, being the present governments of Western Australia and Queensland. It is very clear that firm Federal discipline is required. The will to discipline irresponsible State governments is something that has been conspicuously absent from the record of the Fraser Government. I will give two examples of grossly irresponsible State government behaviour, behaviour so irresponsible that it verges on State governments acting as agents for foreign economic interests. They both come from Western Australia. The first is the North West Shelf project. In 1974 an ultimatum was issued by the then Premier Court, that no Australian Government equity in the North West Shelf project would be permitted. At that stage, of course, it was still thought that the States may have had constitutional sovereignty below the low water mark. The same Premier who had vetoed any Australian Government equity in the project was quite happy to accept equity in the project by a foreign government, the British Government, through the British Petroleum Co. of Australia, equity which it had and which it still has.

But there have been even more alarming sequels to that North West Shelf project . It has been apparent for some time, notwithstanding the glib assurances of former Premier Court and a gaggle of other Western Australian and Federal Liberal Ministers, that the Japanese will not buy gas from the North West Shelf in the foreseeable future. It is fortunate, I suppose, that just this day it should have been announced in the Press that the Japanese are unlikely to buy before 1990, and there is no guarantee that they will buy even then. That has been clear for some time. The consequence, of course, of the failure to make any sale to Japan would be that the whole project would have been deferred-something which would have been a tremendous blow to the ego of the former Western Australian Premier and, of course, a severe political blow to the Western Australian Liberal Party.

The response of the Premier, apart from persistent attempts to deceive the public about the potential for Japanese gas sales, was to instruct the State Energy Commission to sign a take or pay contract with the joint venturers which would generate sufficient revenue to get the project off the ground with one production platform. That was done in 1980-conveniently just before the Federal election. It is now quite clear that the Energy Commission cannot cover its costs in the foreseeable future, the costs that it will incur in purchasing that gas and building the pipeline to transport it to Perth. In other words, the potential losses of this project are being underwritten by the captive customers of the State Energy Commission and the most captive customers are those in the household sector. It is being underwritten by the household sector of the gas market through the Western Australian Government. Surely, if losses are to be underwritten by the public, however surreptitiously, in this way the state ought to demand-I use the word 'state' in the general term-to have some equity in the project. Otherwise it is a question of heads the company wins, tails the captive customers lose.

The second matter I want to raise-I will have to be very brief-concerns Camballin farms which have been operating in the Fitzroy region of the Kimberleys in Western Australia. This is a subsidiary of the Texas-owned Australian Land and Cattle Co. It has been fiddling around for seven or eight years with an agricultural project which is typical of north Australian-North American agricultural projects-a lot of high-powered publicity, extravagant predictions and very little action. It was supposed to have planted 22,000 acres of sorghum last year but it in fact planted 7,000 acres, only 2,000 of which were harvested.

I will have to skip a fair bit of what I intended to say. The point I really want to make is that in December last year, when the dogs in the Kimberley were barking that this company was insolvent because its cheques were bouncing and it had not paid its staff for three years, the Western Australian Government pushed special legislation through the State Parliament to give the company freehold title to 50,000 acres of Fitzroy Flats. The alleged reason-alleged as long as six months earlier-which always had the ring of truth and which was confirmed by the action of the Western Australian Government, is that the Government's intention is to flog off the company to the Arabs once it gets freehold title.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise only because Senator Walsh referred to the North West Shelf project. I feel that, because this project is of very significant importance not only to the people of Western Australia but also to the people of Australia, I should put the position in perspective. I put it to the Senate, with the greatest of good will, that the Australian people have a vested interest in wanting to see such a project get off the ground successfully, not only for Australia but also for the people of the world. Simply denigrating the project is in itself a very bad thing for both Australia and the world at large.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me put the matter in perspective. The fact of the matter is that on the north-west coast of Australia there is a very significant defined gas field of great future importance. Indeed, as exploration develops the size of the field becomes very prospective indeed. That should be viewed against the background that the world, irrespective of the immediacy of the glut situation, is moving towards a scarcity of oil and an ultimate loss of oil, and towards a desperate situation in petroleum products with the need for gas and gas products to take the place of oil in the future. Therefore for Australia and for the world there is a need to get into place in the future projects such as the North West Shelf. I hope that honourable senators in the future will be looking towards constructive ways of bringing this about instead of destructive ways of denigrating it.

What has happened is that the world, having reacted to the 1973 Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries price hike and the subsequent price hikes, has brought about conservation measures which have been very successful, particularly in Japan and America, and which have resulted in a considerable fall in the consumption of oil and oil products, including gas. There also remains a recession in the world brought about very largely by the fact that oil prices over the years since 1973 have created inflation and have absorbed the foreign exchange capacity of nations and therefore affected their ability to trade in things other than oil. The situation is that temporarily two things are causing a glut in petroleum products but that the absolute certainty is that in the years and decades ahead there will be a grave scarcity. We have the very great success-I hope everyone would commend it-of conservation both here and abroad.

We have the effects of recession brought about by inflation and the absorption of foreign exchange. I hope that everyone would deplore that situation and would want to work towards ensuring that never again will oil prices or energy prices rise to such a point that they dominate the absorption of foreign exchange to the detriment of trade. Therefore, we need undertakings such as the North West Shelf project so that they can avert future scarcity. At the moment projects such as that on the North West Shelf, like coal and uranium projects, are having a temporary difficulty in that the immediate glut of petroleum, fuel oil, liquefied petroleum gas and other gases in the world is causing nations to reassess, for the moment, their contracts to buy. In other words, they are sliding their lead times but they are not abolishing their longer term need; and that is the fundamental in this situation.

One should be sympathising with the problems that the North West Shelf proprietors have, and the Western Australian Government and people have, in their present dilemma. One should be wanting to encourage the establishment of this organisation as fast as reasonably possible. One should also understand that on occasions we will be altering lead times due to the very success of conservation and alternative fuels. The success of conservation and alternatives has altered the lead times of synthetic crude production. It ought to be regarded as a plus and not denigrated. I rose only to put the matter right. In years and decades ahead there will be a vast need for the natural gas that will come from Australia and in particular from Western Australia. There will be a vital need for the project. The project itself is of an order of magnitude of $6 billion. It is creating jobs in Australia; it is creating a great resource for Australia. I hope that I do not hear denigration of project issue again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Foreign Investment Review Board is in many senses a handbook guide to foreign investment in Australia. It is quite easy to look through it and develop a picture of the state of foreign investment in our country today. Incidentally, Australia rates second only to Canada amongst the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries for levels of transnational capital penetration. What are the major features of this report? In the year to June 1981 the Board approved 1 ,172 foreign investment proposals while it rejected only 40. The Board has gone to great pains, it seems to me, to explain the low number of rejections. The main reasons given are the clarity of foreign investment guidelines and the advisory-I emphasise that word-role as opposed to the watchdog role that the FIRB plays in assisting foreign investors to get their applications within the guidelines. In this regard the policy of the FIRB flows from its being given directions from the Government that it should assist foreign investors to understand the foreign investment policy guidelines and to help them formulate proposals on a basis that would be consistent with policy. So Australia's national interest, which I and my party consider important in the Board's deliberations, is somewhat secondary to that objective. According to the report:

SPEECH.PARA: Each proposal is examined on its merits and against the background of a wide range of economic considerations.

The most frequently claimed benefits are increased employment, as Senator Sir John Carrick suggested, the introduction of new technology, access to finance and improvement of management efficiency. There seems to be a large gap here, with which the Parliament should concern itself. Considerations of Australian autonomy, the effect of investment in one sector of our economy as against another, the broader balance of our economy, the dominance of the economy by a few large corporations based in a few countries and other aspects of foreign investment do not seem to be in the criteria or getting the consideration of the Board at all.

In the years 1979 to 1980 it is obvious that there were three main investment countries, the United Kingdom, the United States of America and Japan. They continue to be the main sources for foreign investment. There was a noted increase in funds from the European Economic Community, excluding the United Kingdom, particularly West Germany and France. Despite the problems that those countries have with stagnation and slow growth, their funds are coming into our country for the purpose of higher profitability. Not surprisingly, the industries that received the most heavy foreign inflow in 1979-80 were mining and quarrying, oil exploration and production, oil distribution, commerce, finance and property other than banking and insurance, food, drink, tobacco, transport, storage and communications, chemicals and allied products. That is shown on page 25 of the report.

Looking at the trends in more detail, we find that there has been a surge in resource-based development and real estate investment. This rise has been accompanied by a proportionate drop in manufacturing investment, hence our difficulties with our manufacturing base in this country. Specifically, in 1974- 75 foreign investment in the manufacturing sector accounted for 43 per cent of total foreign investment. Other industries, which included those I have listed, accounted for 45 per cent. In 1979 the figures were 16 per cent and 62 per cent respectively-a marked change. These figures clearly illustrate the process of Australia becoming locked into an international economy. Let us have a close look at finance investment. The Campbell report, which is still being considered by the Government, emphasised deregulation. It stated:
A feature of 1980-81 was the number of proposals submitted in which approval was sought for the establishment of new finance companies and merchant banks.

It is clear what the picture will be in the future. I turn to the regional implications of foreign investment. Figures on page 66 of the report show that foreign investment proposals by location indicate an uneven regional development . Basically, it seems that the resource rich States are currently doing very well. The figures on foreign investment by State show that New South Wales and Queensland are doing quite well, with Western Australia and Victoria some way behind. Victoria, because of the sheer size of its manufacturing sector and its significant finance sector, can still attract some investment, although on a per head basis it lags way behind. In the mining and exploration sector the figures are stark. Western Australia accounted for 51.9 per cent of all new exploration outlays. Queensland came next with 14.3 per cent. The regional implications are therefore self-evident.

If ever there was a case for national government intervention in regional development, this is surely one. We have only to look at the real estate sector, an issue which has attracted some interest in recent times. On the admission of the Treasurer (Mr Howard), detailed figures on foreign investment in Australian real estate are not available. He gave that answer in reply to a question from Ralph Jacobi as late as 13 October last year. The figures in the Foreign Investment Review Board report on this issue are quite damning. Total recorded foreign investment in urban real estate increased by $431.7m in 1980-81. The most significant areas were the development and sale proposals-capital gain finance activity-which should net foreign investors $439.4m in 1980-81 compared with only $81.2m in 1979-80.

There seems to be a genuine concern throughout the country about rural areas. The real situation is obscured by the fact that the Government has exempted real estate transactions of less then $350,000 from the need for foreign investment review and investigation. Detailed registration of foreign land ownership is therefore not made. There is a real feeling in property circles, however, that large gains are being made through the speculative purchase and sale of rural land. The overall data for capital inflow indicates that foreign investment inflows in 1980-81 totalled $5,625m which was much higher than the 1979-80 figure of $2,961m. The FIRB notes the concern expressed in many circles about the extent of this inflow and states:

Foreign investment policy was not designed to be an instrument for external economic policy, or for domestic monetary stabilisation. Attempts to use the policy in this way, apart from their very limited effectiveness, would require large and relatively frequent swings in the policy, leading to a loss of confidence in the policy by foreign investors. This could have potentially serious implications for the longer term.

This is, in effect, an indictment of the Government's position as stated in the Treasurer's Budget speech and in comments by the head of the Department of the Treasury, Mr Stone, that the public sector must make room for this inflow. The report of the FIRB echoes these sentiments. In relation to resource development it states:

The additional funds required for the increase in investment in the resource based sector will have to come from higher saving in the domestic economy, from lower investment in other areas of the economy and from greater reliance on capital inflows or from some combination of these three alternatives.

Of course, that is the linchpin of this Government's economic policies. There has to be a diversion from our domestic requirements in order to make way for capital inflow-it has been done in the benign and rather inane belief that this will somehow create growth, development and jobs in the Australian economy-from countries whose own economies are such that if they have capital investment funds they ought to be invested in those countries. This would bring about the necessary and essential regeneration of those domestic economies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Reading the latest annual report of the Foreign Investment Review Board was a constant disappointment. Five years ago Sir Bede Callaghan was asked to inquire into the structure of industry and the employment situation in Tasmania. He produced a worthwhile report that made some points which were relevant to all of Australia. One was the dependence of Tasmania on large mining and manufacturing companies serving the international market. Five years later we find Sir Bede heading the Foreign Investment Review Board and doing his best to steer Australia on to the same course of development that he warned Tasmanians about. I was present at a seminar in Sydney this year organised by the Real Estate Institute. Sir Bede said quite clearly that his aim was to facilitate and aid foreign investment, particularly in resources, in this country. Again, in an address to a Citibank international finance symposium he said that capital will go only where it is welcome and well treated. Sir Bede has certainly put his ideas into practice at the FIRB. Between April 1976 and June 1981 only 1.2 per cent of nearly 7,000 investment proposals put to it were rejected and 3 per cent in the year of the report which is before the Senate today. Last year three out of five investment dollars were used in the acquisition of existing Australian businesses.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party's concern about this aspect of foreign investment is well known. I will deal with particular aspects of the Board's latest report. The first is the continuing decline in the actual amount of capital brought into this country in that more and more companies are using retained earnings or debt capital raised in Australia to finance their operations. Needless to say, they still repatriate huge amounts to their parent companies. Unfortunately, anyone who looks to the FIRB report for details of this activity will be confused. The report uses dubious accounting procedures that try to show that the demand by foreign companies for Australian capital is not as great as it is. My own figures, for the year 1978-79, show that 65 per cent of new money raised by multinationals came from Australian investors. The vast proportion of this is debt, not equity, capital. The difference this makes in terms of control of the capital is obvious. However, the FIRB uses a rather strange method of arithmetic to show that only 47 per cent of the money came from Australians.

In order to put this use of local capital markets in perspective we need only to look at the situation in 1977-78. In that year, only 18.9 per cent of funds raised by multinationals came from Australia. The next year it jumped to 65 per cent. If these figures are related to the total level of savings in the economy, it can be seen that Australian borrowings by foreign-controlled corporations rose dramatically from 1.4 per cent of savings in 1977-78 to 18.8 per cent in 1978-79. When these effects of the resources boom are combined with this Government's monetary policy the results are dramatic. Credit in other allegedly less profitable sectors has dried up. In the three years from July 1977 to July 1980 overdraft limits increased by 33 per cent overall. Within this general rise -a small one in real terms-some sectors did better than others. Agriculture gained only an 11.4 per cent rise. Finance gained a massive 61.2 per cent rise. Consumer credit has tightened. In fact, there has been a 21 per cent drop in the real value of credit to individuals.
Although I disagree with the Campbell report on many things, its view of this crowding out of small borrowers is similar to my own. The Campbell report states at page 618:

. . . the committee notes that, within an overall policy framework of monetary restraint, higher rates of capital inflow (channelled into resource development) might entail a lower availability of finance for certain groups in the community , such as small businesses and home buyers. This in turn might create some social tensions.

The reality is that via the resources boom there has been a dramatic increase in foreign investment which has strained the capital market. To prevent any benefit of the boom spilling over to the rest of the community, the Government clamped down on the money supply, thus throwing the burden of adjusting to the flood of foreign investment on to wage and salary earners, small business people and farmers. The FIRB, through its abdication of responsibility, has fed the Australian people to the financial wolves of multi- national business organisations. Although I am cricical of the Board, of course the Fraser Government must bear the full responsibility for the policy that is being followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I compliment Senator Childs on a very fine and well-rehearsed speech with which I totally concur. I will be brief because my attitude towards the Foreign Investment Review Board is well known, along with the attitudes of other notorious critics of the Board, such as my friend Senator Tate, who-I paraphrase him-once described the FIRB as follows: 'In this country we seem to have, on behalf of the Government, a colonial mentality towards foreign investment which puts our political sovereignty at risk'. That attitude does seem to exist. I want my friend, Senator Martyr, who I understand will follow me in this debate, to comment on this. We do seem to have a colonial mentality; we seem to relish being taken over; there seems to be an adoration of and an obeisance to foreigners who take over our assets. I liked the expression used by Senator Gietzelt. He said that the Foreign Investment Review Board's report is almost a handbook guide to foreigners to take over Australia. It says, almost: 'This is the best value for any foreigner in taking over something in Australia'. It goes against my grain that taxpayers' money is being used to provide this sort of information.

SPEECH.PARA: I am critical of this report. I do not know how hard-worked the Board is but it took the Board from 30 June 1981 until 17 December-six months later-to place its report on its rather doubtful activities before the Treasurer (Mr Howard). It then took until the end of February for it to be debated in this place. Like Senator Childs I am critical of the FIRB. But I wonder whether the real blame should not be sheeted home to the Treasurer and to the Government because clearly the Board is implementing the Government's policies. I repeat for the record that last year 1,733 proposals were received by the Board and only 40 were rejected. I have spoken before in this chamber about the approval of applications relating to private hospitals. I think it is disgusting that foreigners are coming into Australia and making money out of the terminally ill and are being subsidised under our Medibank scheme. I find it absolutely offensive that this Government is aiding and abetting that sort of activity. I have alerted the Parliament about the incursions of foreign companies into the ownership of land. I was pleased to see some token action on this matter taken recently by the Government.

I am disturbed that foreign investment is now moving into uranium. One concern recently bought 25 per cent-which is the maximum amount allowable-of Energy Resources of Australia Ltd. It is almost sickening to read some sections of the Board's report. On page 3 it states, almost proudly:
Only a relatively small number of proposals were rejected in 1980-81-about 3 per cent of the total requiring decision. This low figure is a reflection of the fact, inter alia:
Some proposals were withdrawn by their proponents once it became clear to them that the proposals were likely to be rejected unless changed to meet the Government's policy requirements.
That is almost an attempt by the Board to have a clean sheet, to have 100 per cent of applications accepted. The report continues:

Many proposals which would otherwise have been rejected were approved after modification to make them consistent with policy requirements. A number of the more significant cases were modified to eliminate features in conflict with the policy as a result of discussions between the parties and the Board.

What a cosy arrangement that is. A foreign company can come into Australia and say: 'We want to take something over'. The Board then says: 'That does not quite meet with the rules, but if you change this or change that we will give a stamp of approval for this and it will be okay'. I find it offensive that Australians- an officer of the Department of the Treasury is a member of the Board-are aiding and abetting people in taking over our assets. The report continues:
With other proposals, rather than advising rejection, the Board recommended to the Government that approval be granted, subject to the parties to the proposals meeting certain prescribed conditions.

In other words, the Board, on some occasions, said: 'Here is someone who does not meet the conditions and who will not change the conditions, but we will fix it up with the Government. We will recommend to the Government that it overlook that he is not conforming to the rules'. When one looks at the terms of reference in the front of the report one wonders sometimes whether the three gentlemen who make up the Board overstep the mark in their manic desire to implement this colonial mentality which they seem to have and which seems to be fostered by the present Liberal-National Country Party Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Investment Review Board has always worried me but for reasons different from those expounded by other speakers this morning. To me the Foreign Investment Review Board has always seemed to be a restricter and a controller rather than a help to free and private enterprise. I am surprised that others in this place this morning have condemned its activities because it seems to me that the thing for which I have mostly criticised the Board, publicly and privately, is the restricting and controlling facet. I would have thought that those honourable senators opposite who have spoken this morning would have been supportive of the Foreign Investment Review Board.

SPEECH.PARA: In any case this morning Senator Walsh was basically concerned with two matters . He alleged foreign domination of our resources and consequent political pressures. He alleged excessive foreign ownership of rural land. I have noticed that Senator Walsh never ceases to attack the Western Australian and Queensland governments. He never ceases to attack the Federal Government too, but that is his job and what he is here for. Indeed, with one or two of his attacks I have not found myself in tremendous disagreement. I think his attack this morning on the Western Australian Government was somewhat unfortunate when he highlighted some of the present problems of the North West Shelf development. The fact is that no one has yet denied that very considerable problems are associated with the full development of the gas resource at the North West Shelf. To me it would have been fairer if Senator Walsh had waited to see what finality of negotiations would eventuate before criticising what is now a highly difficult circumstance. I can understand his opposition.

Something Senator Walsh did not seem to have taken cognisance of was the possible rearrangement of gas marketing which, with some small adjustment, could possibly give extensive profit as well as paying for the subsequent development of the oil resources in the same area. Obviously I cannot speak too much further on this because these are matters of quite intensive negotiation. They are factors which Senator Walsh, if he is aware of them, should have been fair enough to tell the Senate. So it is my worry that foreign investors will be concerned enough not to come to places such as Western Australia where we desperately need them. They will be put off by attacks in this place and in the other House. They will become worried that an attitude will develop in Australia amongst the people. Such an attitude has already started and been fanned during various election campaigns. Somehow or other it appears that the multinational companies and the investors of risk capital are not welcome in Australia.

In Western Australia we are vitally concerned to keep up the flow of foreign investment. I do not accept Senator Childs's figures about the importance of local investment and the way that local investment is harnessed by overseas companies. My own impression is that we cannot get local risk capital in large enough lumps to do what needs to be done. I do not demean spending on gambling, booze, tobacco, holidays and home improvements; people are entitled to do what they like with their own money and I hope that they do it in moderation. But it seems to me that if this is where the money is going it does not leave much for savings and therefore for local investment. I think we have experienced this problem in this country for a long time. As I understand it, the main local investment is in hire purchase and housing which, of course, is entirely different from risk capital which we need for the bigger mineral developments.

I move from the risk capital aspect which I think Senator Walsh raised in part to some of his thoughts about land sales to foreign owners. I can well understand that people could be concerned about this. But the only complaints that I have heard were from local owners of fairly large rural properties in various parts of Western Australia who were not prepared to pay the going market price for large tracts of rural land. I did not hear any complaints at all from the sellers of those properties. I suppose that that is understandable. The sellers were satisfied with the price they got and, of course, those who were not prepared to pay the price were extremely dissatisfied and proceeded to find reasons to complain and somehow to blame the Government just because they were not able to get a piece of land at the price they felt they ought to pay.

I think governments ought to be very wary of becoming involved in arguments which essentially are about what price is paid. It is not that I am without some understanding of the fact that if this situation is left totally unobserved it might get out of control. What are we really worried about in regard to foreign ownership? Foreign owners cannot take the land away. They cannot take away any of the expertise or other things that we gain in Australia. It seems to me that the tax structure as it is imposes a pretty solid levy on such investors from which all of us gain.

TALK.START.PARA: —You finish up feeling a stranger in your country.

—I recognise the point made by Senator Elstob. I do not feel a stranger in my own country. Indeed, there are probably more reasons for me to feel a stranger in the Senate. I cannot see what Opposition senators are worried about at this stage. There is nothing to be worried about. We are the net gainers of foreign investment and foreign capital particularly in the risk area. I put to the Senate that the time is coming-I hope sooner rather than later-when we ourselves will be exporters of capital. I wonder-if some of us are still around at that stage-how we will react to the complaints that no doubt will arise in other countries about Australian capital and the alleged influence it is having on the conduct of government in those countries. It seems to me that this is one of those storms in a teacup. It seems to me that the reasons I have advanced for being concerned about FIRB as a restricter of foreign capital investment in this country rather than as an encourager have more validity than the worries of the Opposition about an organisation which essentially is its friend and not mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a few remarks on the report brought down by the Foreign Investment Review Board. While in some ways I could be critical of the report I believe that to have the report and some action is better than having no action at all. I believe a number of areas in the report could be tightened up and a number of actions taken by the Government. I do not agree with the previous speaker, Senator Martyr, in relation to the amount of land in Australia that we should sell to foreign investors. I believe that Australians should be very jealous of their heritage and of the fact that they should own their country rather than its being a paradise for foreign investors. One of the problems I see is described on page 33 of the report in a section concerning foreign investment in real estate in which the Government has exempted from need for foreign investment approval real estate transactions of less than $350,000. It seems to me that if we talk about $350,000 it is not a small real estate transaction. The transaction becomes bigger and bigger, not necessarily because of the amount of money being paid but because of where the transaction is taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, you would be aware of the purchase in Queensland of land on beach fronts and in rain forest areas where for $350,000 a foreign investor could buy, without any approval from the Foreign Investment Review Board, large tracts of land for future development. I believe no exemptions should be made for foreign investment in Australia. It should be a clearly stated duty of the Board to see that approval is sought and given before any foreign money goes into the purchase of land close to a capital city or where we know that in 10 or 12 years there will be high-rise tourist developments. There should be no exemptions by the Foreign Investment Review Board for the purchase of land that may be developed in the future.

The second problem that I see in relation to investment is the lack of any investment portfolio. There should be a very clear listing of every purchase and it should be available for people in this country to view so that they can see what investment has taken place. We should put a figure on the maximum amount of foreign investment permitted in Australia. In my opinion that figure should be very low.

Another problem that we face is that of nominee companies, and Australians acting as agents for foreign investors. Nominee companies provide one way for investors to invest in Australia without the Foreign Investment Review Board having any close look at the investment. In Queensland a Japanese investor sought to purchase further land close to the establishment that he already had there. He could not get permission from the Foreign Investment Review Board. A $ 2 nominee company was then set up in Melbourne and bought the land. Six months later we found that cattle on the property belonged to the person who purchased the original land and that some of his employees were working there. Surely controls over those types of dealings can be tightened up. We cannot allow the Australian people or Australians to be placed in a position where foreign investors can so easily get willing Australians to act as a nominee company to purchase land in Australia on their behalf. I believe that the activties of the Foreign Investment Review Board should be tightened up to show the people of Australia that the Board has the power to control foreign land purchases and investment in Australia generally.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH COUNCIL FOR RURAL RESEARCH AND EXTENSION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1980-81

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

It is most unfortunate that today we have before us for debate a document from an extinct organisation. This is one of the many organisations which became the victim of the so-called razor gang. It is most enlightening to look at some of the remarks in this report about the establishment of the Council. I will not quote it all but I need to quote parts of it. Under the heading 'Establishment of Council' the report states:
The Industries Assistance Commission's Report, Financing Rural Research (1976), recommended the establishment of a Bureau of Rural Research within the Department of Primary Industry.
The recommendations of the Commission were to some extent anticipated in the Green Paper, Rural Policy in Australia (1974) . . .

Of course that Green Paper was compiled and published by the then Whitlam Government. Despite the fact that it is often said by honourable senators opposite that the Australian Labor Party, whether in government or opposition, has no interest in primary industry, that Green Paper was prepared under the Ministership of Ken Wriedt, who was the then Minister for Primary Industry. It is now often referred to by agricultural people as their bible. Whenever one picks up a document which deals with primary industry one will see that the Green Paper 'Rural Policy in Australia (1974)' is often quoted. It has been a very valuable document. It is also referred to in this report in the following terms:

. . . had suggested an advisory group to report to the Ministers for Primary Industry and Science in the Australian Government, and to the State Governments through the Australian Agricultural Council.
In the last paragraph about the establishment of the Council, the report states:

In August 1978, the then Minister for Primary Industry announced Cabinet's decision to establish the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension as an advisory body reporting to the Minister. The establishment of the Council was thus a Commonwealth initiative.

Those of us who have taken a long-standing interest in primary industry can recall the great hullabaloo and all the fine public pronouncements made by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) when he announced the establishment of this Council. It was a great thing for primary producers but it did not last very long. It was very short-lived. I wonder what the thinking of Mr Nixon was when the razor gang included the abolition of this Council in its recommendations. He could not have fought very hard for it, which proves to me that he was not very sincere when in August 1978 he made his grandiose announcements about the establishment of the Council. It was just a political ploy because an election was coming up in 1980. Once again we see that, whilst this Government is prepared to make grandiose statements about what it is going to do to assist primary industry, there is very little depth in those promises as in the promises that it makes on many other things.

It is very fortunate for primary producers that the current reference of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources is an inquiry into the Commonwealth's role in rural research and extension services and the contributions of those services to the development of the rural sector and the Australian economy. We are well into our public inquiries on that reference. As I said, it is very fortunate for primary industry people in Australia that at least a body is now looking at the Commonwealth's role, despite the fact that the Council has been abolished. I think its abolition was a retrograde step by the Government and I hope that primary producers, at the next election, will remind particularly National Country Party members that they have let them down and have not been prepared to carry out those grandiose promises which they made .

It would have been nice to have a submission from this Council to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources so that we could question members on the needs of primary industry. But unfortunately members of the Council cannot appear before the Committee with a submission, or represent this body because it no longer exists. As I have said, it is unfortunate that this is the last report of this body to be tabled in the Parliament, but I hope that some of the former members of that Council will see fit to make a private submission to our inquiry so that we can follow through some of the good work that they were doing as members of the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOUTH AUSTRALIAN LOCAL GOVERNMENT GRANTS COMMISSION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I mention briefly that the South Australian Local Government Grants Commission is another organisation which was set up by the Dunstan Labor Government in South Australia. I commend it for the good work that it is doing. I personally know two of the people on the Commission, Dr Ian McPhail and Mr Gordon Johnson. Mr Gordon Johnson is well known in local government circles in South Australia and is a former president and councillor of Pinaroo. Whenever one goes to local government meetings in South Australia one sees both of these gentlemen. They talk to councillors and learn what they can in addition to what they learn in their official capacities and from receiving official submissions. They learn by word of mouth about many of the problems which exist in local government areas in South Australia. I repeat that this organisation was set up by a Labor Government in South Australia. It is one of the few organisations that have not felt the axe of the present Tonkin Liberal Government. Ever since it came into office in 1979, it has set about abolishing, at a very rapid rate, a lot of the organisations which were serving the State well. It will have to be very quick if it wants to abolish any more organisations as it is getting near the end of its term. Labor will be back in government at the first opportunity. My attention was attracted to the following paragraph on page 7 of the report:

With the winding down of the Monarto Development Commission and the annexation of the Monarto site to the District Council of Murray Bridge, as gazetted on 13 August 1981, no further grant will be made to the Monarto Development Commission . These changes should not affect the level of grants to the District Council of Murray Bridge until the 1983-84 grant cycle.

There has been quite a lot of discussion in the Murray Bridge District Council as to what will be its responsibilities for land under the jurisdiction of the Monarto Development Commission. A lot of that land has now been sold back to some of the previous landholders. I think the people of South Australia will live to regret the decision of the Tonkin Liberal Government to sell off this very valuable land which will be needed for future development in South Australia. As I said earlier, that Government has been too hasty in winding up a lot of organisations which were set up by the State Labor Government.

The winding down of the Monarto Development Commission goes a little further than that. The Tonkin Liberal Government has lost control of the economy of the State, just as this Government has lost control of the economy of Australia. The Tonkin Government is selling off all its assets in order to try to balance the books. The Monarto Development Commission is one such asset. Although that Government has been able to boast that its budget has blown out only to a certain degree, when we look at the fine figures we see that it is getting money in by selling off those assets which belong to the people.

When Labor is elected to govern, either at the end of this year or early next year, the Public Service, the Highways Department, the Engineering and Water Supply Department, and all of these other services where people have been retrenched and equipment has been sold will be run down. The Labor Government will then have to turn around and find money to re-establish all of those organisations. Tonkin will get up shortly and say: 'We have a balanced budget'. But where did he get it? He gave away $30m of taxpayers' money by abolishing gift and succession duties to help his wealthy friends. He has to get the money from somewhere so he is selling off the assets of the State. This report of the South Australian Local Government Grants Commission refers in a roundabout way to the winding down of the Monarto Development Commission. As I have said, that is one way in which Tonkin is finding money to try to balance the books. But he has not fooled the people of South Australia. They are well aware of what he is doing. He will get his just desserts as soon as the people can get to the polls. The sooner that happens the better. South Australia is getting into a desperate financial situation, as is the whole of the Commonwealth of Australia under the jurisdiction of Liberal governments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1980-81

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The majority of honourable senators would be aware of my attitude to the Standing Order which provides such little time to debate matters of great importance dealt with in reports presented to Parliament. A period of 90 minutes certainly is not enough for everybody to have a go. For that reason I will be quite brief. I wish to speak to this issue because in the foreword to the report of the Atomic Energy Commission, under the heading 'Advisory Committee', we find this:

Function: To review periodically the health and safety standards and procedures adopted by the Commission in the operation of its reactors and in the use of radiation, radioactive substances and toxic materials.
I want to refer mainly to that part which states:
. . . and in the use of radiation, radioactive substances and toxic materials.

A town called Capel in the south of Western Australia has been using radioactive substances for land fill. This is creating a health hazard for the people who live there. I asked a question of the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) on Tuesday of this week. The information that he has given me is quite startling. He stated that at Byron Bay-he understood that the situation at Capel was very similiar-one would need to have something like 1,200 hours exposure to get the equivalent radiation of two chest X-rays a year. If we want to put it in perspective we have to look at what that 1,200 hours means. On my calculations that is 50 days. If one is confined to one's home for 24 hours a day that would result in 14 non-elective X-rays a year. In the case of a person who was working and was at home only 14 hours during the day and perhaps only 10 hours on a weekend we come down to six non-elective X- rays each year. In the case of a person who was working, who was in the home for 14 hours a day and who spent his or her entire weekends away-a total of 70 hours a week-we find that for every 170 days that person would have the equivalent of two chest X-rays or four X-rays a year. According to newspaper reports there are many areas in Capel where the level is much higher than that quoted as being satisfactory. A report in the West Australian on Wednesday of this week stated:
Inside homes where tailings had been used as land fill, the levels ranged from 11 to 223.
That is, 11 microrems to 223 microrems. The report continued:
In the yards of 26 other dwellings, the range had been from 30 to 700. In nine vacant lots, the range had been 40 to 1,500.

Now 1,500 rems-even 40 rems, I dare to suggest-could prove to be quite an undesirable level. We have not yet been convinced-I do not think the people who deal in radioactivity are yet convinced-that it is only high level radiation which is a dangerous substance. A recent report shows that the low level of radiation causes much greater problems in the long term than anything that is considered to be high level immediate radiation.

There are matters in this annual report to which I want to turn my attention. I will come back to Capel at a later stage, when discussing a different report. On page 62 of the report we find the heading 'Major Overseas Developments of Regulatory Significance'. The report then goes on to list four accidents which are considered to be of such significance as to require tightening the regulations. One of those was the accident which occurred at Three Mile Island in March 1979. The report goes on to say:

This . . . has had major repercussions in the nuclear regulatory scene, not only in the USA but world-wide. As a result, during the period under review, significant changes were made in the regulatory requirements for nuclear plant in the USA. These changes included design improvements to reactors similar to those at Three Mile Island, raising the standards of operator competence, and an urgent upgrading of emergency response plans.

In 1980 I put out from my office the third edition of a collation entitled ' Safety Record of the Nuclear Power Industry: Accidents, leaks, failures and incidents'. I am curious to know why, if we had documentary evidence to show that the first accident occurred in 1950, it has taken 32 years to tighten up the regulatory procedures to prevent, or perhaps preclude, an accident similar to that which occurred at Three Mile Island happening again. It appears to me that if we are, as we are constantly being told, going to enter the nuclear age, we have to ensure, for the safety of people in Australia, that our regulatory procedures are tight from the word go. This is perhaps why I have raised the subject of Capel. If the Atomic Energy Act as it stands provides-the Minister informed me the other day that he was responsible for radioactive substances-for the Minister to have that power, we have to ask why he does not have the power to prevent the use of radioactive materials for land fill, particularly in domestic areas where people will be living, working and going to school. The report continues:

The clean-up and recovery of the damaged plant is proving a slow and complex task. The objective is the removal from the reactor vessel of the nuclear fuel, most of which was badly damaged during the accident, for safe disposal.

I have to question what the report means by 'safe disposal'. Have the people concerned gone to the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission to see what methods it is planning on using for the 'safe' disposal of the very large quantities of radioactive contamination inside the containment building? I do not believe that scientists can yet say that we have discovered the safe disposal methods for any radioactive waste. In looking at the report we find that one of the other incidents related to Indian Point, Unit No. 2. In the document I have already referred to entitled 'Safety Record of the Nuclear Power Industry: Accidents, leaks, failures and incidents', we note that this is not the first accident that has occurred at the Indian Point unit. In fact, when I was in the United States in 1976 I decided as part of my tourist bit to see George Washington's place of birth. When I went to catch a ferry I was disturbed to find a very large sign on the banks of the Hudson River saying: 'Do not come in contact with this water. It is contaminated'. It did not say what it was contaminated with, but it could have been contaminated by the Indian Point nuclear reactor because of what is said in the report. It states:
On 17 October 1980, it was discovered that the floor of the containment building had been flooded with water from the Hudson River, which is the source of cooling water for the plant.

The report goes on to explain that the water is used for cooling the plant and then put back into the Hudson River. It is no wonder that I saw many fish floating on the top of the Hudson River which had obviously been affected by the pollution. I promised my colleagues that I would not take my full time. I am sorry that my remarks have taken so long. My time has almost expired. In those circumstances and because there are other people who wish to speak on other reports, I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage.
Leave granted.

That the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I was on my feet. I wish to speak to the matter to which Senator Coleman has been addressing herself.

—I have not put the motion. Senator Coleman has sought and been given leave to continue her remarks. I have not put the motion for the adjournment of the debate as yet; it has not been agreed to. Perhaps Senator Martyr can seek leave to make a statement on the same matter.
—I will do whatever is suitable.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I think what Senator Martyr has done is an infringement of the Standing Orders of the Senate. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand Senator Coleman's concern about the situation in Capel but I wonder, in all the circumstances, whether her concern is reasonable. An article which appeared in the West Australian of Wednesday, 24 February reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Health Department's radiological council said that though the background radiation-from tailings from a nearby mining operation used for some years in the town as landfill-was not high enough to warrant drastic action, it had recommended the removal of the tailings where possible.

That is a quote from the newspaper article to which the honourable senator has referred. It seems to me that the Public Health Department in Western Australia, regardless of which party is in power, can be trusted to look after the essential health and welfare of the people. Senator Coleman's concern is somewhat unjustified, and the attack she made on the Public Health Department in Western Australia was certainly unjustified.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not attacking the Public Health Department.
—The implication I got was pretty strong. The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The townspeople yesterday appeared not to be concerned at the survey results.
People spoken to in the streets of Capel yesterday said they were not worried. Most of them would not give their name.
They said that they had lived with the tailings for up to 20 years and had not suffered any noticeable side effects.

The honourable senator gets concerned about things without any facts. That is my concern about the honourable senator's assertions about Three Mile Island and quite a number of other matters connected with the uranium industry and the nuclear industry. It is well known that Dr Teller, the world's premier nuclear scientist, said recently that he had nearly suffered a heart attack as a result of pressure to answer all of the unjustified assertions, allegations and lies- the scare tactics that are deliberately instituted by people who, for political or whatever other reasons, are determined to destroy the uranium industry and the nuclear industry. I do not care what motivates Senator Coleman. The honourable senator may have the best of personal reasons for being opposed to nuclear energy. All I ask, not only of the honourable senator but also of a few of her colleagues, is that they stick to the essential facts and do not give us these emotional scare tactics which are not profitable to her argument, which certainly are not objective and which do not help her cause.
