SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the question of future water supplies for Australia, for both domestic and industrial purposes, is perhaps one of the most important resources questions before Australia. The Senate has before it the Institute of Freshwater Studies Bill, introduced as a private member's Bill, which aims to set up an institute of freshwater studies. Whilst the Government will oppose it, the opposition will be on the basis that the Bill would use the wrong methodology; not on the basis of opposing the goals. I want to make that perfectly clear. The Government is second to none in its belief that in Australia, the most arid continent on Earth, there should be developed the fullest practical understanding and the best uses of water, whether it be surface or aquifer. My remarks will be directed to methodology.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing to be established is that Australia, as everyone knows, is a federation. Entrenched in the Federation has been the development of six States which have a fervent desire that the water development within each State shall primarily be that State's responsibility. Let no one cause any doubt about that. We need the full co-operation of the States. There is in Australia, as honourable senators would know, an Australian Water Resources Council which is a joint Commonwealth-State ministerial body on which there is also representation from the Northern Territory. It has wide-ranging responsibilities in the development of water and in the research into water in Australia. Some time ago it established a specialist working group to undertake inquiries into the need for reform in research into water in Australia. It is acknowledged by all that there is a need to develop more expertise and co-ordination in research into water in Australia. The Australian Water Resources Council-that is, the six State Ministers, the Northern Territory Minister and the Commonwealth Minister- established this body. One of Australia's most prominent freshwater researchers, Professor W. D. Williams of the University of Adelaide, an eminent aquatic biologist, was a member of that group.

The report is not at the stage of being public as yet and therefore cannot be presented. The report has been formulated and is now passing through the officials' hands to the Ministers. But it is known, and known without qualification, that that group has decided quite emphatically-there was no disagreement on the working group's conclusion-that the establishment of an institute of freshwater studies at this time is not appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is the Minister entitled to quote from that report when he has told us it is not a public document? Honourable senators on this side of the House-and Mr Jacobi, whose Bill this is-have not been privy to the contents of that report. I ask you to rule that the Minister cannot quote from that report or tell the Senate about the recommendations embodied in it unless he is prepared to make it available to every honourable senator.
—I want to make it clear that I said I would not quote from the report.
—You just did.

—I do not need the extra help. What I said was that it is known from the States concerned and the Commonwealth, because there is a general knowledge and a general discussion beyond the working group on water, that the six States and the Commonwealth are unanimous in their view that it is not appropriate to establish a freshwater institute at his moment. I am not quoting in any way, nor am I able to do so, for the simple reason that, although I will have to refer to the document's existence because of what is happening, it is emphatically a private document until it is processed through the officers and the Ministerial Council. But I am able to state, and it is competent upon honourable senators to check with the States, that the States concerned are unanimous on their input into this general matter. I point out that Professor Williams is himself a member of that working group.
—With respect, the States have been unanimous for 80 years to do nothing about the problem.

—I am simply saying that a group of people with great expertise-more expertise, with great respect, than honourable senators here-have been given a job. I am second to none in believing that these people would do it as well as anybody else, as well as or better than honourable senators, because they are expert-
—Order! The honourable senator should be speaking to the point of order. I have not ruled on it yet. I rule that there is no point of order. I accept what the Minister said.

—I am sorry. I apologise for that. Mr Acting Deputy President, you are quite right. I will now talk to the general motion. The simple fact is that if we are to say that the best expert group that the States and Commonwealth can put together can be denigrated by saying that it has talked for years and got nowhere then we are-
—I meant the Ministers, the politicians.

—I am talking about an expert group which includes Professor Williams and others. I want to make it perfectly clear that that working party has been set up. I am not able to produce the document. If I could I would readily make it available. As soon as it is available after the Ministerial Council discussion I will be happy to give it to honourable senators .

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that one must start from the basis that one has an Australian Water Resources Council. That body has done a great deal of work over the years. Individual State water departments and commissions have been themselves highly expert in their work. Therefore, one can look with some real reason for guidance from them. What will happen is that in terms of research that body will report, as it has done in very recent days, to officers. That report will go on to the Ministerial Council in several months' time. The Ministerial Council will then, of course, make recommendations. But it is quite clear from the broad discussions which I, as the Commonwealth Minister, have had with the States that in no way do the States believe that there is an appropriate need at this moment for such an institute.

Let me put the matter into perspective. The fact is that some months ago the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced a major statement which did not get a great deal of publicity; it deserved better. He said that the significance of water in both domestic and industrial development was such that within the course of the next year an overview ought to be made of Australia's water needs through to the end of the century. I do not think anyone would deny that. The Prime Minister has communicated with each of the Premiers and asked whether the States would co-operate in a major overview to derive information on what are believed to be the needs for water to the end of the century. There have been dicussions already among the States. The Commonwealth is at this moment in the process of setting up a steering committee. The aim would be that consultants would be employed. the States have indicated that they all have a great mass of information available to them that they would like to put into the study. It is believed that the study should be capable of being concluded within the next year or 18 months. For the first time that will give a national overview. It will help the States, the Commonwealth and also the Australian Water Resources Council.

The Commonwealth has not been marking time. It has been taking progressive moves of its own. It cannot fail to be noticed that the most significant reform that has occurred in modern times in water usage and control in Australia has been the conclusion of the agreement on the River Murray between the three States concerned and the Commonwealth. That agreement is utterly significant. It is approaching its enshrinement in law. The Commonwealth has taken the initiative in doing the homework to get this done. The agreement is such that from the moment it was reached the States and the Commonwealth understood and supported the idea that its terms should operate instantly. As a result in Australia today the River Murray Commission has set into action the various measures necessary for quantity and quality control; in particular, a computer model has been set up to study the river systems and a large number of initiatives have been taken. Of course, the various measures derived from the studies by Maunsell and Partners Pty Ltd are being undertaken. A great deal of progress is being made within the Murray and Darling river systems. There has been a great deal of understanding between the governments. This has been a very good exercise in co-operation within a federation.

I take it that nobody believes that we should assert real or unreal Commonwealth power to act unilaterally in these matters. One must seek to act, if that is the case, within the Constitution and, therefore, by getting agreement with the States. Along with that the Commonwealth has been looking at its own current approaches to both water needs and water research. The Commonwealth's activities lie in a number of places. First of all, in my own Department, the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics has a very considerable knowledge and expertise in a geological sense in Australia, particularly with relation to knowledge of underground water and of aquafers in general. That is one of the existing resource areas. The Australian Atomic Energy Commission has a body of expert knowledge which is used in the tracing, ageing and measurement of water to ascertain whether it is a perennial source or a non-renewable source. That is being looked at to see how it can be co- ordinated.

Specifically, within the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation a multitude of research projects into water are going on. These overlap with other undertakings. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) has been undertaking a survey of the CSIRO to see whether there can be some better co-ordination and drawing together of water research, funds and expertise. Some thought is emerging that there might be two developments: One looking at quantity and quality and salinity control as the broad target and the other looking at underground water. They are matters that are starting to emerge . They are matters that will come together when we have the report and recommendations of the Australian Water Resources Council. It is a disability of the Senate and of anyone who speaks on this matter that one does not have a basic knowledge of how the report on research will emerge.

I suggest to honourable senators that it would be utterly premature to reach a decision on the nature and shape of research without waiting for this report. Let us think of that. It would be quite unusual for a Parliament, in the knowledge that an expert body in a federation of the States and the Commonwealth has been at work, reached its conclusion and passed it on to a ministerial council, to say: 'We do not want to know what that expert body says; we can make up our minds regardless'. I put it to the Senate that that is beyond reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was the working party constituted?

—I think the working party was constituted about a year ago. It has taken a reasonable time to reach its conclusions. I am perfectly prepared to have this debate adjourned and not to finalise the matter-I notice that Senator McLaren shakes his head but I must make this point-until the time that the Senate has before it all the information that it must have if it is going to make up its mind. Indeed, if the Opposition is going to make up its mind on this matter without knowing what the Australian Water Resources Council, the six States and the Commonwealth will recommend, I say to the Senate that that is in breach of any kind of sanity, any kind of parliamentary process. I note that the Australian Democrats have made a strong stand in public that they will never reach decisions until they have all the information in front of them. I invite the Democrats not to make a decision one way or another today but to defer until the information is available within several months time. If it is decided not to defer then the onus will be on those who make that decision to say in the Senate why they ignore what is regarded throughout Australia, by the States and the Commonwealth, as the significant expert body that can give information on this matter. It is as though one were to set out to bring in the results, as though a commission of inquiry were taking place in the country and one were to decide: 'We will not wait for the report; we will bring in the results beforehand'. I stress that.

SPEECH.PARA: Before we can make a judgment on this matter, particularly in the knowledge that the various States and the Commonwealth have a general understanding about it which is certain to be reflected throughout the report and that they do not believe in establishing an Institute of Freshwater Studies at this stage, we need to know the basis of the evidence given to this committee on inquiry comprising officers and Ministers of the six States, the Territories and the Commonwealth. To me, to do otherwise would be in frustration of all the processes of Parliament. I make that point emphatically. No one who advocates the establishment of this Institute can, in the knowledge that the expert volume of evidence will be released in the next month or two, say in this chamber: ' Nevertheless, I will ignore the evidence for some reason of my own'.

The situation is that the River Murray Agreement has been put in position and is making great progress, the States are working very well together in a national water resources program. The Federal-State water research program is perhaps inadequate but the Commonwealth is building up its co-ordination of expertise in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Bureau of Mineral Resources, the Australian Atomic Energy Commission and my Department. So much is happening at the moment and so much needs to be known about what is happening in all those areas before one can evaluate whether this institute is necessary or desirable. I ask: How can the Senate evaluate this matter without in the first place having the expert information from the CSIRO as to what its resources for research are and will be and how they will shape? How can anyone do that? It is beyond belief. How can anyone do that knowing that work is going on to try to achieve a sensible co-ordination of the research of the BMR, the AAEC and the CSIRO? How can anyone reach a conclusion without the necessary knowledge?

Against that background and against the fact that the Commonwealth has set up a Federal and State study in an overview of water resources from now until the end of the century, I say that the Commonwealth does not oppose the goals of finding a better method of research, of collecting data and of understanding water, surface and underground, in this country. On the contrary, considerable moves are presently being made to ensure that more and more is done. Against the knowledge that these inquiries are in existence and are approaching finality, I have to say that the sensible thing to do now is to defer the matter.

I repeat what I said at the beginning of my speech: In no way would the Commonwealth question the general goals to be striven for; that is, the need to undertake research, the need to find out more about water. They are acceptable. The Commonwealth is saying that in its view the way suggested is not the appropriate way and is likely to be found the inappropriate way by the States. Why would one seek to set up an institute if one is likely to find it opposed at all levels of government? Why would one not want to pause, get the reports and then look at them? If we all are genuine in our desires in this matter there is absolutely no justification for our not pausing for several months. Therefore I strongly recommend to the Senate that after there has been an informed debate on this matter the Senate adjourn consideration of the Bill until a subsequent time , until other information is available. As soon as the detailed information is available I will undertake to supply it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the setting up of an Institute of Freshwater Studies. I believe that in Australia, as in many other countries, water will be in very short supply by the end of this century. Australia is one of the driest continents on earth and South Australia is the driest State in the driest continent on earth. Not only is Australia short of water but many other countries are running into the problem of water shortage. Of course, we are all concerned with problems of water pollution. Much of this has been caused by ignorance in the past. I suppose that all countries in the past have gone ahead without really studying the effects of what they were doing with irrigation. They have opened up new land without full and informed discussions and opened up new projects without scientific evidence being obtained or thought of.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that in the past we have destroyed much of our country through ignorance. Because of the type of irrigation we have been using salinity is becoming a big problem in our nation. This is all because of ignorance. One has only to go up the Murray Valley to see the amount of land that has been destroyed by salination of the soil. Much of this has been brought about by flood irrigation. Had there been a study, probably 50 years ago, and had sprinkler or drip irrigation been used instead of flood irrigation, I believe we would not have many of these problems today. Because there was no investigation or study, much of this land became sterile. As I said, this was because of lack of knowledge.

I believe it is essential not only for South Australia, which is very dry, but also for all States to look to the quantity and quality of their water. I believe that lack of water of good quality will be a restricting factor in Australia's growth. Unless we can provide adequate quantities and quality of water in the future this country will stagnate. There is no doubt about that. I believe we have acted in ignorance in the past, and that must be stopped. Ignorance is no excuse. Today we have facilities to study what we should be doing and what we should not be doing. I believe it is criminal to allow the situation to go on in the way in which it is going. The setting up of an Institute of Freshwater Studies would result in a scientific approach to the problems. Senator Sir John Carrick said in his speech that this Senate would be making the decisions. I do not believe any honourable senator would be capable of making those decisions. I believe it is essential to set up a scientific body to look at the problems we are facing. That is all we are asking for.

In the past the States have not co-ordinated or joined together. The history of this country shows a deplorable record in that regard. I believe water should not be a political football. All political parties should be looking at and endeavouring to overcome this great problem. It is for the good of this nation. To cure the problems that have already evolved will take many years. Through our political system we will have to be sure that ongoing funding is given to such a priority. I believe all parties should be involved. I believe it is only the scientific evidence that politicians will receive in the future that will enable them to act with security. I do not agree that we politicians should just go ahead, because we would not be expert enough in this field. To get experts into an Institute of Freshwater Studies is the logical way to go about it.

The problems are not only in the Murray River. They are all over Australia. Many of our underground systems are becoming polluted because they have been ill -used due to ignorance. We cannot go on in the future destroying our natural water resources. We are doing this now unfortunately. Over much of Australia there is a salt layer. Through ignorance we have taken off the deep-rooted vegetation. Nature provided for the trees that naturally grew on our land to go through that salt layer. When we removed the deep-rooted vegetation from the land we substituted shallow-rooted vegetation which has a capacity for bringing that salt to the surface. That is one of the problems that the whole of Australia is facing. All of this has been done because of ignorance. All living plants have a capillary action. If the deep-rooted vegetation is replaced by shallow-rooted vegetation, the salt must come up. Certain areas should probably never have been cleared or irrigated but because of ignorance those things were done.

The Murray River is actually floating on salt now; there is a layer of salt within a few metres of the bottom. When the river is low the salt comes into the river. This problem cannot be solved by laymen; it has to be solved scientifically. The whole matter should be looked at scientifically. We will run into problems. As I have said, we have destroyed much of our country. We have destroyed the quality of the water, which we cannot afford to do. I do not believe this matter can be left to the States. The Commonwealth Government should look seriously at setting up an Institute of Freshwater Studies. Such an institute could pay for itself because local governments, State governments and the Federal Government could be paid by various bodies for the research done by the institute. It would not be a great expense to the Commonwealth Government. If we look at the problem seriously we see that the nation can expand and become larger, but it is not doing so because of inadequate water supplies.

We have spent very little on research on water in this country and I think that is to the great shame of all past governments. We have to learn a lesson from our past. Listening to the States, I do not believe that they will ever combine to solve many of these problems. Time is very short. We cannot go on the way we have been doing. With every passing year we destroy more of our underground systems. We destroy our rivers. We destroy the land itself through, as I have said, ignorance. That is unforgivable. We should not allow this. The quicker we can set up an Institute of Freshwater Studies, the sooner this country's future can be secured. We can expand if there is adequate planning. Some years ago there was a study into the possibility of bringing in icebergs. Many people laugh at that. This country should be looking seriously at such propositions. It is not impossible, and we may have to depend on such a solution. We cannot allow things to go on as they have done in the past. We should be looking at many options for increasing our water supply in this country. But we do not spend any money on research. That is quite inadequate; it is simply not good enough.

We are a major exporter of foodstuffs and I believe that in the future we will have to improve our track record. The population of the world is increasing and will be looking for more food supplies. We should be planning for the future to fulfil some of those needs. It is not a question of feeding and developing only ourselves. I believe that we as a nation have a responsibility to others. As I said, I think that the way in which we have treated our land and our water is criminal. We should scientifically study the problems. If politicians are given the facts, they can make sound judgments. If we wait for the States to come to an agreement we will be waiting a long time. Look at our railway systems. They are in a terrible turmoil simply because transportation in this country was left to the States. I plead with the Senate to take the initiative in setting up the Institute of Freshwater Studies and to take a lead in showing the rest of the States that it is economic to do such a thing. I believe that once we have the scientific evidence before us there can be no argument against that course of action.

The Commonwealth Government has the responsibility for the whole of this nation . The quicker we can get on with the job the better it will be. I am not in favour of pushing the matter aside. I think we should make a decision. We in the Senate are supposed to represent the States. I believe that every State in this great country will face real problems before the turn of the century. The shortage of water will be a problem not only for South Australia but also for the other States. We cannot allow the problem to go on in the future. As I said, I hope that this problem will be solved by politicians who desire to do something for their country without taking a political line. We should by serious enough-especially those of us in this chamber-to say that this will be good for the nation. We should not allow the terrible destruction of our water and soil to continue.

We should be talking amongst ourselves when we get the scientific evidence we should decide as politicians the amount of money that the scheme will cost. Ongoing funding should be guaranteed by all political parties because the matter is of such national importance. I believe that is the way to solve the problem. It should not be used as a political football. It is a great need which should be fulfilled now, not at some time in the future. We are a great nation. If we are to continue to grow we should have the capacity to overcome this problem. I ask that the Senate seriously consider supporting this Bill, which was introduced in the lower House by Mr Jacobi and by Senator McLaren in this chamber. I believe that it is a worthwhile Bill, which every one of us should support. Australia will only benefit from it. I ask each and every senator to consider the Bill seriously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today the Institute of Freshwater Studies Bill. Politicians have not fared well in the public debate on management of Australia's water resources. Sir Barton Pope, in a recent and widely distributed paper entitled 'Water Resources-A Call to Action' said:

SPEECH.PARA: Water resources-the nation's most vital resource shortest in supply in the world's driest continent is being destroyed by political unawareness, inaction or party politics . . . We want statesmen planning for the benefit of future generations, not politicians looking to the next election.
Mr Jacobi, who sponsored the Bill, also showed little mercy to his own kind when , in his second reading speech, he added:

It is politicians that have failed to manage properly our water resources, and squabbles of power and empire have put at risk our most precious resource. It is time that parochial and vested interests were swept aside, and that effective, impartial and national approaches were taken to our water resources.

From a position of the damned and condemned-perhaps not unreasonably so-we are today considering this Bill to establish an Institute of Freshwater Studies. The subject has been of deep concern to all South Australian Liberal senators. There is much in Mr Jacobi's second reading speech with which I am able to concur and at times applaud. The call for a national approach to find solutions to a national problem has my support. The deficiencies of the constitution are used to justify the lack of a national approach. That is, to my mind, a shallow justification. It is difficult to dispute much of what Mr Jacobi said in his speech on the subject of '100 years of thoughtless exploitation of the River Murray system' and the state of jeopardy in which it is now placed. That is not to discredit the recent formalisation of the River Murray Commission's responsibilities in relation to water quality, determined after many years of failure to agree. No better example can be given of the inadequacy of our Federal system to cope with water research and management than the years of bickering over the subject of whether a commission, comprising the three States concerned and the Commonwealth, should have any responsibility for water quality . No better example can be given to justify the need for a national approach to a critical resource not limited by State boundaries.

Mr Jacobi called for an urgent and considerable broadening of the Commonwealth' s role in the area of water resource management. He stressed that he did not envisage that the management responsibilities of the States would be pre-empted. What is specifically called for is that the Commonwealth establish a national institute to conduct research into specific matters affecting water management. Within that mire are two separate and distinct subject matters which are often confused in the public debate on this subject: Firstly, who should control and manage the water resources that cross State boundaries? Secondly, who should be responsible for carrying out the basic research upon which the responsible body can make appropriate management decisions? The Jacobi Bill sees the answer to the second question as the Commonwealth and proposes that the Commonwealth fill that responsibility by setting up a national freshwater institute. Neither the Bill nor the second reading speech of the Bill's sponsor provides an answer to the first question other than to recognise the constitutional difficulties, to state that the institute would not pre-empt the State management role and then largely to condemn that role as a failure referring to, in relation to the River Murray-fairly, I think-'the pathetic in-fighting between States bordering the resource, all behind the smoke-screen of ''sovereign rights''.'

The first question is really the major challenge in this whole subject and, of course, as I have said, it is not directly confronted by this Bill. The second and less complicated question is directly the subject of the proposed legislation. The South Australian Minister of Water Resources, the Honourable Peter Arnold, who has had a lifetime of involvement with the River Murray, better than most, distinguishes the problems I have mentioned. In the South Australian Hansard of 11 November 1981 it is recorded that he indicated his Government's support for the institute proposal, but distinguished between management and research. He said:

Such an institute is not a management institute; it is a research institute . . . No matter what recommendations the institute may make, it will still come back , ultimately to the States and the Commonwealth as to whether those recommendations are implemented.

He sees the management question as the first and most critical and repeats the often cited problem of the River Murray Commission, that is, its lack of executive power to carry out effectively the work that needs to be done. He sees the institute as an adjunct. His approach, therefore, is that as an adjunct the institute, as in the case of any other body with a charter to provide research in relation to water resources, would have to be supported. It is not a dissimilar view to that of Mr Jacobi. He is putting up the institute as one way of achieving a goal of more comprehensive, better co-ordinated research in freshwater studies in Australia. He concedes, by implication, that the responsibilities and activities of the proposed institute could be incorporated within the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Finally , and fairly, he concedes that the measures proposed in the Bill cannot of themselves solve all of the major water resource problems facing Australia. This is, of course, a recognition that the more difficult question is that of effective management responsibility. On that question Mr Arnold supported the ultimate solution when he said, as was reported in the Advertiser of 24 March 1981, that the South Australian Government would welcome a national body to have authority over the total river system. He said:
We would hand over power to a national body tomorrow if the other States would agree.

A similar approach to the question of management is taken in a good article by Paul Malone in the Australian Financial Review of 22 July 1981 on the subject of water resources and the difficulties facing Australia. In speaking of the Murray -Darling system, he said:

State parochialism has damaged the national management of this major resource . . . It is perhaps time to take the responsibility for this resource out of the hands of State Governments and place responsibility squarely on the shoulders of the Federal Government.

He said that Mr Jacobi's Bill could also make some contribution to a rational approach to the problem. Again, a similar attitude was expressed by Dr Sam Lake, senior lecturer in the Department of Zoology at Monash University, when, in a paper delivered to the Australian Society of Limnology in May of last year, he said:

Australia needs a national water resources policy which can assist, and if necessary, over-ride regional or State agencies. Water resource planning in Australia, State by State, is simply not good enough.
On research, Dr Lake said:
Proper long term management of water resources and freshwater ecosystems depends on the sound, co-ordinated research . . .
Later he said:

Considering the potential resources boom, and the current events problems of salinification, catchment deterioration, pollution and a spread of exotic aquatic plants and animals it is paramount that freshwater research be adequately supported.

He argued that the research answer lay in a national institute but his reasons were not developed. Presumably, in the context of his speech, he thought that an institute would see research being less fragmented and better financed. Sir Barton Pope, in the article to which I earlier referred, said:
It is to our shame that we have not got a planned centralised committee program of hydrological research and management.

He is, therefore, melding both management and research. He gave support to the proposed institute but gave no reasons. The message from this selection of quotes-from a politician, a journalist, a researcher and an accredited industrialist -is that the real challenge is the first question of control and management. Good control and management does, however, require good research. The institute concept is then picked up as the only alternative in the offing. There is not an attempt to analyse the proposal constructively but critically or to look in any other direction. But this is a responsibility that this Senate must not now avoid. Mr Jacobi's proposed institute has become a bit like motherhood; no one criticises motherhood.

An examination of the whole subject of water research was not avoided by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources in 1978 in its report 'Australia 's Water Resources-The Commonwealth's Role'. Whilst it might be said that the Committee ducked the question of control and management, it certainly dealt comprehensively with the subject of research and recommended a national water research policy and program. The Committee said:

Australia needs a clear national policy on water research which will identify significant areas, establish priorities and give encouragement both to public and private institutions to engage in, and persist with, practical research to provide a better basis for the management of our water resources.

The Committee recommended that the Commonwealth establish a national research program in accordance with a water research policy to be administered and co- ordinated by a bureau of water resources. The concept of a national water research policy and program was rejected by the Government although the Minister did say that the Commonwealth would encourage research relevant to its broad policy objectives and continue to use its influence within the Australian Water Resources Council to co-ordinate the overall national research effort. In other words, by implication, it expressed satisfaction with its contribution to research, both in quantum and direction. This, therefore, invites an assessment of Commonwealth water research support, an assessment of priorities, because criticism in the area abounds. Take simply, for example, a comment by Dr Lake, to whom I referred earlier. He said:
Although research on freshwater ecological problems is carried out in Australia it is fragmentary and poorly financed.

The Commonwealth contributes to water research in a number of ways. First, it does so by its direct financial support of the CSIRO, the universities, the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, the Bureau of Meteorology, the Bureau of Mineral Resources and others. Secondly, it helps to finance State government departments and instrumentalities in research projects through specific grants under the National Water Resources Program. Thirdly, it provides funds through the Water Research Fund, which it established in 1968, which supports the research program developed through the Australian Water Resources Council. Fourthly, it provides financial support to the Water Research Foundation of Australia. In addition to its research funds, it provides funding for the National Resources Assessment Program to co-ordinate information on the nation's surface and underground water resources.

But the role, therefore, played by the Commonwealth in assessing research priority can be best described as indirect. About one-third of the research, on the estimate of the Senate Standing Committee, to which I earlier referred, is undertaken by the CSIRO. The Government contribution to the direction of that research would be slight, as it would be to that undertaken by various universities. The Australian Water Resources Council, as the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) said, is of course a forum of State Ministers, the Northern Territory Minister and the Minister for National Development and Energy. Thus the Commonwealth's contribution to the direction of funds allocated to the Water Research Fund cannot be great. The Water Research Foundation determines its own priorities and the funds going to research under the National Water Resources Program is limited. Thus the charge is developed that Australia's water research is ad hoc and fragmented.

It appears to be almost beyond argument that the Federal Government should establish a national research program in accordance with a water research policy . But once determined, the question is how best it can be implemented-through a national institute as is suggested by this Bill, through the CSIRO, through the other existing research vehicles or in some other way. The CSIRO has many strengths. It has an international reputation of high standing as a scientific institution. It has an established administrative infrastructure. It has the strength of offering expertise in so many areas related to the subject of freshwater research-land use, mineral physics, soils, irrigation, plant life, et cetera. On the other hand, it is not equipped and is probably not the body to carry out research in the areas of economic and social evaluation which would have to be incorporated within a comprehensive research program.

The national institute concept has factors in its favour. Mr Jacobi, in his speech, gave reasons for his support. Firstly, he stressed that research by the institute would view the river system as a whole and that evaluation of benefits and costs could be assessed by the institute from a national viewpoint. I see that as the strongest reason for an institute. Secondly, he said it would be free from governmental interference. I have reservations as to whether that would be the case and, in any event, question the merit. After all, the Government must take the final responsibility for management of Australia's water resources. Thirdly, he said that the institute would examine the environmental and biological aspects of water quality. That may be so, but that does not require an institute. Fourthly, he said that it could play a role in the rapid introduction of improved technology and practices. Again, it may, but not necessarily.
The Senate Standing Committee, however, rejected the idea of an institute of freshwater research. It said:

The physical nature of the Australian continent is such that a wide range of tasks of development and opportunities for research are present. Distances are great and there is a diverse range of climate and topography. If a central research authority were established it would have to have branches located throughout Australia in order to operate effectively.

More critically, why attempt to take a group of scientists who have a particular interest from a university or the CSIRO and set them up within another institute ? It gains nothing but tends to add a limit to the institute, that is, to the research capacity of its staff scientists. Probably the answer is to leave the scientists in the other institutions and contract their expertise; but then why have an institute? If honourable senators peruse the published list of CSIRO water resource programs in both water management and water technology they will find an immense amount of worthwhile work being done. Similarly the guide to freshwater research in universities indicates the not inconsiderable expertise and interest in the subject throughout our tertiary institutions. The individual contributions of the water authorities within the States are also considerable. It appears to me that rather than setting up a new bureaucracy when the research capacity exists throughout Australia we need better co-ordination and communication. In other words, we should adopt the position of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources which said:
The need in Australia is for an improved overall assessment and co-ordination of water research through a central agency.

That must be accepted as a Commonwealth responsibility in the national interest. The Australian Water Resources Council representing the vested interests of each State government is not the appropriate body for overall assessment and co- ordination of water resources in Australia. What then is required is a new body that can, first, offer guidelines for research programs that meet Commonwealth priorities and, secondly, assess submissions for funding for particular projects from researchers and institutions. The body may not be dissimilar to the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council, NERDDC, in the energy field. The water NERDDC would be serviced by the Commonwealth Department of National Development and Energy and could incorporate users, particularly local corporations which put into practice at the most basic level much of the research information, as well as the more obvious Commonwealth and State water authority and research representation.

More importantly the Commonwealth must set the parameters and priorities within which the more detailed guidelines can be produced. My opinion is that the Commonwealth should be advised by a small council of the highest capacity. To again use the analogy of energy it may well be a water National Energy Advisory Committee. It was stated in the Department of the National Development and Energy annual report for 1980-81 that the National Energy Advisory Committee was established to advise on energy matters and to assist in the formulation and development of a national energy policy for Australia. That appears to be just what is needed for water. The same publication also stated that NERDDC was established to advise the Minister on development and co-ordination of the Government's overall effort in energy research development and demonstration and on the allocation of grants for individual projects. Similarly that criterion appears to fit the bill. The national Water Resources Council could then revert to the role for which it was set up, that is, as a forum for Ministers dealing with water resource matters of mutual interest or, in other words, an avenue for communication and liaison.

At an even more fundamental level the real challenge will come in the question of control and management. It appears to me that the national problems involved in management of a national resource can most effectively be handled by a national authority. This would require a grant of power from the States, or more effectively, constitutional change to allow the Commonwealth to legislate in the area of freshwater management. A national authority could then be set up which could, for the first time, effectively manage a national resource in the national interest. Such a move would take considerable political courage from the States, particularly Victoria and New South Wales. But I have no doubt it would be to the ultimate benefit of such States and the balance of Australia.

While I therefore applaud the spirit of Mr Jacobi's Bill I do not presently believe his proposed institute to be the most efficient or constructive way in which we can co-ordinate and upgrade water research in this country. I look forward in the near future to constructive government proposals coming out of the reviews referred to by the Minister; in the reviews of research work done by the CSIRO and the AWRC which are currently taking place. Even more so I look forward to the day the Federal Government takes a lead and urges upon the States and the people of Australia a national water authority. I will conclude by quoting a few lines from a speech by Dr Wild, Chairman of CSIRO, on 22 November 1981. He said freshwater was:
Probably the most precious resource in Australia, and the main limiting factor to growth and welfare.
He added:
Let us hope that everyone concerned-politicians, water authorities and researchers, will make the early part of the 1980s memorable for fixing a problem long overdue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to put on record both my own support and my party's support for the concept and the content of the Institute of Freshwater Studies Bill 1981 which is before us today. I do so for two main reasons. The first is that I am sick to death-as are most South Australians-of the procrastination and the buck passing that have gone on for so long between State and Federal governments, local government authorities, the River Murray Commission and other organisations interested in the problem and which have contributed greatly to the very poor quality of South Australia's water. The second reason is that as a South Australian, who for something over three decades has had to suffer the results of that procrastination, I do not feel that I can any longer stand by and allow this situation to continue.
—Have a glass of water.

—Yes, I will have a glass of water as the honourable senator opposite so generously offered. It is water which is a darn sight better to drink, a lot more palatable, a lot clearer and a lot less tasty-in water that is a good quality-than the stuff that we regularly get out of our taps in South Australia. I digress at this point because of Senator Teague's interjection to point out that there are occasions in South Australia when it is almost impossible to take a shower because the water smells so bad. We have put up with this for far too long. The Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick), who expressed the Government's opposition to the Bill, mentioned the need for perspective. I respectfully suggest to the Minister that South Australians have the most accurate perspective to offer when it comes to River Murray water and its quality and quantity.

SPEECH.PARA: A lot has been said since last October when the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) tabled a statement relating to the new River Murray Waters Agreement. The three-State-Commonwealth government agreement was going to be the first of a number of significant changes in the approach to the problem of the River Murray Waters. I suggest, and I said this last October, that the agreement is meaningless. It is significant only in that it finally, belatedly recognises officially that something must be done about the quality control of River Murray water. I made the point last October that all the States involved and the Commonwealth Government had for years been derelict in their duty in regard to finding a solution to the problem faced by South Australians as far as water supply and the quality of that water supply is concerned.

Yet the Minister can still stand up and say that there is still no need for the sort of move proposed by the Bill at this stage. One wonders how much longer we in South Australia have to wait before the Minister and this Government approve of the stage that we have reached and see it as an appropriate point for doing something. How many more reports do South Australians have to sit back and watch be commissioned before something is done and not just talked about? The Minister is being nothing more than sanctimonious in his attitude to the very real concern that South Australians feel about the issue. I remind honourable senators that the Senate is a States House. Despite what the Minister says, the Senate is more than competent to press for action to be taken on a matter such as this and to press for it to be taken now as a matter of considerable urgency. For South Australia's sake we cannot afford to pussy-foot around any longer.

The Minister referred repeatedly to expert information coming but the references that he made are a smokescreen. Indeed a smokescreen is all that the plethora of inquiries, committees and reports that have popped up with nauseating regularity over the last few decades are. They are a means by which the Commonwealth Government, a State government or some other authority can stall making a decision which might prove unpopular in some areas. Calling for reports or referrals to committees is a great and traditional means for procrastination. I share the Australian Labor Party's belief that the time for that is past. We are not the only people who believe this. People who live along the River Murray within the South Australian border, people who drink and use River Murray water, all agree that the time for procrastination is past.

This Bill seeks to do something positive. At worst, the setting up of the Institute can do no harm, which is more than can be said for some government initiatives. At best it will provide the opportunity for the development of a permanent data collecting agency, for a central forward planning body, for an impartial evaluation system, for in essence an organisation solely designed to co-ordinate the research into Australia's most precious resource. Even the Minister has to admit that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization does not have the charter, resources, time or staff to concentrate solely on the problems of water quality in Australia.

Other countries recognise the need for a unique institute whose charter allows it-indeed expects it-to concentrate on water research. There is no need for Australia not to follow that example. The River Murray Commission cannot achieve such a mammoth task. It has no powers now and it certainly does not have the resources to do so. A multigovernmental body certainly will not. There is too much at stake to leave the matter to the vagaries of the State versus State, party versus party or State versus Commonwealth Government politics. A new approach is very clearly required. The dismal failure of previous approaches is a clear indication of this. I point out to Senator Hill, who said that the idea of an Institute of Freshwater Studies was not approved of by the Senate committee, that Senate committees are not infallible and that the knowledge and experiences of people who are very close to the problem certainly warrant some consideration.

The Murray is dying. It must be the one river in this country on which one can walk. If that is not the case now it is rapidly approaching that stage. If we do not do something to halt this South Australia is going to die. That the Minister can sit back and ask us in South Australia to wait for the results of yet another interminable report is an indictment of the present Government's attitude to the needs and rights of smaller States. Despite the Minister's little homily about the Australian Democrats waiting until the latest inquiry is completed before making a decision, I can assure him that we believe that enough information has been gathered over the years and enough knowledge has been garnered. We believe that the problems are self-evident, that the half-hearted solutions of the past have just as evidently failed and no more information is required to prove to any thinking person that South Australia's water problems need urgent and positive action.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all agreed on that.

—We may well be all agreed on it but what we are clearly not agreed on is that the time is now, if it was not a decade ago, to do something definite about it. Putting it off again and again is no solution. I cannot understand how any South Australian senator can listen to his Minister say; 'The time is not yet upon us'. It is. Although instigators of this Bill admit quite openly that it is not going to turn the River Murray into a crystal clear stream by next week, it will go some way towards a permanent solution to the problems that we face in South Australia. Even though it will not be an overnight solution its instigation could well halt the present deterioration of the quality of River Murray water and turn the tide-if that expression can be used for a stream of water which barely moves let alone turns-so that the one and a half million South Australians who are to a great degree dependent on that water for drinking and irrigation purposes can once again have access to water which is the worst in Australia if not in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I deplore the Government's politicising of the issue. I assure the Senate and the people of South Australia that the Australian Democrats are prepared and determined to contribute to a multi-party approach to finding a solution to the problems inherent in our consumption of River Murray water. I commend Mr Jacobi for his action and concern in initiating this Bill. I make no apology for the stand that the Democrats are taking on the issue. I wholeheartedly support both the concept and the timing of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly welcome the opportunity to enter this debate on the Institute of Freshwater Studies Bill and am grateful to Mr Jacobi for introducing the matter so that the important question can be debated in this place. I suppose that people would agree that I have taken a very strong interest in water resources in Australia for the very good reason that I believe that by the year 2000 or thereabouts our water resources will be fully committed.
—By the year 2000 there won't be a River Murray.

—The honourable senator obviously has not travelled the River Murray as much as I have. I admit that I walked across the River Murray mouth when the river closed last year but subsequently I went back and 27 feet of water was running through the mouth. This is a problem which has been with us for centuries and it behoves us all to have a national look at the whole question of not only the River Murray system but every other river system in Australia. I believe there is certainly a need for a more co-ordinated effort with respect to research into fresh water in Australia. I do not think the Bill goes far enough. People should remember that, of the water that falls on this continent each year, 50 per cent runs into the ocean and is wasted. Of the rest about 90 per cent evaporates. So only a very small amount of water is retained on the Australian continent for our use. Of that, one per cent is used for domestic purposes, industrial and municipal consumption and 7 per cent is used for the irrigation of about one million hectares of crops and for watering stock . I will seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a letter I wrote last year, one which attracted the attention of the editor of the Australian Financial Review. In it I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Recently, researchers at a Melbourne university provided a graphic example of the problems to be faced when they carried out a study of proposed coal liquefaction plants to be built in the La Trobe Valley. Noting that these plants required large amounts of water, they estimated that, to supply the demand, the entire annual mean flow of the Upper La Trobe rivers would be required by the year 2010. Further, it would result in a 50% reduction in the annual flow into Lake Wellington by the year 2020 and would require the total flow of all East Gippsland rivers by the year 2039.
That is a very graphic description of what was discovered by those researchers who made a careful examination of the problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did that come from?
—That research was undertaken by the La Trobe University. I will incorporate that letter in Hansard. That will give honourable senators the information that they require. That letter also said:

SPEECH.PARA: Not all the problems associated with the availability of water are in the future . Recently,-
Last year-
attention has been focused on farmers in the Narrabri area of N.S.W. who draw extensively for water from a small artesian basin. It is expected that next season,-
That is, this season-
those farmers on the outskirts of the basin will experience water shortages as a direct result of indiscriminate use of artesian water.

Senator Hill mentioned Sir Barton Pope. He has been very anxious for something to be done not only with respect to research into our surface water but also our artesian water of which there is a considerable quantity. It is quite important that we assess the amount of artesian water available to us and the average water table that should be maintained in order that we do not mine that very important resource. I was talking to someone from the American Embassy over lunch. That person said that America is experiencing problems similar to those which apply in our country. In effect America is mining some of its artesian basins. It behoves us to take action to ensure that that does not happen here.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I ask the honourable senator whether he seeks leave for the incorporation of that letter in Hansard.
—At your suggestion, Mr President, I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-

PROCTEXT.PARA: OFFICE OF SENATOR DON JESSOP
Commonwealth Parliament Offices A.M.P. Building 1 King William Street Adelaide, S.A. 5000 Telephone: 216 3483 216 3484
Dear Sir,

At a time when more and more newspaper space is being devoted to details of new or prospective resource developments, I think it is timely to point out that the availability of adequate water supplies will have a major bearing on the success of these projects.

Many, if not all, of the developments require the availability of reasonably large amounts of water if they are to proceed. At the same time, however, many of these projects are situated in areas where water is either scarce or committed elsewhere.

Recently, researchers at a Melbourne university provided a graphic example of the problems to be faced when they carried out a study of proposed coal liquefaction plants to be built in the La Trobe Valley. Noting that these plants required large amounts of water, they estimated that, to supply the demand, the entire annual mean flow of the Upper La Trobe rivers would be required by the year 2010. Further, it would result in a 50% reduction in the annual flow into Lake Wellington by the year 2020 and, would require the total flow of all East Gippsland rivers by the year 2039.

Not only would these demands have serious effects upon the surrounding environment but problems would also arise because of the competition for water between the existing agricultural users and the proposed plants.

Not all the problems associated with the availability of water are in the future. Recently, attention has been focused on farmers in the Narrabri area of NSW who draw extensively for water from a small artesian basin. It is expected that next season, those farmers on the outskirts of the basin will experience water shortages as a direct result of indiscriminate use of artesian water.

As the years progress it is reasonable to expect that more of these problems will arise unless governments act now to adopt a co-ordinated approach to the conservation and management of Australia's water resources.

I believe that what is required is a national programme which would identify objectives and co-ordinate government efforts in their attainment. Obviously, in reaching any goals the financial assistance of the Federal Government is vital and active participation by industry should be encouraged.

Unless governments act now to implement such a plan of action, development in Australia will undergo a decline from the beginning of the next century, and could cease altogether towards the end of that era,
Yours sincerely,
DON JESSOP Senator for South Australia

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator JESSOP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I seek leave also to incorporate in Hansard an article that I wrote for the Australian Liberal-a very well read journal.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walsh-I think we had better see that incorporation.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator JESSOP

TALK.START.PARA: —What Sir Barton Pope said was quite correct; we have to deal with the question of artesian water as well. In my view a national water authority ought to be established. I agree that the wheels of government grind exceedingly slowly. I believe it is urgent for the Government to recognise that unless we take action now the development of Australia's resources beyond the year 2050 will considerably slow down, if not cease altogether. I took the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick, up to the northern part of South Australia late last year to have a look at the potential of the mineral projects at Roxby Downs in the Olympic Dam area and also at Stoney Point. One of the first questions I ask these mining companies and the people wishing to develop such resources is: 'How much water do you require?' Quite often I think developers go in without having that thought foremost in their minds. I assure honourable senators that an incredible amount of water will be required to develop that resource for South Australia.

INTERJECT.PARA: I am encouraged also at the concept of a national approach. I envisage an Institute of Freshwater Studies to be included under the umbrella of such an authority. I envisage also that not only do we require scientific information and expertise but also we require engineering expertise. Perhaps the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority could well be the engineering institute within such an organisation that I am describing. Only with massive engineering ability and massive scientific advice will we be able to do something about diverting the 50 per cent of our water that currently is being wasted each year into the oceans surrounding our continent. I strongly support the concept of the Bill that is before us but I do not think it goes far enough. It suggests:
In making recommendations with respect to the functions of the Institute, the Interim Council shall give consideration to the need for-

(a) information and research necessary to provide for the efficient management by the Commonwealth and the relevant States of the interstate river systems, with particular reference to be given to the River Murray and its tributaries;

I think the word 'management' is the key word there. This Institute would not perform that important function. I believe that that is an inadequacy in this measure. In addition, I thought that one of the prime functions of this Institute of Freshwater Studies would be, as a matter of priority, to examine ways and means in which the Commonwealth and the States could co-operate to establish a national authority to manage Australia's freshwater reserves.

I am encouraged also by the support that has been forthcoming from no less than 12 councils in the River Murray area for the concept of a national approach to this problem. I indicate that district 5 or 7 of the River Murray league is also right behind that concept. The Premier of South Australia and the Minister of Water Resources are behind the proposition of a national approach to this matter . To my knowledge it is the first time that any State government has come forward and risen above the parochial attitude that quite often arises. I have always said that water knows no State boundary and should know no political boundaries either. Therefore, we all have to work together in an effort to try to convince all the States and the Commonwealth that what we are doing is not only in the national interest but also in the interest of future State development. Without water the States cannot develop either.
The Victorian Chambers of Commerce and Industry sent me a letter in December last year. This letter, which is signed by John L. Harrower, Managing Director of that organisation, states:
I have read with interest your letter . . .
that letter has been incorporated in Hansard-

At a recent meeting of our Council of State Federations of Chambers of Commerce , which is an affiliation of the South Australian, New South Wales and Victorian State organisations of chambers of commerce, we recorded our concern at the need for more effective control of the Murray Rivers' waters on a national basis.

A co-ordinated national approach to the conservation and management of Australian water resources, as you suggest, is a positive step towards assuring adequate water for community and development needs and resolving also the problems of salinity of the waters of the Murray River.
I seek leave to incorporate that letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-

DEBATE.TITLE: VICTORIAN CHAMBERS OF COMMERCE AND INDUSTRY

PROCTEXT.PARA: P.O. Box 21 Hawthorn. Phone 819 1311. Telegrams 'Vicployer' Melbourne
14th December, 1981
Senator Don Jessop, M.P.,

Adelaide, S.A., 5000.

I have read with interest your letter in the 'Financial Review' 9th December 1981, re the need for water storages.

A co-ordinated national approach to the conservation and management of Australia's water resources, as you suggest, is a positive step toward assuring adequate water for community and development needs and resolving also the problem of salinity of the waters of the Murray River.

As Executive Officer of our Council of State Federations, I shall be pleased to receive copies of any reports or material that may be available for circulation to our member State organisations in order that we may better support your efforts in this most important area in all three States.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator JESSOP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I listened with interest to what the Minister had to say at the outset of this debate. I believe that the Commonwealth Government is slowly recognising that this is a vital question, but too slowly for my satisfaction because I think it is a fundamental matter.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Chipp-It is not just the Commonwealth. The States have been a bit slow too.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator JESSOP

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that. The honourable senator reminds me of the procrastination that took place with respect to the changes in the River Murray Agreement. Agreement was reached in principle in 1970. It was not until 11 years later, after considerable argument, that all the States agreed that these amendments should be made. Thankfully the River Murray Commission now has some say in water quality matters, but it still does not have the teeth required to insist that its recommendations be given effect. The Minister said that he was going to recommend that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation establish two further institutes or whatever within that organisation to deal with water. He said that his Department will expand its activities with respect to water resource interests and informed us also that the Ministerial Council which deals with national water resources has met and is currently examining the whole question. We hope that it is and that we will see a report from it in due course. I think the Minister said he would provide information for the benefit of the Senate and the Parliament so that we could contribute even further to the debate that is of such vital significance to Australia.

INTERJECT.PARA: The most constructive thing to do at this stage is recognise the value of the Bill that is before us. It is an attempt to lay down some positive suggestions as to what ought to be done with respect to research. I think that is quite important, but other matters have to be looked at. I would like to receive more information before I am prepared to agree that what the Bill proposes is what is required. I have said before-I will continue to say it as long as I am able to be present in this place, with any moderate influence that I may have-that I strongly support the concept of a national approach to this important question. I move:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Bill be referred for inquiry and report to the Standing Committee on National Resources.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this amendment I am not forgoing my right, as the person who introduced the Institute of Freshwater Studies Bill, to reply to the second reading debate. I say from the outset that the Opposition will not entertain the amendment moved by Senator Jessop. It is just another delaying tactic. Senator Jessop submitted in his speech that the wheels of government grind exceedingly slow. He is now trying to engage in a further delaying tactic by referring this Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, of which I am a member. We have already conducted an inquiry into the Commonwealth's role in Australia's water resources. We made a recommendation to the Senate four years ago as to what the Government ought to do. The Government waited three years after receiving our recommendations before it set up a working party under the auspices of the Australian Water Resources Council. So the Government did not act upon the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources.

SPEECH.PARA: That leads me to believe that no matter what recommendation we might make if we were to look at this Bill, the Government again would not act upon it. It is quite obvious that the Government does not want to take any action. I will be referring to the reasons why the Government will not do anything when I close the second reading debate on the Bill. I do not wish to delay the Senate any further. I say from the outset that Senator Jessop has not put forward a valid argument as to why we should accept the amendment he has moved. The amendment reads:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Bill be referred for inquiry and report to the Standing Committee on National Resources.'
All that Senator Jessop has tried to do this afternoon is delay the passage of the Bill introduced in the other place by Mr Jacobi. The Opposition will not support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment. The importance and urgency of finding a solution to the water problems of South Australia requires the kind of total and national approach that has been outlined in this chamber by Senator Hill and Senator Jessop from South Australia. They have taken up the spirit of the Institute of Freshwater Studies Bill introduced in the other place by Mr Jacobi. All honourable senators from South Australia recognise the urgency and importance of finding a proper solution to this very vexing problem of water in our State. We are not so blinded by a concentration on the problem in South Australia that we do not see it as a national problem which needs to be approached in national terms as, indeed, the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick outlined. This amendment is appropriate because it will ensure that the matters that have been raised in this debate-I refer to the urgency and importance that has been declared by everyone who has spoken-will gain all the more direction if looked at by the appropriate body in this chamber; that is the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not good enough that we have only a narrow Institute of Freshwater Studies. We should approach this matter with the full advice of water resources Ministers from each State in concert, under the auspices of the Australian Water Resources Council, and with the full advice of those bodies referred to by the Minister, Senator Hill and Senator Jessop, such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and universities where research is being undertaken. It is important that we have a national co-ordinated approach. Just to pass this Bill in the Senate without implementing the correct procedures in order to gain the best solution would be shortsighted. I urge honourable senators to support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I add my voice for one minute to say that I was sitting in my room working on some papers when I heard the proposal by Senator Jessop that this matter be referred for inquiry and report to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. This proposal has been put without any consultation with that Committee whatsoever. I make it quite clear to honourable senators opposite that that course of action is not feasible. At the moment our Committee is engaged in a major review of rural research and extension services in Australia. Only yesterday we had circulated to us for consideration some five or six topics which are clamouring for our attention in the later part of this year and into 1983. Committee members are required over the next few weeks to make a choice between those five or six important matters. Quite frankly, this ruse by Senator Jessop of South Australia certainly does not commend itself to the members of the Senate Committee whom he is trying to get involved, and it ought not to commend itself to any other honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, the Australian Democrats will oppose the amendment and vote for the second reading of the Institute of Freshwater Studies Bill 1981. Senator Haines has already expressed our view. I commend Mr Jacobi and those honourable senators who have brought this initiative to the Parliament. I am sorry a slightly discordant note has entered the debate because I thought the spirit in which the debate had been carried on by honourable senators on both sides of the House had been excellent. I place on record that I will be voting against Senator Jessop's amendment, but I totally respect the reasons that motivated him to move it. I make that perfectly clear.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: in reply-I take it that I am now in order in closing the second reading debate on the Institute of Freshwater Studies Bill. Every person and every organisation in Australia concerned with our water needs and the many associated problems is indebted to Mr Ralph Jacobi, the Federal member for Hawker, for the in-depth research he has done, for the work he has put into the drafting of this Bill and for introducing it into the Parliament for consideration. Senator Carrick, when he opened for the Government , told us without any preamble that the Government would oppose the Bill. One of the reasons he gave was that the Bill was of the wrong methodology. He then went on to state that the Australian Water Resources Commission study group was unanimous in its opposition to an institute of freshwater studies.

SPEECH.PARA: I took a point of order and asked how Senator Sir John Carrick could refer to that report when it is not yet a public document. Of course he claimed that it was a private document. But that did not prevent Senator Sir John Carrick trying to bolster his argument by telling the Senate that that working party had come to a unanimous decision. I will have a few words to say about that later when I quote from a couple of State government decisions becaue I am not yet convinced that it was a unanimous decision. I have not seen the report. If it was a unanimous decision some members of that working party must be at odds with their State Ministers. I have some evidence to show that they do not support that view . Why did he say that it was a private document? Why did he refer to it? As I said, it was only to bolster his argument.

The Bill has created intense constructive discussion about and inquiry into water needs in this country. It has the support of the Murray Valley League, which is a well recognised organisation with representatives along the length of the Murray from Albury to Goolwa in South Australia. It has the support of local councils right along the Murray, particularly in South Australia, which are concerned about the water needs of their residents and ratepayers. It has the support of irrigation organisations which are also concerned that Australia's water resources be protected. It has the support of the South Australian Parliament. This now brings me to the point on which I disagree with Senator Sir John Carrick. He said that the decision of the working party of the AWRC was unanimous. I have not seen a list of the people who were on that committee, but he said there was a voice from every State. I shall read a letter which I received from the Premier of South Australia dated 18 November 1981. It is addressed to Senator G. T. McLaren, 6 Third Street, Murray Bridge, South Australia and it reads:
Dear Senator McLaren,
I inform you that on Wednesday, 11 November, the South Australian House of Assembly passed the following resolution.

That this House strongly supports the establishment of an Australian Institute of Freshwater Studies and calls upon all South Australian Federal Parliamentary Members to support the Private Member's Bill introduced into Federal parliament by the Member for Hawker, Mr Jacobi.
The Motion was introduced to the House by Mr G. F. Keneally (A.L.P., Stuart).
Yours sincerely, David Tonkin, Premier.
Mr Keneally is the Opposition spokesman on water resources in South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the House pass it unanimously?

—The House passed it unanimously. Senator Hill made reference to the South Australian Hansard and quoted some words used by Mr Arnold, but he did not say that Mr Arnold opposed the resolution. In fact he said he supported the principle of the Bill.
—I said that.
—Yes, Senator Hill said that, but then he said that he is opposed to the Bill. Senator Hill is going against the decision of the lower House of South Australia which carried a unanimous decision--
—I attempted to give reasons.

—Yes. Senator Hill is going against that decision and of course he will have to answer to Mr Tonkin for that. That is his problem. That knocks Senator Carrick's argument into a cocked hat.
