He stated, and it is on the record , that the representatives of the States on the AWRC working party are unanimous in their decision. They are not in unanimous agreement with the Minister of Water Resources in South Australia because he supports Mr Jacobi's Bill. Again, I am reminded that Mr Bannon, the Opposition Leader in South Australia received support from Mr Wran, the Premier of New South Wales, for the setting up of an institute of freshwater studies. Of course, the two States that have been most involved in this water war in recent times are South Australia and New South Wales. Many hot words have been said. On one occasion New South Wales was accused by Mr Arnold of stealing South Australia's water. I do not want to go into that matter because I have mentioned it on many occasions. That claim was not correct. We now have two Ministers of two governments, one a Liberal government and one a Labor government, agreeing with the contents and the purport of Mr Jacobi's Bill to set up this institute of freshwater studies. I do not know what Victoria's decision is because nothing has been published. I am sure that after the election takes place we will have Victoria's support as well . The Save the Murray Campaign was set up primarily by former Senator Davidson. He was the inaugural chairman of the Save the Murray Campaign committee. He got that organisation off the ground. That is another organisation that supports Ralph Jacobi's Bill. The executive officer of the Save the Murray Campaign Committee, Mr Daryl Hicks, has reaffirmed by public statements and correspondence the Committee's full support for the Bill. I received a letter from him just recently. No doubt honourable senators who sit opposite also have both of those pieces of correspondence stating that that organisation supports Mr Jacobi's Bill.
—But they have not looked at alternatives.

—It is said that they have not looked at alternatives. I will quote from a submission to the AWRC working group by the executive director of the Murray Valley League, Mr Proud. I have a copy here. I attended a regional meeting just the other day. I am a member of the Murray Valley League and I get copies of its minutes. I attend the meetings whenever possible. Part of the submission by Mr Proud on behalf of the Murray Valley League states:

SPEECH.PARA: The league sees the attractive aspect in Mr Jacobi's proposals that they tiptoe daintily and apparently safely through the constitutional minefield. Bearing in mind the history of interstate squabbling over the Murray River, the league believes that recalcitrant States would be reluctant to be seen to oppose propositions from a prestigious research institute.
That is what this institute will be. The submission further states:

The league also believes that the proposed resource developments will also need water in considerable quantities and that a research institute to provide overall management guidelines would be economically justified on this ground alone.

I have no doubt that the Murray Valley League sought legal advice on the contents of Mr Jacobi's Bill; otherwise it would not have said that the Bill tiptoes daintily and apparently safely through the constitutional minefield. That was one of the arguments used today by Senator Carrick; we could not get around the Constitution to set up this institute of freshwater studies. Mr Jacobi had very good legal advice in drawing up the Bill. He is congratulated by the Murray Valley League. The institute would be able to tiptoe gently through the minefields we are facing.

While I am talking about the Murray Valley League I will mention some of the councils that support the proposition. I have been at many meetings of the Murray Valley League when this Bill has been debated. I have the minutes of a meeting held at Strathalbyn on 30 October last. There was correspondence from the District Councils of Strathalbyn, Ridley, Murray Bridge and Mannum supporting Mr Jacobi's Bill. I had the pleasure last year of attending a meeting of the League at Mannum where Mr Jacobi had been invited along as a guest speaker to explain his Bill. I understand that he has been to many areas in the Riverland speaking to public bodies. They have all given him full support after he has explained the Bill and answered many questions to their satisfaction. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in his electorate talk of 22 November 1981, stated that water should receive a top priority. He further stated:
. . . an investigation and study will be undertaken by the Department of National Development and Energy, in collaboration with relevant water authorities and other organisations.

By way of interjection I asked Senator Carrick when this working party had been set up. He told me that it was some 12 months ago. Yet the Prime Minister, in his statement, said that an investigation and study would be undertaken by the Department. He made that statement on 22 November. Whilst I do not dispute the fact that the working group may have been set up 12 months ago, apparently, if we can believe what the Prime Minister said, it did not commence work until after the introduction of Mr Jacobi's Bill in the other place on 4 June last year and the introduction of that Bill into the Senate on 9 June. This announcement comes six months after Mr Jacobi introduced an identical Bill to the one now before us. The Prime Minister, in his electoral talk on Sunday 22 November, went on to state:

The Government believes we need an updated assessment of all Australian water resources, including underground as well as surface water, in terms of both quality and quantity. We need estimates of current water usage, we need to know the trends in expenditure on water resource development, and we need to examine the implications of future demands.

That is the very thing which Mr Jacobi's Bill will do when this Institute of Freshwater Studies is set up. It will do all the things which the Prime Minister said need to be done. It will do all the things which the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources in its report in 1978 said ought to be done. There we have it. I can vouch for the authority of the Senate Standing Committee of which I am a member and Deputy Chairman but I will not vouch for anybody else . That is the point. Mr Jacobi's Bill does all the things which the Prime Minister, the Committee of which I am a member, local councils and other people who have looked at the Bill have said that it will do.

Mr Jacobi is of the opinion that the Government can treat the Bill in any one of four different ways. Of course, when he made those remarks he was not aware that it could be treated in any one of five different ways. We had the fifth different way outlined to the Senate a while ago when the Government tried to shove the Bill off--

TALK.START.PARA: —Pigeon-holed.

—And pigeon-hole it, but we have dealt with that. The first way the Government could deal with the Bill would be to do nothing with it after it passed the Senate. The Bill would go over to the other place. It would appear twice on the Notice Paper because Mr Jacobi already has the Bill on the Notice Paper. The second reading debate has occurred. The Bill will go from this place to the other House by message when we pass the Bill very shortly. So, it would be twice on the Notice Paper. The second way is for the Government to shuffle the pack and rearrange either the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Bureau of Mineral Resources or the Department of National Development and Energy to set up the Institute. This would mean, in effect, very little additional costs and little or no increase in staff. The third way would be to create a separate division of the CSIRO to implement the purpose of the Bill. Some reference has been made today to the CSIRO and what it would do. Of course, the CSIRO would not have the full backing of the Parliament in what it would be doing. Again, the aims of the Bill would be thrown off into a side stream. There would be a shelving of something which ought to be dealt with by a specific body such as this Bill envisages.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth way the Bill could be treated is: Due to the urgency of coming to grips with our water problem-all honourable senators who have spoken in this debate today are agreed on that point-an interim council as provided in the Bill could be set up. The council would make a thorough investigation into water priority throughout Australia and then recommend what would be the best type of structure to meet Australia's pressing water needs, both in the short term and in the long term. We have every confidence that any impartial council that inquires into Australia's water needs would ultimately have to consider some central collection centre being established where all the information data and statistics collected could be assessed, collated and distributed to all interested parties. We recognise and acknowledge also the critical need for regional research and input. We particularly emphasise also the need for full co -operation and assistance from the States to ensure that water is looked at as a national priority and research is co-ordinated. These are the things that we are saying. They are what Mr Jacobi said in his second reading speech and what I am saying today here in the Senate with his concurrence. These are the things which have to be done. Mr Jacobi's Bill does all of these things.

Senator Carrick in his speech of opposition to this Institute said that the Opposition should not be hasty in making up its mind what we ought to be doing with our water resources. Of course, he tried to draw a smoke-screen across the whole issue. The Senate is not making up its mind. The expertise to make up our minds on how our water resources ought to be developed and used is not in this chamber. What we are saying by way of this Bill is that we should be setting up an Institute of Freshwater Studies to examine and report on the whole gamut of the problem. The Senate can make up its mind after having looked at what the Institute of Freshwater Studies recommends. I do not think Senator Carrick was very serious in what he was trying to do. He could not possibly seriously suggest that the working party which we have had no public report from yet and which has been in operation, he says, for 12 months-according to the Minister it may have been set up 12 months ago; I do not know how long it has been carrying out its work-has all the answers in the short space of 12 months, if in fact it has been working that long. That is what he said. I cannot really believe that he was serious when he said that. He went on to say that so much is happening and so much needs to happen. Of course so much is happening. A lot of what is happening involves disputes between the States and all types of various experts on our water problem. Mr Jacobi's Bill will overcome that. As I said previously, the Senate is not evaluating the problem that we have. We will be guided by the Institute. Its task is to do the evaluation.

Senator Hill quoted Mr Jacobi's second reading speech where he said that it was politicians who were to blame for the problem we have today. What stronger argument is there for the establishment of this Institute? Of course, that statement by Mr Jacobi is fully supported by Senator Hill-it is the politicians who have not been able to come to grips with the problem and who have caused all of the dissention. What stronger argument can we have for the establishment of this Institute than the passing of this Bill today? As I said previously when I was speaking on the amendment which sought to refer this Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, it is nearly four years since that Committee reported to the Senate. Apart from recommending the setting up of this working party it took the Government three years to take action. If the Bill went to the Committee again-it will not because the vote against that has been taken-we might find ourselves faced with another stalemate for goodness knows how many years.

I do not need to take the time of the Senate any longer because we have other pressing business. I again commend Mr Jacobi for the work that he has done on his Bill. I know that many long days and nights and months of work have been put in by Mr Jacobi in drawing up this Bill. I am very pleased that the Australian Democrats are giving the Bill their full support. I hope that the Bill will pass the Senate. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, pursuant to Standing Order 358, there be laid upon the Table a document containing specific details of the Government's proposed amendments to industrial legislation referred to in the Ministerial statement given to the Senate on 16 February 1982, such details having been supplied by the Minister for Industrial Relations to interest groups but not to the Parliament.

The purpose of the motion is to ensure that an intelligent public debate takes place on the very vital matter of amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and perhaps to other pieces of legislation and statute. Thus far we have received from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) a statement which is really fit only for presentation to the East Kew women's branch of the Liberal Party. The Minister's statement of 16 February did not do justice to the very important subject with which it purported to deal. It did not give adequate detail upon which an intelligent debate could take place and so raised the question as to whether the Government was not just using industrial relations as a political football for the Lowe by-election and for the Victorian State election. A number of comments in the statement immediately raise a number of very important questions. I do not propose to go into those today because I understand from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), who represents the Minister for Industrial Relations, that the Government is now prepared to provide a document which includes some of those things which we are now seeking. I suspect, however, that the document which will be provided to us will be as significant in what it does not say as it will be in what it does say . I give some examples of the type of information that I at least, with 20 years or more of experience in the field of industrial relations, would like to see emanate from the Government. The Minister, on page 18 of the circulated statement stated:

During this session I intend to introduce a number of legislative initiatives which I discussed with the National Labour Consultative Council on 4 February and which will be the subject of further discussion at a special meeting of that Council to be held in March.
Incidentally, I understand that that meeting will be held on the Monday after the Lowe by-election. The Minister went on to say:
The Government has been accused of seeking confrontation with the union movement because of these legislative proposals.
He then said:

Far from being confrontationist, the three legislative proposals are a responsible and reasonable response, both immediate and longer term, to meet a level of industrial disruption which all Australians recognise as totally unsatisfactory.

There are two things to be said about that matter relevant to the motion that is now before the Senate. First of all, after the words 'far from being confrontationist' one would have expected the Minister to say 'negotiations are now proceeding with the interested parties through the NLCC to ensure that there is some unanimity of view on these matters'. After all, on page 22 of the circulated document the Minister stated:
I expect that legislative action will be taken on the basis of that report--
That is, the Searby report-
later this year to bring about a substantial restructuring and simplification of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.
He said:
The Government, with the ACTU and the Confederation of Australian Industry, is currently examining the report . . .

Naturally, this is the way in which things occur with the National Labour Consultative Council. I understand that previously the Government has taken matters to it for consultation, the recommendations have gone to the Minister, the Minister has taken them to Cabinet and has perhaps made a statement in this Parliament, there has been a broad debate on the subject and, after that debate, there has been or should have been the introduction of legislation having regard to views other than those stated by the NLCC. But on this occasion the Minister has stated to the NLCC that he will introduce legislation in this session. In effect, therefore, there has been no consultation. At the same time, to reinforce that entrenched confrontationist viewpoint the Minister has come into this Parliament and made a statement of intent to the Parliament indicating that in this session these proposals, which are not agreed upon en bloc by either the unions or employers, will be implemented by the Government. That is not a consultative procedure.

Surely the Government cannot therefore say that it withholds information from the Parliament because that information happens to be in the possession of interest groups who are allegedly in consultation with the Government, They are not-unless I am wrong. I hope that I am wrong. I hope that the Minister for Social Security will be able to tell me that I am wrong, that consultations are actually taking place and that there is a possibility that the Government will retreat from its intention as stated in the document circulated by the Minister on 16 February. I will be the first one to apologise to the Minister for Social Security, who is at the table, and indeed to the Minister for Industrial Relations, if I have misunderstood him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be the second.

—Good. I thank Senator Button. I imagine that that will open the way for the Minister to state that genuine negotiations are going on and that in those circumstances particular documents that are essential for confidential negotiations at that level need not necessarily be tabled. Let me say that at no time have I asked for those sorts of documents to be tabled in the Parliament. I wish to make that perfectly clear. In the first place, it is clear that the consultation processes of the NLCC ought to be of a confidential character. that is the essence of genuine negotiations into which the parties go with reasonable, open minds. As I understand the situation, on this occasion the Government has gone in with a closed mind. I hope that the result of this debate will be to afford the Government an opportunity again to open its mind to suggestions from the NLCC, from a broad range of unions and employer organisations and, indeed, from the Parliament when the debate continues after we have received some further elaboration.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to the second point that I want to make about page 18 of the circulated statement. The Minister said:
. . . the three legislative proposals are . . . to meet a level of industrial disruption which all Australians recognise as totally unsatisfactory.

He went on to list very briefly what those three legislative proposals will be- the stand-down proposal, the withdrawal of preference proposal and the union structure proposal. I certainly would like to see a detailed document elaborating on the Minister's information and setting out just how many disputes have occurred as a result of the preference clauses that are currently in awards granted by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

I wonder whether the documentation that, I understand, we are to be presented with will include support for the allegation or the suggestion by the Minister that this legislative proposal will affect favourably the level of industrial disputation. Of course, I would like to see a document including some elaboration of the powers of the various State tribunals in regard to preference . What protection, what right of appeal, has the Government in mind to prevent stand-downs of an unreasonable character? What protection will there be for workers who would otherwise be gainfully employed? That protection is there at the moment; the employer must take the matter to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The statement proposes a complete change of onus of proof and we ought to have further information in regard to that aspect. Furthermore, so far as union structure is concerned, we would like to know precisely what the Government means by enterprise unions. There is a list of about 15 different things which I would like to put to the Minister. I will not read them out at this stage, because, as I understand it, the Minister has some sort of document and I do not want to pre-empt what might or might not be in that document.

Finally, let me say this: Whilst the consultative procedures of the NLCC ought to be confidential in character, there is no legislative sanction which places confidentiality on documents provided to the NLCC, as there is in some other legislation. Nevertheless, I have not asked for those documents. All I am asking for by this motion is a document containing specific details of the Government's proposed amendments to industrial legislation which were referred to in the Minister's statement read to the Senate on 16 February and such details as were supplied by the Minister for Industrial Relations to interested groups but not to the Parliament. It was stated in the Press that those documents were in fact supplied to the Australian Council of Trade Unions and to the chambers of commerce. I believe that the Government has made a rod for its own back, on the one hand, by suggesting that these matters are privy to the NLCC and, on the other hand, by providing this Parliament with a document which is totally inadequate for genuine and intelligent debate on this very important matter. I say again to the Minister for Social Security that if he now says that the Minister for Industrial Relations is in genuine negotiation with the NLCC on these matters, I will be the first to apologise. But also I insist that we, as parliamentarians, deserve better treatment than we have been given. We deserve specific details so that the debate on the Minister's original statement and the further document can ensue when next we are in session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion which has been moved by Senator Harradine. I do not think there is much that I really want to add to what he had to say, particularly in view of the undertaking that has been given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). I support Senator Harradine's motion mainly because the statement which was tabled by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) reminded me very much of that expression: 'Where there is smoke, there is fire'. There is an awful lot of smoke in that statement, but I could not distinguish where the fire was; and that is what the Parliament is entitled to know. For example, I hope that any further statement which is brought down will at least explain to members of this Parliament how the proposed organisation of unions into, first of all, enterprise unions-whatever that may mean-and/or industry unions relates to the very vague statement on proposed wages policy. There is, in my view, a very profound conflict in the statement in relation to those matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, as Senator Harradine pointed out, I would like to know what is meant by the expression 'enterprise union'. There are a number of other matters in that document which are very important and which ought to be explained to the Parliament so that thoughtful debate can take place. I share Senator Harradine's view about the National Labour Consultative Council's deliberations and the respect which should be accorded them. I hope that he and I are both wrong in suspecting that the bringing down of the statement at the time it was brought down was something in the nature of a political stunt, which has not been unknown in the industrial relations area in the life of this Government. If we can be reassured on that matter I am sure that we can have a much more intelligent debate about the issues. I commend Senator Harradine for his initiative in this matter and hope that the response meets what is intended by that initiative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may shorten the debate-on the other hand, it may not-if I speak at this stage and indicate the Government's attitude to this motion. The Opposition Whip is looking concerned. It is not my motion and my speaking at this stage has no effect on the order of speakers in the debate or anything else. I must say that I was relieved when the text of the motion was actually produced in the Senate after the original statement made by Senator Harradine on 17 February. I can indicate to the Senate that the Government does not oppose the motion that he has moved, but I would like to explain why there was some concern about the original statement of intention which preceded the notice of motion. On 17 February Senator Harradine said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I intend to move the adjournment of the debate and tomorrow I will seek a suspension of Standing Orders to demand from the Minister the documentation which has been provided to the National Labour Consultative Council on this matter but which he has not had the courtesy of providing to the Parliament.

The wording of the motion and Senator Harradine's comments here today make it quite clear that he has had second and better thoughts, which I welcome, on the procedures that might be followed, because the motion seeks not the specific documentation but a document containing specific details of the Government's proposed amendments to industrial legislation. The concern which the Government had, and which, I must say, is shared by both employers and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, relates to documentation provided to the National Labour Consultative Council in the course of the consultations which are provided for under that Act. Section 5 (1) of that Act states:

The purpose of the Council is to provide, in the public interest, a regular and organised means by which representatives of the Government of the Commonwealth of employers and of employees may consult together on industrial relations matters, and manpower matters, of national concern.

I stress that the body, as it is statutorily established, is a body which is to permit consultation between those three key groups in this area-the Commonwealth Government, the employers and the trade union movement representing employees. What I can say to the Senate in response to the points which have been raised by Senator Harradine is that what is occurring with the National Labour Consultative Council at the moment is the process of consultation which is required by the National Labour Consultative Council Act. On a number of occasions Senator Harradine asked whether the Government was in negotiation with the National Labour Consultative Council. I think the proper answer is no. The Government is in consultation with the other members of that Council. Section 5 (2) (c) of the Act states:

subject to the rights of members to report to the organizations by which they are nominated and to the right of the Council to make announcements that the members agree are in the public interest, the views of members expressed at meetings of the Council will be kept confidential.

Senator Harradine distinguished between views expressed at Council meetings and documents which might be provided. I respectfully suggest to the Senate that it is certainly within the spirit-I would argue that it is within the letter-of that provision that documents provided in the course of consultation would be regarded as part of the consultation and should be given the same confidential status as the expression of views at meetings. In that regard I am advised by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), who has had discussions with both the trade union movement, through the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and the employer representatives on the National Labour Consultative Council, that those two groups are concerned to preserve the confidentiality of National Labour Consultative Council matters and documents although, in this case, both the employers and the employees' representatives are agreeable to the parts of the paper which was provided to the National Labour Consultative Council by the Government, relating to the three areas of amendment referred to in Mr Viner's statement, which I put down in this place, being released to the Senate. I propose, therefore, on the carriage of this motion-it certainly will be carried in the light of the support it has received around the chamber-to table a paper which picks up those parts of the written communications from the Commonwealth to the National Labour Consultative Council which relate to the Government's proposals to legislate as to voluntary unionism, the removal of preference to unionists, the standing down of employees and industry and enterprise unions.

I do not wish to prolong the debate on this matter unnecessarily but, to my mind, a somewhat curious concern has been expressed by both Senator Harradine and Senator Button, on behalf of the Opposition, about the fact that the Parliament was asked to debate the broad statements of intention contained in the statement put down by Mr Viner and by me in this chamber before the full detail was made available to permit a debate on that detail. I think that there are many instances in this chamber of there being useful debate on questions of broad principle prior to the Senate engaging its attention on the detailed implementation of that principle. In the present case, rather than the Government producing legislation without warning, it has given an indication of its intentions and, at roughly the same time, it has engaged in the process of consultation which is envisaged by the National Labour Consultative Council Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it consultation?
—Of course it is consultation.
—With the possibility of another result?

—Of course the Minister will consider the precise form of the legislation in light of the consultations which will occur in March, as has been indicated by previous speakers. None of this can take from the fact that the key thing is that the Government will, of course, have to bring its legislation into the Parliament, firstly into the House of Representatives and ultimately into this chamber where honourable senators will have ample opportunity to debate in their usual way the detail of the legislation with the very great freedom which we enjoy in this place for that sort of debate on detail, whether at the second reading stage or in the Committee of the Whole. I simply proffer the view to the Senate in response to the complaints which have been made by Senator Harradine and Senator Button that a forecast of intention of this sort is no bad thing. It permits a degree of public debate and a degree of debate in this chamber on the principles which are involved before one gets down to the equally difficult task , having formulated the principles one wishes to apply, of saying how those principles shall actually be put into execution.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had a similar experience recently. I made a statement of intention at the time of the last Budget. I have to confess that putting the intention into legislative form has proved more difficult than I thought at the time the statement was made. I think I am being assisted in the shaping of that legislation by the views which have been put to me over the months since the Budget, sometimes with considerable force. In my case-I give this as a parallel example-as recently as last Wednesday I met with the Australian Pensioners' Federation which put some views which further illuminated for me the approaches which might be taken in this area. I suggest to honourable senators that debate on fairly broad statements can be quite productive and can lead to assisting the Government in the shaping of its legislation. I am not saying that in the future we will not follow a similar course-an announcement of intention which will permit debate both here and elsewhere which will promote better legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you being so helpful?

—I do not wish to stop Senator Evans from helping me in this speech, particularly as he is interjecting in a far more elegant way than he did on my colleague, Senator Teague, the other evening, which interjections, fortunately, did not find their way into Hansard. If Senator Evans wishes to break in, he should feel free to do so.

—While you are being so helpful would you mind telling us what is the constitutional foundation that is proposed for the automatic stand downs? How in hell are you going to base it on 51 (xx) and 51 (i) as well as 51 (xxxv)?

—Having given Senator Evans the chance, in breach of the Standing Orders, to interject and question me in that way, I can say that that is the sort of very detailed question that I look forward to hearing discussed in later debate. I think there have been statements that there is a series of constitutional heads of power on which this legislation will be based. The point which has been raised by Senator Evans simply underlines that this is an area of some legal and constitutional complexity. From that point of view I would have thought that debate on the subject would be more likely to be useful than not.

SPEECH.PARA: I said that I would not prolong the debate. Senator Harradine has moderated his demand of the evening of 17 February to a request which is consistent with the protection of the confidentiality of the National Labour Consultative Council. For that reason, the Government will be able to support the motion and comply with it quickly. I merely wish to respond to one other point which Senator Harradine raised. He wanted to know whether we would provide details of how many industrial disputes had arisen out of preference clauses. That was merely one of the points he raised about which he was curious. I simply say that some aspects of the legislation may well relate, not merely to what industrial disputes have occurred or might be prevented in the future but also to the freedom of individual Australians to obtain employment without being the victims of some trade union action which is against their personal beliefs or wishes. Some questions may relate to the freedom of individuals to go about their business without interference, quite apart from the cessation or reduction of industrial disputes.

I put down one final caution with respect to the statement that I table. As I understand, it contains the points made to the National Labour Consultative Council with respect to the three areas of amendment which are proposed. It is, of course, not a final statement of all the specific details. If we were able to provide such a final statement of specific details we would be able to produce a draft Bill. Just as importantly, to be able to produce a final statement of specific details would simply establish the point that Senator Harradine has been making, namely that no genuine process of consultation was proceeding. So I cannot say that this document is a final statement. It is a statement which picks up the points which have been made for the purposes of the consultation which has occurred. The final form may differ flowing from that consultation and from the Government consideration which is given to the measures following that consultation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Australian Democrats very briefly to support Senator Harradine's motion. I am delighted to hear that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) is proposing to table documents setting out the details of the Government's proposals in the industrial relations area. In my speech on Mr Viner's original ministerial statement I protested that I had not received a copy of the statement until Tuesday, 17 February, although it apparently had been widely circulated the previous week. But it has also come to my notice that supplementary material was available that was circulated to newspapers, members of the National Labour Consultative Council and various other interested bodies. This supplementary material does, apparently, outline in some detail the Government's intention. I think that if that material was available at least the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine, who obviously has a very deep interest in industrial relations, should have been given a copy of it. There were very detailed reports of the Government's intention in various newspapers following the Government's announcement. We were not informed of those details. Therefore, we were not able to make informed statements on our party's attitude to the proposals of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney suggested that it is beneficial to discuss these matters in broad detail. I am afraid I cannot agree with him. How are we intelligently to debate basic new concepts which the Government now proposes? How can we debate intelligently the question of union amalgamation when we are confronted with a concept of enterprise unions without any definition of what the Government means by an enterprise union? It is necessary for us to have these details. Senator Evans has indicated the very doubtful constitutional basis on which compulsory stand-down legislation could be drafted. It seems to me that this has to be addressed before we raise such a bogy before the whole industrial relations scene in this country. Obviously the Government knew that its proposals would be highly contentious and that they would worry the trade union movement, as they worry the Australian Democrats. We hope that there will be a better climate for industrial relations in this country-one of co-operation. The Government's approach does not engender that atmosphere.

I do not wish to say any more about the matter except to comment that I was amused to find out the other day that apparently this chamber has the power, ultimately, to order the Black Rod to take a senator who wilfully disobeys the Senate into custody under Standing Order 444. So, one lives and learns. We are looking forward to reading the papers which set out the details. Hopefully they will allow us to be much better informed in our opinions on and attitudes to the Government's proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with Senator Harradine in being rather concerned about the lack of detail in the statement of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner). I am pleased to hear from the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, that the Government will bring down a detailed statement. I doubt that it will be as detailed as Senator Harradine or Senator Siddons imagined because, in the first place, I felt the statement was a piece of kite flying from the very beginning. Senator Chaney said that it is good to discuss the broad principle. It is the broad principle embodied in this statement that worried me, because I could not see any. I can assure Senator Siddons that he did not miss much by getting the statement late.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a 23-page statement on wages and industrial relations. I sincerely hope that the detailed statement of the Minister has something about industrial relations in it and does not confine itself solely to wages. The 23-page document contains the words 'wage' or 'wages' some 60 times. There are no less than 29 attacks on wage earners and the unions who sought those wage increases. No reference is made to the huge profits that have been made in the past, and which are still being made, by large companies and banks. The statement expresses the Government's concern over working days lost through industrial disputes. But it is obvious that it has not looked into the total figure of lost production in many fields other than wages. The so-called 'broad principle' referred to by Senator Chaney shows the Government's attitude towards unions.

One gets the impression from reading the statement that all industrial disputes are confined to wages and that that is the one and only factor that has any bearing on industrial relations. So the broad principle is confined to that one factor. Therefore, one can assume from the statement only that the intention of the Government as a broad principle is to screw down on wage earners as hard as it is humanely possible. It reveals also that the obsession that this Government is accused of havng with union bashing is, indeed, a fact. Despite the disgust that employers show from time to time towards the Government because of its interference in what should be the employer-employee negotiations, it keeps on and on insisting that all the ills of the nation over which it presides can be heaped on the back of the union movement.

I assure the Senate that there is a lot more in the field of industrial relations which requires attention than was contained in the ill-informed view that was expressed in the broad statement of principle. It is time that the Government had a good look at some of the causes behind the strained industrial relations. I hope that the detailed statement to be presented by the Minister looks into industrial relations and thoroughly considers the causes before considering the cures. Fore example, I have never heard any Government member point out that time lost in industrial disputes can be broken up into a number of areas and that the area concerning wages accounts for only 27 per cent of industrial disputes.

Leaving aside industrial disputes, let us consider another far more important aspect of industrial relations and the loss of production in that area. As I have pointed out to the Senate before, time lost because of industrial accidents is about two to three times more than the time lost because of industrial disputes. Here is a whole huge field in which the Government should be doing something more constructive if it is genuinely concerned about the loss of production and the welfare of the people that put it into office. In discussing the broad principles of industrial relations I would like to see something in the detailed statement dealing more with the whole of the field of industrial relations. Has the Government any idea of the pain and disruptions caused by industrial accidents or illness? Has it any insight into the financial and social loss associated with time off work because of injury? Does it have any idea of the inadequacies of data collection relating to the extent and nature of industrial accidents in Australia? Using existing data, it is not possible to know how many people are injured at work each year or how badly they are hurt. It is impossible to isolate the causes of accidents and to compare them across industries and occupations to monitor changing patterns of risks for workers. Research into prevention is hampered by the lack of information. The community is left ignorant of the costs in human and economic terms. Surely this is part of industrial relations.

The Federal Government must accept responsibility in this field. A national occupational health safety office should be established and the national responsibilities involved in this area vested in certain authorities. I hope that the detailed report on industrial relations concerns a means of co- ordination between State and federal authorities in the field of health, safety and welfare. I hope that the Government legislates for union elected health and safety representatives and health and safety committees both at the shop floor and the industrial level. I hope that the detailed report on industrial relations-a most important field-will lead to legislation to provide effective penalties, enforcement of powers, national research facilities and the right of union representatives and officers to carry out work place inspections and to have access to information held by employees and government agencies. I hope all those things come into the detailed statement that the Minister intends to table . I hope there is training at public expense of sufficient nursing, medical and ancillaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, the motion requests information about the three areas of amendment.

—The title of the ministerial statement is 'wage determination and industrial relations'. Surely these matters are all part of industrial relations. The Minister said that we should be debating the broad principle, and surely the matters I am talking about come within the ambit of that broad principle. The Minister has completely avoided that principle. There is also another area in which the Government could play a useful and constructive role instead of the destructive role which it has embarked on. It should examine the causes of tradesmen not working at their trades. I am sure the Government would rather talk about the predicted shortfalls in skills and in the training of more people than help those people who are already trained and experienced. This matter comes under industrial relations. I feel it has been sadly neglected. I do not see anything about this in the broad principle of statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Does the Government realise that an extra 6,000 tradesmen would be available each year if the drop-out rate of apprentices was reduced from one-third to one- fifth of its present rate? The report on the fitting and machining trade course of the New South Wales Department of Technical and Further Education included a section on wastage rates. TAFE sent out a questionnaire to 250 ex-fitting and machining apprentices in an attempt to ascertain the career paths of these tradesmen. Eighty-two of the questionnaires were returned. But out of these 82 people, 45 per cent were no longer employed in the trade for which they were trained. Some 97 per cent of those were under 30 years of age. That was a very small sample. On its own, the result would need to be treated with some caution, I agree.

However, the result is supported by a further survey conducted by TAFE this time covering stage III fitting and machining apprentices in New South Wales. At that time, 1977, approximately 1,400 of these stage III students were in New South Wales technical colleges. As the survey was conducted in the classroom it was possible to obtain a complete coverage. When asked about their future career plans 45 per cent claimed that they intended to leave the trade within the next few years thereby accurately reflecting the actual behaviour of the ex-students sampled. The most frequent reason given by ex-students for leaving the trade was lack of financial return. Lack of opportunities for promotion and loss of interest in their trade were amongst some other reasons. Of course, the main point was the lack of financial return. We are dealing with wages here but the Government's intention in the so-called broad principle of the Minister seems to be to further reduce wages.

The 1976 census showed that 300,000 males with tradesmen's certificates were working in non-tradesmen's jobs. Some 20,000 were working as bus, car or truck drivers. The last thing this Government is interested in is the cause of strained industrial relations. It is the very last thing the Government seems to be interested in if we take this document as a broad statement of principle. As I said it concentrated all the way through on wages. The ministerial statement mentioned wages 60 times. I will not go over that again. But the Governments seems to be concentrating on that aspect more than anything else. If the Government were really genuinely concerned about industrial relations and training of tradesmen it should look at why the country is losing so many tradesmen. The Government mentioned wages no less than 60 times. It made no less than 29 attacks on wage earners and the unions which sought increases. Is this the broad principle the Government is talking about that we should be debating? That seems to be the whole gist of the Minister's statement.

It is obvious that returns for one's labour, working conditions and unfulfilled expectations all go together when talking about industrial relations. People are not fools. They want to see the wealth of this wealthy nation shared by all. They want to be able to enjoy the environment in which they work as well as live . They are aware of the unequal distribution of our resources. They are aware of the Government's inability to tackle the problems in society where 10 per cent of people own almost 60 per cent of the total wealth of this country. The richest 2,000 members of our society have as much as the poorest 2.5 million adult Australians. In this country 2.5 million humans exist on the poverty line. Nearly 60 per cent of all wage and salary earners receive less than the average weekly earnings before tax. Government senators have the temerity to hide behind an excuse for their failure to grapple with those problems. They blame it all on the unions. The broad principle statement that we had to debate was, to repeat what I said at the beginning, nothing but a bit of kite-flying. I sincerely hope that when the document of details comes down it includes matters concerning the whole spectrum of industrial relations and does not confine itself to wages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing the debate I will simply state that I am encouraged by some of the statements made by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) who represents the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner). Senator Chaney's comments will be read with a good deal of interest. I will reserve any further comment until such time as I see what is in the documentation to be made available and how much notice the Government takes of the consultative procedures now taking place, according to the Minister, with representatives of the trade union movement and employers.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the resolution I table a paper providing that information presented to members of the National Labour Consultative Council on 12 February 1982 in the light of the discussions of 4 February 1982 about the Government's proposal to legislate as to voluntary unionism, removal of preference to unionists, standing down of employees and industry and enterprise unions. I indicate the scope of the document merely because of the very much broader scope of what was requested by Senator McIntosh.

SPEECH.PARA: SALES TAX AMENDMENT BILLS (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981 [No. 2] (1982)
Second Readings
Debate resumed from 24 February, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief because I have spoken on this matter a number of times now in the Senate. I believe the time has now arrived when the Senate ought to proceed to a vote on these sales tax measures.
—Hear, hear!

—Very good. I hope that vote takes place today. In conclusion I say that this strikes me as an exercise by the Government to persuade the Senate to buy a pig in a poke. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his Budget Speech made mention of the fact, as he saw it, that it is clear that there is an advantage in making some change in the mix of direct and indirect taxes to increase the potential for desirable reductions in direct taxes, particularly personal income tax, as economic and budgetary conditions permit. As far back as 26 August I challenged the Treasurer to spell out the Government's hinted proposals for future income tax relief. I said then that the Government must come clean on its personal tax proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate cannot be asked to buy a pig in a poke. What I did then and what the Senate has done by returning these Bills to the House of Representatives has been to give the Treasurer the opportunity to clarify his vague proposals contained in the Budget papers to ease direct or personal taxes. He has not done that. He has not addressed public attention to how, when and where these taxes would be applied. It is just not on to ask the Senate to adopt these sales tax measures with some vague promise of some vague proposals for reductions in direct taxes. As has been said in the debate, the $53m that the Government will get from these measures this financial year will be simply a drop in the bucket in easing direct taxation.

The other aspect of the pig in a poke proposal that is before us is the fact that the Government has brought back, in its own words, 'for constitutional reasons' the Bills as I understand them in precisely the same form as they came before us last year. Of course what that means is that the Government wishes to have the double dissolution gun loaded. I think that the Government would be very unwise to go to the people over the Senate's rejection of these proposals. In my view the Government is not acting genuinely when it brings down legislation such as this, which has a particular date of operation, and then suggests that if it is passed it will bring in another Bill which will have another operative date. That seems an extraordinary way for a responsible Government to act. The newly established Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, in its second report, that of 24 February 1982, states that these Bills have provisions which are retrospective in operation to 1 January 1982.
The report continues:

Because they impose a financial obligation on individuals, under principle 1 (a ) (i) of the Committee's terms of reference they might be regarded as trespassing unduly on personal rights and liberties. However, the Treasurer's second reading speech indicates that the date 1 January 1982 has been included to comply with the requirements of section 57 of the Constitution-1 January being the prospective date of commencement specified in the Bills previously introduced into the Parliament but not passed by the Senate. The Treasurer has indicated in his speech that a further Bill will be introduced to change this date to 29 March 1982 'as soon as these Bills have been passed by both Houses', thus eliminating the retrospective date.

I suggest to members of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills that if they genuinely subscribe to the principle that they refer to in that statement they should, as a matter of principle, vote against a piece of tax legislation of this character which has a retrospective date. If the Senate passed this legislation and rejected the foreshadowed legislation which amended the retrospective date it would be impossible to implement the retrospective aspect of the present legislation. I suggest that the Senate proceed quickly to a vote on these Bills. Consistent with my previous opposition, I will be voting against the Bills and I hope that the Senate rejects them in toto.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be no secret by now that the Opposition, too, consistent with its initial position, opposes the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981 [No. 2] (1982) on their merits. We do so for both general and quite specific reasons. The general reasons are, of course, that we regard any indirect taxes as almost inevitably being more regressive in their operation than properly formulated progressive direct taxes. As a result we always have a preference for revenue raising by direct taxes. More specifically we oppose the particular items in these Bills for reasons which have been enumerated and set out by speaker after speaker. We oppose the new tax on books and newspapers because of the unprecedented character of this tax on knowledge, properly so described, in the Australian and indeed whole Anglo-Saxon environment. We oppose it because of the potentially devastating impact, even the comparatively small impost, in percentage terms, it will have on marginally viable publishing enterprises, small book publishers and especially publishers of small magazines.

SPEECH.PARA: We oppose the new taxes on clothing, footwear and drapery because they deal with matters that are unequivocally among the necessities of life on any definition of that now rather overused expression. We oppose the taxes on wrapping and packaging material because of the small but undoubtedly cumulative effect they will have on the price of food, another obvious necessity. We oppose the new tax on building materials because of the significant marginal impact a new tax of 2 1/2 per cent will have on the already escalating price of new houses and indeed on building activity generally in an industry which is staggering on its feet at the moment as a result of the obviously desolate condition of the general economy. We have objections which, as I say, speaker after speaker in this debate and debates before it have enumerated to everyone of the items in issue in these Bills just as we opposed-unlike our colleagues the Australian Democrats-the more general tax increases and even more broad- ranging ones in Bills Nos 1 to 9 and in the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1981 which were passed in the last parliamentary year, of course, with the Australian Democrats' support.

We believe that most of the items in the present list of matters in Bills Nos 1A to 9A come within the description of necessities, including books, about which Senator Lewis for, in his case, quite understandable reasons was so doubtful. But of course-this needs to be reiterated-we similarly took the view that a great many of the other matters in the previous packages of Bills also came within that description. It is a matter of regret that the conversion of the Australian Democrats, the shaft of light which overtook them on the road to the ballot box, apparently left some scales that cover still their eyes in this respect.

In Bills Nos 1 to 9, for example, there was an increase from 27 1/2 per cent to 30 per cent on items such as pens, deodorants, razors and shavers, and radios and television. Can it be said these days that those items are luxuries, or are they indeed part of the necessities of life? Perhaps radio and television might be thought to be marginal cases but how can they be regarded otherwise than as necessities, particularly for elderly peope living by themselves? Again there was an increase from 2 1/2 per cent to 5 per cent on furnishings, crockery, glass, cutlery, washing machines, vacuum cleaners, radiators, jugs, mattresses, pillows, light fittings and candles. What else are they but necessities of life on any view of it? In the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1981 there is an increase from zero up to 17 1/2 per cent through to 30 per cent on items such as pet foods, insecticides, windscreens and other car accessories and, indeed, oil for people's motor cars. Are these luxuries or, indeed, these days, necessities of life.

I am glad, as we all are on this side of the chamber, that the Australian Democrats have finally seen the light about Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos. 1A to 9A) 1981 [No. 2] (1982) that are now before us. But we can only wish, with the rest of the community, that that shaft of light had struck home a little bit sooner. Even though the case against these Bills-like all the other Bills before them in this sales tax package-on the merits of the Bills is, I suggest, overwhelming, the decision to oppose them was not by any means a reflex one on our part as has been claimed by some, particularly again the Australian Democrats whose reflexes these days must be getting a little bit dull through overuse. Rather it was a carefully considered decision on our part because important questions of principle are undoubtedly involved when any money Bill or any Budget Bill-the present Bills satisfy both those descriptions-is in issue.

We, unlike our opponents on the other side of this chamber, are concerned with constitutional propriety. We do not regard it as appropriate that this chamber should have the power of life or death-including financial life or death-over the properly elected government of the day. We want to secure a change in the role of this House, and in the way it perceives its role, to make it a constructive rather than a destructive influence in the parliamentary and political life of this nation. At the same time, operating, as we do, in a political and constitutional environment where our views of the role of this place do not seem to be shared on all sides of this House and where there is a community expectation that we will resist those measures which are manifestly damaging to the people and for which the Government lacks any credible mandate, we do not want to abdicate completely the powers that the present Constitution gives us to oppose Bills when it is manifestly in the larger community interest to do so.

Against this background, taking all those considerations into account, the Australian Labor Party had no doubt as to where its duty lay. There could be no justification in principle for rejecting or blocking any Bill on which the survival of a government depends-in other words, the kind of supply or appropriation Bills that were in issue in 1974-75. To do that for any reason, except perhaps as an absolute last resort device for explicitly securing constitutional reform, if that reform cannot be achieved by any other means, is to go straight back to the crude opportunistic path that was trodden by our opponents in 1974 and 1975 to the manifest disadvantage of this country's democratic constitutional arrangements. We will not be a part of it. But by the same token, with lesser Bills, whether they be money Bills or non-money Bills, those Bills which cannot be described as crucial in any way to the survival of the Government, we have consistently taken the view that we have an obligation to look at their merits. If the Bills in question are manifestly unmeritorious and if they lack any kind of clear, electoral mandate from the people, then we have an obligation, as long as the Senate operates as it does and retains the powers that it has at the moment, to defeat them.

These are the principles which we have consistently applied in the case of these Bills, despite all the numerous, tiresome and repetitive claims by speakers on the other side of the chamber that the Labor Party, its spokesmen and I in particular, have adopted as unprincipled a course as they did in 1975 and 1975. These are the principles which we have consistently applied in the course of reacting to these Bills because all the criteria that I have just mentioned have been amply satisfied in relation to them. So far as their merit or lack of it is concerned, I have said sufficient to demonstrate the basis on which that argument stands. So far as the question of a mandate is concerned, it has been said by speaker after speaker that, of course, it is the case that the Government can claim no mandate for this from the people. The situation is that the implementation of this measure is a product of deliberate Government deceit, with explicit statements being made throughout the course of the last election campaign that the government had no intention to introduce any broad-based indirect taxes of the kind that are in issue here and with the matter being the subject of a 'no comment' by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) just four days after the election date suggesting that the idea of implementing taxes such as this was very much in the Government's mind during the run-up to the election and was in the forefront of its thinking as a priority for implementation very soon afterwards. So there is a lack of a mandate on any view. But worse than that, there is a course of deceit associated with the introduction of these Bills.

More particularly, because this tends to be rather the issue on which the debate has focused, these Bills are simply not crucial to the survival of this Government in office in the way that it would be necessary for them to be if, as a matter of principle, it would be wrong for us to be opposing them. These sales tax Bills as a whole-that is not just Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A-9A) but Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1-9) 1981 and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classification) Amendment Bills which preceded them-represent some $553m worth of anticipated revenue out of a Budget of over $40,000m this financial year; just one eightieth of the total. Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A-9A) with which we are dealing right now represent much less than that-$132m anticipated initially for this financial year; $330m in a full year. Large as these sums may appear when looked at solely by themselves, in the total budgetary context they do not amount to much more than petty cash. With a deficit now running at something like $800m and likely to blow out beyond $1,000m this financial year, it is clear that $132m is not a sum of life or death significance to this Government.

With tax revenue from personal exertion increasing this year by a minimum, on the most conservative estimates, of around $3,000m, and a much more likely figure, according to Eric Risstrom, of something like $5,500m, it is clear that it is just plain dishonest to imply-as the Treasurer John Howard has-that any failure of the Government to grant further tax relief this year is on our heads, the heads of those who oppose the implementation of this sales tax legislation. The rejection of these Bills, and the reduction of the revenue that the Government can accordingly expect, may undoubtedly have made life more difficult for the Government this financial year but it has not threatened the capacity of the Fraser Government to govern. It has not threatened the capacity of this Government to survive in office for just as long as it wants to until the 1983 election. All that the rejection of this legislation means is that the Government will have to rethink its revenue sources and, in particular, it will have to take a much harder line than it has so far, despite all the trumpeted flim-flam of the Treasurer, Mr Howard, against the phenomenon of tax avoidance which rages unabated in our community.

The principled character of the opposition from the ALP, which I have been at pains to endeavour to explain-built, as it is, around these concepts of survival as distinct from non-survival Bills and around the concepts of mandate and merit , such that we will in summary only contemplate opposing non-survival Bills for which the Government has no mandate and which are manifestly unmeritorious- stands, I fear, in rather stark contrast to the principled position of our bedfellows on this occasion, the Australian Democrats.

The Australian Democrats-I regret that none of them is here in the chamber; I did, in fact, give them some advance warning that I would be saying these things , not too unkindly but more in a spirit of sorrow than anger-have found themselves obliged to admit that they have abandoned 'constitutional purity', to use their words, and succumbed to the blandishments of electoral opportunism. They have been forced through their leader to explain rather bashfully that they were tempted, that for a time they maintained their constitutional purity and resisted that temptation rather like a set of political Cliff Richardses; but now they have succumbed to the siren call of the ballot box. They have rolled over and they have given in. It is not really a mortal sin, they claim, because, after all, a lot of people will be better off as a result, but it is, they acknowledge regretfully and a little shamefacedly, a venial sin which they rather hope will be quickly forgiven and forgotten.

The most extraordinary thing about this whole convoluted process from our colleagues, the Australian Democrats-I will not weary the Senate with quotation and counter-quotation from the statutory declarations, mother's dying oaths, platform speeches, media columns and pages of Hansard, in the course of which, as I have said previously, they have adopted rather more positions than the ferris wheel at the Melbourne Show-is that it is all so unnecessary. The Australian Democrats perceived dilemma between constitutional purity on the one hand and crude opportunistic expediency on the other should not have been a dilemma at all. It became a dilemma only because of the Australian Democrats total conceptual confusion on matters of constitutional law and constitutional principle-a confusion which I suspect continues rather to this day. There was an utter inability to appreciate relevant differences between money Bills and Budget Bills, and Supply Bills and Appropriation Bills. Most of that language appears in the Constitution and all of it means something, but the meaning of most of it seems to this day to remain something of a mystery to the Democrats who, as a result, have been quite unable to articulate any kind of principled theory of the proper role of the Senate in a stable parliamentary democracy. There is a way in which to maintain constitutional purity while still opposing these Bills. The Labor Party without shame or apology has, I believe, shown that way, the relevant principles being those that I have been at pains to spell out again today as I, in common with other spokesmen on our side, have spelt out time and time again previously.

Let me finish by saying just a little about the implications perhaps for the future of the Senate acting in this way today or whenever it is that these votes are taken. There is no doubt that in respect of these Bills or others with which we have recently dealt or will deal in the near future, the conditions for a double dissolution will sooner or later be created. Indeed, if the literal terms of the Constitution mean anything at all-the literal language of the Constitution has in the past demonstrated its appeal to our political opponents- given that the literal text of the Constitution fails to say anything at all about advice in respect of a double dissolution actually being given to the Governor-General by the government of the day or the Prime Minister of the day, it may be that the Opposition will ask the Governor-General for a double dissolution when the conditions are satisfied. As I say, that would merely be based on a literal reading of the Constitution and have nothing to do with the conventions that have supposedly grown up around it.

It seems unlikely, that scenario apart, that there will be any double dissolution called by the Government this side of 30 June for the reason, if no other-I put political considerations to one side-that, by virtue of the operation of section 13 of the Constitution, to have a double dissolution before 30 June would once again for the future throw half Senate elections and House of Representatives elections completely out of kilter. The reason is-this will be well known to honourable senators-that in the event of a double dissolution their term commences from the preceding 1 July. If there were a double dissolution in the first half of this year, the half Senate would be due again before the middle of 1984 whereas the House of Representatives, of course, would not be due until 1985. So it seems unlikely that anything like that will happen before July.

In common with my party colleagues, I want to make the point-putting all that technical detail to one side-that if the Government wants to test its popularity at any time on this or any other issue with the electorate we will be only too happy to take it on. In an economic environment where interest rates are escalating weekly to intolerable levels, where inflation is rocketing back into double figures with the consumer price index for the last quarter taking it up to 11.3 per cent, where unemployment is back to its 1980 peak after appearing to level out for a time last year, where new job creations are falling sharply despite all the Government's crowing last year about the underlying rate of job creation and all its predictions to the contrary, where the Budget deficit is ballooning out to $800m to $1,000m when it was supposed to be $500m less than last year, and where the overall growth rate is clearly not going to do anything like reach the targeted figure of 3.5 per cent-taking all this and adding to it the iniquitous package of sales tax measures which the Senate is, I believe, about to reject-it is easy to see why it is that we in the Opposition are only too delighted to contemplate a double dissolution election at any time the Government dares to call one on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating an attempt by this Government to expand indirect taxation by applying a cruel tax to many essential household items. Indirect taxation is regarded by many of this country 's top economists as a very regressive tax in that it hits hardest the people who can least afford it. The low income earners, the unemployed and pensioners all have to pay the same amount of particular indirect taxes as the very wealthy in the community; in other words, a much higher proportion of their income. The study by Neil Warren of the University of New South Wales clearly shows this to be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills now before us-the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981 [No . 2] 1982-are seeking to increase this inequality and place an even greater burden on the poor and underprivileged sections of the Australian community. This Government is trying to extract a further $330m of revenue from taxpayers on top of the huge increases in pay-as-you-earn tax collections expected this year. Let us look at how the proposed increases in these taxes will affect people this financial year. While a wage earner receiving $14,500 can expect to gain a pay rise of around 13.5 per cent this year, his tax will go up by a massive 17 per cent. At the same time, a person earning $10,000 can expect to pay 20 per cent more in tax, while a person living near the poverty line will be paying a huge increase in tax of 33 per cent. So clearly, the proposed sales tax increases will make the poor get poorer while the rich get richer as they continue their tax evasion practices. This Government has the audacity to quibble about $330m a year in lost revenue, while tax evasion is costing the ordinary Australian taxpayers $7,000m each year.

As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) has rightly pointed out, tax evasion practices by the wealthiest 10 per cent of the population and by industry are costing the average Australian household $30 per week. That $30 could be used to help pay rocketing home mortgage repayments, higher health charges and all the other everyday living costs that have spiralled over the last 12 months under the Fraser Government. This Government is interested in raking in as much taxation revenue as it can just to hold down the growth in the money supply, which it says will reduce inflation. However, it has added to inflationary pressures by increasing sales taxes, and in doing so has become the highest taxing government in Australia's history. Since Mr Fraser came to power, pay-as-you-earn taxes have increased from 41.7 per cent of total tax revenue to 45.7 per cent. At the same time, taxes collected from the business and property sectors have decreased from 13.1 per cent to 9.5 per cent.

If we look at the taxation figures for other Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development countries we find that Australia has a higher proportion of total tax revenue coming from indirect taxes than the OECD average . Australia's taxation rate is higher than that in many countries, including Canada, the United States of America, West Germany and Japan. We also have a higher proportion of tax revenue coming from income taxes than the OECD average. Yet, when we look at company taxes, we see that the OECD is higher than Australia's figure. So it is quite clear that a case exists for lowering the tax burden on Australia's wage and salary earners.

In this Budget period the Government's total taxation revenue is expected to increase by $5,569m and of this total amount $3,134m will come from wage and salary earners. Next year wage and salary earners will be paying at least a further $5,000m. Yet this Government is trying to squeeze even more money from the Australian people without providing any offsetting reduction in income taxes . It is all very well for Mr Howard to say that these sales taxes are the beginning of an attempt to broaden the indirect tax base, but how can any so- called restructuring of taxation occur without any corresponding reduction in income tax collections? How can Mr Howard justify increasing sales taxes without providing income tax relief for Australia's lower and middle income earners? Most of all, how can he justify forcing pensioners, the unemployed and the poverty stricken to pay this cruel tax on essential items when they are already struggling to pay their rent, electricity and gas bills?

The decision by this Government to impose sales taxes on essential items, and indeed its decision to increase a whole range of sales taxes, is just part of its crippling economic strategy. As a result of the Howard Budget, unemployment is at least 6.3 per cent and rising. Interest rates are out of control and are set to rise again shortly. Surely the clearest indication that the Government's policies are not working is that inflation is rising again. This Government is following the same type of monetary policies as Mrs Thatcher is following in Britain-policies which have taken that country's unemployment total to nearly four million.

That brings me to another reason for opposing the imposition of taxes on essential items: namely, the crippling effect they will have on sections of the Australian economy. For instance, the sales tax on building materials will drive yet another nail into the coffin of the building industry in Australia and will add hundreds of dollars to the cost of the average home. Dwelling approvals in Australia are already at their lowest level for years, as a direct result of the Fraser Government's economic policies. High interest rates have already hit many young home buyers, and have even forced some people to sell off their homes as mortgage repayments have gone beyond their means. With another one percentage point rise in interest rates just around the corner, hundreds more Australians will be forced to give up that great Australian dream. The last thing the building industry wants now is a tax induced price rise on building materials. This is particularly so in South Australia, where the building industry has been ailing not only because of Fraser Government interest rates but also because of a totally incompetent State Government under Mr Tonkin.

I find it incredible that members of this Government have the nerve to criticise the Opposition for stopping the Government ripping off another $330m from Australian taxpayers. Yet they are from the same parties that blocked a whole Budget in 1975. It is my view, and the view of the Australian Labor Party, that the Australian people have had enough of this Government's restrictive economic policies.
