They are sick of crippling income taxes, forever increasing interest rates and this Government's pathetic attempt to impose even more taxes by way of these sales taxes on essential items. These Bills must be opposed in the interests of the Australian community, especially the poor and the needy and everyone else who is struggling for survival under the cruel and harsh economic policies of the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Government's revised emphasis taxation policies. At this stage of the debate I will be brief because I think most of the points involved have already been well covered. The information that comes to us from bodies such as the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development indicates that Australia is not highly taxed overall but that our personal income tax rates are high. As we all know, once tax rates start to get higher, incentive declines and evasion becomes more desirable. It brings out the worst in decent people and even encourages some to become crooks. It places undue burdens on people's fundamental honesty and produces a whole range of undesirable sidelines in their behaviour.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that a tax on goods is quite a fair tax to the extent that people with little money pay little tax and people with much money pay much tax. Under the scales of sales tax, the less necessary goods are, the more the rate of tax on them rises. That is an important point to remember. The rate of tax paid by people with more money works out to be a considerable amount higher than for those on lower ranges. I am against tax-all taxes-in any form. I should like to know who is not against taxes. While there is a move for certain sections of the community to pay less tax, I am not sure whether I am clear from the arguments as to who is supposed to pay the extra tax or in what form that is to come. If the groups that were specifically mentioned by the previous speaker, Senator Foreman, were to pay less tax where would we go? Would we look to the farmers? I think if we looked at them we would find that their incomes had a fairly nasty battering in the last year or two. So, I do not think we are likely to get much joy from having another run at the farmers at the moment.

Do we look to the miners? We are told of the enormous wealth of these nasty, multinational mining companies. But the figures I have seen in the last few days indicate that no miner of any consequence in Australia is making enormous profits that we can have a rattle at. Is it small business that we are looking to? Will we have another clean-up around small business? Are we looking to the manufacturers who are trying at the moment to cope with wage rises of, in the main, $30 or $40 a week? I do not think we will get much more out of them this year. Yet, we want to give tax cuts. Everybody would like to see tax cuts. At the same time we are looking for areas where we will provide more money.

I was going through a few copies of Hansard a little while ago just to see the areas where honourable senators opposite have suggested that we ought to be providing more money. I found reference to where more money was needed for housing, interest subsidies, Canberra development, the construction industry, setting up another Medibank, education of all sorts, all the items that were covered under the Review of Commonwealth Functions, buying South West Tasmania, assistance for small business, roads, more Public Service staff, more unemployment benefits, more migrant education payments, bigger and better pensions, school-to-work transition programs and the revision of apprenticeship schemes. If we are to start to look for money for all those things it has to come from somewhere. Do we revert to the old system and say, as Jim Cairns would say: 'We will run it off the printing press'? That is the only alternative. If we are not going to raise the money we have to print it. We have to have it before we can spend it. That is fairly fundamental.

If we do not get the money somebody will be short. Is it that we will cut the States short? Is it that we will cut local governments short? Will we start to go over the list of budgetary items that came out in the last Budget and say: ' Well, perhaps we had better rethink how much we are paying each child under the family allowance scheme'? Do we cut back assistance for Aboriginals, health, defence, education, employment and training schemes? All these items have had allocations made to them. We just need to have a look at these now and say: ' Well, if we do not have the money, what will we do?' Do we cut back assistance for industry? Do we cut back funding for research, culture or education? I have already mentioned housing. We have to start to look at the actual areas where money can be provided. Revenue either comes from taxes or from money not spent. It has to be one way or the other. When I look at that list of things that I mentioned on which the honourable senators opposite would like to spend money, I see that we can find that money only by a printing press job.

Senator Evans made the same old comments and endeavoured to justify them by saying that the matter is not crucial, is not a matter of survival and is not vital. What he has not told us even yet is how big the matter needs to be before he considers it to be crucial or vital. Does he have a limit? By whose standards do we determine the size that is necessary? How many times can we do something before it becomes vital? It sounds to me like the rather crude expression of ' being a little bit pregnant'. I am not sure at what stage one ceases to be in one condition and starts to be in another. I do not think Senator Evans does either, nor has he taken the trouble to try to explain it. Having seen the notes of some of the comments he has made at lectures to Labor lawyers and at various other places I can see that he certainly is not very sure himself. I do not really see that there is any reason he would be able to explain it to us any better than he can explain it to others.

Clearly, for me it is a matter of yes or no. Senator Evans's proposition has an enormous grey area. I think before we can start to take his proposition in any way seriously we need to have some limits put on it by him as to exactly what is involved. I do not see that there is any difference in principle whether it is big money or little money. I have always had a rule in my family that I never let my children refer to any amount of money with the word 'only' in front of it . It is money; it does not matter whether it is 2c or $2. One does not say 'only '. Exactly the same thing applies here. Money may buy an aircraft carrier or provide assistance to an unmarried mother, but it is still money.

I learnt this another way. I remember that once when I was fairly young I was engaged in a business dealing when a gentleman made an offer-a six figure offer- for a particular property in which I was involved. I went to the owner and said to him: 'Look, it's very close. It's within $5,000 of the price. I think it's pretty good'. He said: 'Boy, remember it's $5,000, and $5,000 is exactly the same amount of money to me as it is to you'. That is the sort of attitude that we need to take. It is not a matter of saying: 'Oh, it is only a little bit, it doesn't matter if the Budget only runs over by a little bit'. It runs over by an amount of money, and every dollar is a dollar that has to come from somewhere. It is exactly the same whoever and wherever the money comes from. I am somewhat appalled at the total disregard for any discussion on the management of the Budget, the size of the deficit and whether it should exist-nobody seems to worry. Some say: 'Oh, it's only a little bit and it doesn't matter'. Well, it does matter. The deficit has to be taken into account. There is no way it can just be simply ignored on the basis that it will go away or we will pick it up next year. Every dollar that is not raised has to come from somewhere.

I comment on the one phrase used many times by the previous speaker, Senator Foreman, that it is a cruel tax. Let us just look at this in some sort of perspective. If inflation is running at, say, 10 per cent, an item that costs $ 10 will go up by $1. A sales tax of 2 1/2 per cent will add 25c. Some of the things that have gone up by $10, $20, $50 or something like that at this stage would incur a tax of, say, 50c. As I heard said last night it would be half a cent on a newspaper. We have had a massive canvassing program from newspaper publishers around Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much do they usually put their own prices up, Senator?
—The last price rise by my local newspaper was 6c, I think, in one hit.
—Is that a tax on knowledge?

—A tenth of that is what is being claimed as a tax on knowledge. Paperbacks went up by $1 in one hit. What about the tax there? Is that more or less detrimental than the 7c that would have been involved with sales tax? It is absolutely ridiculous. We want to get this back into some sort of reasonable perspective for the people who have been waging these campaigns. I have to say that some of the outlandish statements and claims that they have made really do not do them a great deal of credit.

SPEECH.PARA: I would not be doing the right thing if I did not make some comment about our friends in the minority party. Much has been said about their situation, and I have heard all the quotations that have been used but when I pause for a minute to ask myself 'What does it show?' I am a little like Senator Evans. I can really only feel sorry for them. But I do not want to go over all the bits and pieces. It is a pity for this place that things have happened the way they have. I think it is probably most unfortunate for the Australian Democrats. This is the first real test that the party has had to face in this chamber. The result is now for history to determine. I believe the likelihood is that when Senator Mason faces St Peter he will be quoted the bottom line that he has referred to over and over again. I am equally sure that he will find that every newspaper in Australia will remember that term, certainly at the next election, and, depending on the results of that election, perhaps the one after that.

I certainly have no difficulties or doubts in supporting the legislation before the chamber. I have no doubts as to the correctness of an indirect tax as a means of spreading the taxation burden reasonably through the community. I certainly believe that the present rate of personal income tax is too high and I would like to see various changes made to it. I would like to see a reversion to the States being responsible for raising more of the money that they spend. I believe that they should be encouraged to undertake a greater responsibility in these matters than they now have. Many speakers have gone over the details of the bits and pieces of the Bill. I certainly support the Government legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes available to me I will confine myself to some of the remarks made by Senator Archer, who has just resumed his seat. I saw that he was getting his riding instructions to sit down. Early in the piece he made a vague reference to small business and criticised the Australian Labor Party, or the Opposition generally, for creating problems in that area. He might like to be reminded that more small businesses, and fairly large businesses, have gone bankrupt since December 1975 under the two governments with which Senator Archer has been associated than had gone bankrupt in the previous 20 years. It is largely as a result of the activities of this Government that so many bankruptcies are occurring not only in my State of Queensland but also in many other places. I am appalled. In my electoral office we help some of our less fortunate constituents who are trying to run a small business, sometimes not with the best of managerial expertise, in restructuring their businesses, consolidating loans and generally trying to put them back on the track. Most times we are able to succeed but of course some have gone so far into the red that it is just not possible to pull them out of the problems in which they find themselves as a direct result of the activities of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Archer proceeded to read out a number of things that are included in the Australian Labor Party policies which were enunciated prior to the last Federal election, many of which, of course, we will continue to use. In offering his criticism, he asked: 'How are you going to get the money?' The thing that amazes me is that this Government has all sorts of devious ways of trying to get money. I had a constituent ring me the other day, apparently over some small account with a particular department. The department had discovered that some two years ago that person had sent in a cheque 10c short of the amount that was required. The matter was not raised at the time but following the activities of the razor gang and with razor gang No. 2 now looking around and digging up old accounts, he got a bill for 10c, with a 24c stamp on it. That is a remarkable example of expertise in bookkeeping. It is no wonder that this country is going bankrupt.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I will not keep the Senate long. The 34th annual report of the Australian Egg Board is signed by Mr Ray Fuge, Chairman of the Australian Egg Board, a very distinguished person of many years standing in the South Australian poultry industry. It gives a comprehensive report on the operation of the Board and on the production and export of eggs from Australia. The matter that I want to raise tonight is the lack of any proper regulations in the Australian Capital Territory to ensure that Australian Capital Territory residents get good quality eggs. Last Saturday I visited a shop-I will not name it-in one of the suburbs of Canberra. Much to my horror stacked up layer after layer were fillers with two and a half dozen eggs on each. On examination I found that the majority of these eggs were second quality eggs. They were being fobbed off to the public here in the Australian Capital Territory. I made inquiries today of the Department of the Capital Territory and I was informed that there are no proper regulations governing the retail sale of eggs in the Australian Capital Territory. I make a plea tonight that something be done about this because recently the Australian Agricultural Council granted a huge extension of the quota applying in the Australian Capital Territory.

There are only two poultry farming organisations in the Territory. One organisation has a near monopoly. The other is a very small enterprise. It is the organisation with a virtual monopoly which is selling these eggs. Such eggs would not be allowed to be sold in any of the States in Australia, which have very rigid and strict regulations for quality and inspection of eggs. There is no inspection of eggs which are offered for sale to the residents of the Australian Capital Territory. I hope that the Government will quickly take some action to ensure that regulations covering the sale of eggs to consumers in the Australian Capital Territory are introduced and that those regulations are in conformity with the regulations and standards which govern the retail sale of eggs in every State in Australia. There are often complaints that eggs that go through the various State egg boards are of poor quality. I deny that because eggs that go through the egg boards are properly handled, properly inspected and properly cared for. That is not so with regard to eggs that are sold in retail outlets in the Australian Capital Territory.

With those few remarks I again make a plea that some action be taken by the Department of the Capital Territory to ensure as quickly as possible that all eggs offered for sale in the Australian Capital Territory are governed by proper regulations and conform with proper health standards. I was informed that the only time eggs offered for retail sale in the Australian Capital Territory are inspected is when the Department gets a complaint from a customer. Very few customers know that they have the right to complain about the quality of eggs. Once one breaks an egg, of course, one cannot put it back in the shell and take it back to the person one bought it from; it is in the pan or the saucepan and it has gone. I make the plea that some regulations be introduced to govern the quality of eggs that are offered for sale in the Australian Capital Territory.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 November 1981, on motion by Senator Thomas:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources outlined earlier, this is one of the most significant reports produced by this Senate for many years. I think it is somewhat disappointing that this parliamentary debate has lagged so far behind the tabling of the report. To some extent its contents have been overtaken by subsequent events, particularly the very severe recession in the aluminium industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I think some features of the Press reporting of the report were quite disappointing. I quote one such report:
Alcoa Reacts Angrily to the Senate Committee Report.
Another one was:
Senators call for a resource/rental tax of the Aluminium Industry.

I do not think those headlines necessarily reflected the balanced approach which the report itself tried to provide. On the other hand, we must acknowledge that there was some very good and useful reporting. I would particularly like to compliment Alan Thornhill of Australian Associated Press on his cool analysis of the aluminium industry which I believe provided readers with a succinct and reasonable appraisal of the Committee's work.

In retrospect I think that maybe the Committee should have placed a little more emphasis on the fact that the industry is by and large export oriented. Perhaps it should have developed a little more deeply some of the problems that the industry has to cope with in an export oriented world, including fluctuating world prices, exchange movements and the need for government to determine consistent policies, particularly with respect to taxation. Such matters as depreciation and the rate at which fixed assets are amortised into the general costing streams I believe should not only have relevance to the Australian environment but should also be related to what other countries adopt as acceptable methods of utilising their asset costs into the general stream of expenses. I do not think it is entirely relevant for export oriented industries merely to be compared with, say, manufacturers in the normal sense which cater purely for the Australian market.

One of the big problems is that the mining industry is faced with a proliferation of taxation systems, which is a matter to which the Committee directed attention. We believe there needs to be a co-ordinated approach in this area. Our report drew attention to the competition between the States to get smelters set up. Some concern was expressed by consumers, particularly of electricity, that they may have been subsidising the cost of electricity to those companies. The Chairman of the Committee, Senator Thomas, pointed out in an interview that certain local authorities, he believed, were negotiating totally blind without any guidance. To some extent local authorities have not had a lot of expertise in this area. There were difficulties not only for the aluminium companies because of a lack of precedent but also for the local authorities. We pointed out certain problems of an overconcentration of aluminium smelters in a particular area, particularly when there is a downturn in economic circumstances.

When this inquiry was first embarked upon there was a general euphoria about the benefits that the aluminium industry would provide for Australia. Some of us had certain feelings of disquiet about this enthusiasm. Other authorities had mentioned the problems of diamond price fluctuations in prices over the years. I refer to the Industries Assistance Commission report on this matter. There was in certain areas concern about the world over-supply of aluminium. This subsequently manifested itself in places such as Japan which had high costs of energy input. Fortunately, in Australia we have not seen the sorry spectacle of an aluminium smelter closing. This has happened overseas. It is true that a number of development projects in Australia have been severely curtailed. In Scotland people saw the sorry spectacle of the closure of an aluminium smelter at Invergordon, which in the 1960s was supposed to be the showplace of what were called the new energy related industries. This closure in an isolated place in Scotland brought about the dismissal of 900 employees. The British Government in recent times came to the conclusion that the British taxpayer could not afford the burdensome cost of keeping the smelter operating in view of the increased energy costs.

Our Committee too expressed concern about an over-concentration of smelters in certain areas such as the Hunter Valley and south-west Western Australia. An economic downturn could have dramatic and economic social effects in those regions. There is a current oversupply of aluminium. In Japan one group of smelters is operating at 64 per cent capacity. In the United Kingdom there are severe restrictions on output. The same situation pertains in the United States of America. I wish to respond to some of the criticisms that were directed to the report. Some were not necessarily criticisms of the Committee's report because they failed to distinguish between the Committee's role and the Government's responsibility. I think this was pretty important. At the same time , our report did not attempt to be a completely exhaustive portrayal of all aspects of the aluminium industry. It did not attempt to identify individual culprits in socially dubious activities such as transfer pricing and tax avoidance et cetera. However, we mentioned that the aluminium industries provided opportunities for a fertile ground for these kinds of practices and we identified certain companies' practices. In other areas we painted with a very broad brush and some companies subsequently felt that they were inevitably caught within the net and were therefore presumed to be culprits. It was not the purpose of the inquiry to carry out an inquisition into who was avoiding tax and who was not.
The report brought a very interesting response from ordinary people around Australia. I had one response from a young man, Warwick Smith, in Launceston. He believed:
The report illustrates the importance of a senate committee system.
I think that is a tribute to the Committee. He continued:
A detailed consideration of many problems and aspects of national life would escape focus and review without the present system of committees . . .

I believe this is an acknowledgement from one person in Australia of the importance of our committee system. Somebody mentioned last night the need for a feedback. This sort of feedback is important to show that we are contributing something to our national responsibilities. Therefore, I seek leave to have page one of Mr Smith's letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
14 Charlton Street, Launceston 7250 17th February, 1982.
Sen. John Watson,
A.M.P. Building,
St. John Street,
Launceston.
Dear Senator Watson,

PROCTEXT.PARA: Thank you for the copy of the Committee's report on the development of the Bauxite and Aluminium industries.
I dare say you have had much expert feedback on the report as the topic is one that requires a degree of specialisation, however, from a layman's viewpoint I would make some comments.

1. The report illustrates yet again the importance of a separate committee system. A detailed consideration of many problems and aspects of national life would escape focus and review without the present system of committees; if anything they should be expanded.

2. (Page 54). The final recommendation re standing in the courts is of particular interest. The Australian Law Reform Commission recently produced a report on class actions which is also related in some regard to the question of standing. Should both concepts i.e. class actions and liberalised standing, be introduced into the Australian Legal System it would, I believe, be to the community benefit. The topic requires much more discussion but the Committee has highlighted a failing in the present Australian Legal System.

3. (Page 33) While I acknowledge the Government's recent announcement with regard to the ''tightening'' of foreign investment guidelines in Australia the issue is, though seemingly dormant, potentially an explosive one. '' Australianism'' is growing in this country and is supported by all political parties in various ways. Foreign investment in Australia becomes emotive where it seems that the investment is such as to deprive Australians of the benefits of that investment. By urging increased equity participation by Australian owned companies and projects and establishing the financial climate for increased partnership arrangements between Australian companies and foreign investors, the Committee is giving voice to what many believe is the minimum acceptable for foreign investment. The recommendation to publish lists of Australian and foreign equity in mineral ventures is laudable. However, I feel more pressure should be exerted towards achieving ''Caltex'' type arrangements. The increased institutional investment in resource projects is one growing source of funds. An immediate adoption of the budget announcement to remove double taxation of dividends and thus entice the small investor into the share market may well be another.

TALK.START.PARA: —I conclude my remarks by saying that this is one of the better reports produced by a Senate Committee. It has provided a very adequate discussion on a matter of great national importance. (Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources entitled 'The Development of the Bauxite, Alumina and Aluminium Industries'. This report is of particular interest to me for a number of reasons. In the first place, I was a member of the Committee and involved in the investigation that went on prior to the writing of the report. I had the same contribution as others in the writing of the report. The second reason why it is of particular interest to me is that I am one of the two senators who represent the Northern Territory in this place. There is a mining and refining project at Gove. I am particularly interested in the relationship between the company and the Aborigines at Yirrkala. This parochial situation exists because of the situation in the Northern Territory. Another aspect which was of particular interest to us during the inquiry was the local government involvement in the bauxite, alumina and aluminium industries, particularly as it related to the establishment of refineries and the infrastructure needed by a large group such as a refinery. As part of this we were looking at the impact of the industry on the community. The last general interest that I had in this project was the way in which Australian people would benefit from the exploitation of Australia's resources.

SPEECH.PARA: We visited Gove. Those who were on the plane will remember that the Gove Peninsula, with its twin communities of Yirrkala and Nhulunbuy, is a delightful place. Although it is on a main route between Darwin and Cairns and is part of the Northern Territory it is isolated. It is interesting to note that the people living there, the people in the company, talk not of going on holidays but of getting out. A person will say: 'I am getting out in November', meaning he is going on holidays. Normally he is going back home although home might be overseas. It was interesting to note what could perhaps be called the siege mentality of people who live in an isolated area such as Gove, with all its amenities. I do not want to speak much about the place but it is delightful. Each of the homes is air conditioned. There is every sport imaginable. It has most of the pastimes a person would want such as archery, shooting, racing, sailing and fishing. In fact, it is very difficult to think of pursuits that we carry on in our leisure time that are not available there. The town is a beautiful place. Over $1m was spent on putting down turf. It is to all appearances one of the most beautiful spots in the Northern Territory, yet because of the sort of mentality to which I have referred people talk about getting out.

People in the Northern Territory, prior to the inquiry and certainly since, have some ideas about the company and its operations. I am not saying that the ideas which they put forward are necessarily true, but they are pretty generally held. It may be of interest, as background, to go through some of these. Before I discuss them, I tell honourable senators that I know the area fairly well. I visited Yirrkala before the mining company moved into Nhulunbuy. I went there many times in my former occupation. I have been a frequent visitor since. So I have watched the growth of the company and the impact of mining on the Aboriginal people in the area and the general impact of the mine on the economy of the Northern Territory.

Let us look at some of these generally held views of the people of the Northern Territory. The first one is that the company paid no taxes for years and that it got away with this by transfer pricing. I wonder whether this is true. Let us have a look at what the report says. Page 26 says:

The second example involves two subsidiaries of Alusuisse, Swiss Aluminium Australia, which owns 70 per cent of the Gove Joint Venture and ISAL, an aluminium smelter in Iceland. It has been suggested that the price of alumina ex Gove has 'increased at sea' before arrival in Iceland and that freight rates have been manipulated with the object of minimising taxable income in both Australia and Iceland. This matter is currently under investigation by the Australian Taxation Office and Icelandic authorities. On the evidence available to the Committee it does appear that the costing of alumina traded between Australia and Iceland has been carried out with the object of maximizing profit to the parent company at the expense of taxation and other charges paid in both Australia and Iceland. However, further comment on this matter should, properly, be deferred until investigation of it is completed.

I do not intend to go ahead because the situation, as suggested, is being investigated. But I do see a need for government to make sure that the companies do not cheat the Australian people. I use that word carefully because it is suggested by most of us that if a company from overseas, or a company from within Australia, for that matter, is exploiting an Australian resource, the people from all over Australia should profit from it. For years, Australia has had a frightened fawn approach to overseas companies. This is a fair comment to make. The real attitude of most State governments-or some of them-was to give overseas companies anything they asked for, to set up the infrastructure they required and hope that something good would come out of it. Queensland is a fairly good example. In Queensland we see that in some places there are railways to a hole in the ground as the only contribution left after the mining company has gone and taken the profits of the mining venture with it. I do not think I have to persuade people on either side of this chamber that this sort of situation must change. We must see the Australian people getting a fair return for the resources which belong to Australia and to Australians.

I make the point that we all accept that companies are in the business of getting the best possible deal for their shareholders and the greatest possible profit. We must see also that local government and State and Federal governments get the best deal for Australia. I will dwell on this point. We discussed it with a number of the local government groups, many of which still have the traditional frightened fawn approach that if they ask the companies for something they might not come and the local government would miss out. It is quite clear that we need skilled negotiators at all levels. It was interesting to see that in some cases there were skilled negotiators. But we certainly must overcome this frightened fawn approach. We must make sure that we appreciate that the company is out to get the best possible deal, particularly a company coming from outside. We like to feel that Australia is one of the affluent countries, and so it is. We like to feel that it is one of the developed countries, and so it is partially. It certainly is one of the lucky countries. But many overseas developers look at us simply as a source of raw material. They look at us no differently from the way in which they look at some of what we regard as Third World countries. They are out to make deals with the local people which will give the greatest possible return to their company. We have an obligation to make sure that we do the best for the people of Australia.

I remember that representatives of the Australian Mining Industry Council came to visit the Australian Labor Party Caucus committee on national resources. Among the many comments made to us was one which I thought was particularly significant. That Council said that government should make clear to any company- we are talking about exploitation of resources-exactly what it wants. The company could then decide whether it thought it was worth while coming in to exploit the resources. The major complaint that the Council had was that companies made certain arrangements but they were changed afterwards. This was felt to be unfair. I think that that is a proposition that most honourable senators would go along with. Of course, we have to buy in the skill that we may not have to make sure that we can negotiate fully to get the greatest return for the Australian people.

The second general feeling of people from the Northern Territory that I am talking about is that the Aboriginal people are not given jobs, that they are not getting a fair deal in that regard. Those honourable senators who read the newspapers at the time of the development of both Gove and Groote Eylandt might remember that a suggestion was made that the Aboriginal people ought to be given jobs and that they ought to be included at appropriate levels of the work force. Company policy at Gove-this is recorded in our report-is that everybody has the same chance irrespective of whether he is black or white. If we take that to the extreme, all graduates, black or white, would be considered in the same way. We all know that this is nonsense. There are not a great many Aboriginal graduates from the universities. Aborigines need to be given an opportunity. They need to be given special conditions of work because they do not approach work in the same way as we approach it, they do not have the same ethics.

We know that Aboriginal people have contracted to cut lawns and to collect garbage. I think we want to see a bit more than that. There are very few in the actual work force in the mine or in the plant. This is in contrast with the situation in the Groote Eylandt Mining Co. I have an advantage over my fellow members of the Committee in that I know that situation well. We did not examine it so I am interpolating my own views on this matter. But certainly, the situation at GEMCO on Groote Eylandt is that every encouragement is given to Aboriginal people to take part. Not only encouragement is given; assistance is also given in the way of special training. I am very pleased to report-I think I may have done this in the chamber before-the wonderful co-operation that exists between the Department of Education in the Northern Territory and the Groote Eylandt Mining Company in preparing the young men to take what are quite prestigious positions as drivers of the heavy machinery and trucks. Aboriginal people seem to have an aptitude for driving heavy machinery. They learn it very quickly.

We have to say that the general view of the people in the Territory that Aboriginal people are not assisted is a reasonable one. I had some personal experience of this in my former occupation when I went to a company with a man who was responsible for encouraging the employment of Aboriginal people by major companies in the Northern Territory. A group of four of us visited a company- this is going back to the late 1960s-and we were far from welcome. The people there made it quite clear that they were not at all interested in the propositions we put forward. On the other side of the coin, there are some people in the Northern Territory who say that the Aboriginal people have too much to say in the control of the mine. This is a value judgment-one that I personally do not support-but the general feeling among the community is that the royalties which are paid, either directly or through the Government, are very little compensation for what has happened to the community since the mining moved in. I refer to the disruptions to life, the drunkenness and the prostitution. This all seems to be part of what happens when a mining group moves in close to an Aboriginal community. I am not saying that it is necessarily so but certainly this has happened in most mining areas of Australia .

After the report had been laid on the table by our Chairman, some additional comments were made. Quite a number of the comments concerned a phrase which we used on page 1 of the report relating to the need for a secure and predictable framework. This goes beyond the on-site infrastructure that we talk about later on and beyond simply local government which is basically that sort of infrastructure although it is assisted by the State. It goes beyond the State and Commonwealth organisations but looks as well at the total economic climate and the attitude of government towards the establishment of the mining community . I will read from a letter written to the Committee by the aluminium firm Alcoa of Australia Ltd. The letter states on page 2:

Your Committee's report comments on Alcoa's power supply and pricing problems in Victoria. This comment itself qualifies the alleged political and economic stability of Australia and shows that the further processing of Australian national resources is not the dominant objective of government policy in this area.
That is a criticism directed not at the report but at the Federal Government. I will repeat the state- ment:
The further processing of Australian national resources is not the dominant objective of government policy in this area.
On page 3 of the letter Alcoa, in talking of the Federal and State economic policies, said:

There continues to be a lack of co-ordination between Federal and State Government, and between Government and Government instrumenalities, to ensure that Australia's national development policies are carried out. Unless the Federal and State Government economic policies are consistent in their application to new projects and Government instrumentalities have the financial capability to implement these policies, then the successful achievement of national objectives will not take place.
The letter states on page 4:

In reviewing the Federal, State and semi-government policies, it is clear that funding is often arranged on a year-by-year basis. While this policy may be relevant at a Federal level, it is contrary to sound financial practice for an instrumentality when funding long-term investment in a power station.

They are a number of criticisms of Federal Government policy towards the development of the bauxite, alumina and aluminium industries. A general point has been made that the industry has slumped since the publication of our report. I am glad to say that this was not actually blamed on the Committee, but the fact was simply noted that there had been a slump since the Committee produced its report.

Of course, the implication is that the recommendations of the Committee no longer apply. I quite clearly reject that proposition. Good management-that is the key of our report; I am sure we could say that-is more important in slump conditions obviously than it is in boom conditions. Almost anyone can handle a boom condition. That is why we have a proliferation of projects in boom conditions. I make the point strongly that good management is needed when the industry is marginal. That is all I have to say on this matter except to add that I support my fellow members of the Committee on calling on the Government to implement the recommendations of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not my intention to speak tonight to the report of the Standing Committee on National Resources on the development of the bauxite, alumina and aluminium industries. But as I discovered that there seemed to be some sort of difference between the view of the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Thomas, and at least one other honourable senator, Senator Tate, that the recommendations were in conflict in respect of the proposal for a resource tax, I thought that I ought to burden the Senate for a few minutes. Page 28 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee believes that any review of the current taxation applying to resources based industries should include consideration of the use of a resource rent tax or other variable tax on profit.

To me that reeks of the perhaps insidious wording that could have been incorporated by one of the sophisticated lawyers from the other side concerning the proposition that there ought to be a review of the taxation arrangements and that they, inherently, ought to include a resource tax. On that matter I have a very strong view, so I am moved to make some observations. It seems to me there has been quite a bit of academic debate about the justification for a resource rental tax. As I understand it the situation the Australian Labor Party would seek to have a resource rental tax because it believes a very significant amount of excess taxation is being kept unto the mining companies. This is money which it believes should quite properly be returned to its alleged rightful owners, the other taxpayers in Australia. It has been argued that minerals are owned by the Crown and therefore the inherent right of the Crown to provide a licence to the mining companies to exploit those minerals gives the Crown a special privilege to demand an economic rent. I would have thought that if that formula and proposal is to be presented in respect of mineral exploitation the same thing ought to apply to farmers given a monopoly over the price of land which the Crown owns by right. Also it would apply to such monopolies as airline companies, banks, television stations--

TALK.START.PARA: —Railways.

—It would apply to railways and to all sorts of other groups in the community which, but for the grace of the Government would not necessarily have the privilege of printing money, as it is described by some honourable senators on the other side including, as I recall, Senator Walsh.
—They are not depleting a non-renewable resource.

—It is suggested that these groups are depleting a non- renewable resource. I suggest that these mineral resources are renewable; the more we explore and exploit the more we are likely to find. Inasmuch as we are not likely to find more-if that is the view of some-then steps will be taken by those seeking to utilise and exploit those resources to find other sorts of resources and energy. To me it is stimulating and a guarantee of a sort of growth in some areas of energy that would not necessarily be found if it were not for the exploitation of these minerals.
—You should read this tomorrow and see what you said.

—Perhaps it may be a bit more sophisticated than Senator Grimes normally hears from his side. With respect, Senator Grimes should try to hear it from our side. It seems to me there is a belief in the community that the mining industry has a capacity to continue to pay and pay enormous amounts of taxation at levels that are not applicable to other sections of industry. I remind the Senate that on present available figures each commercial discovery of minerals costs approximately $50m. For each 1,000 prospects 100 are examined, 10 are drilled and one is brought to production. Drawing on a survey of 117 companies prepared by Coopers and Lybrand Services we see that $2,306m was invested in fixed assets and exploration expenditure in 1980-81. The effective after-tax return on average funds employed was 8.5 per cent. The Australian Bureau of Statistics publishes no figures enabling worthwhile inter-industry profit comparisons to be made. However, in 1976 the Industries Assistance Commission in its report on the petroleum and mining industry found that the average annual return on funds for 27 of the larger mining companies ranged between 11 per cent and 16 per cent for the period 1967-68 to 1973-74. It concluded that there was little difference between the return by the mining companies and the return by the manufacturing companies.
—What date was that?

—That was between 1967-68 and 1973-74. It is not easy to find statistics that give a relative comparison on these matters. The management consultant firm, P.A. Consulting Services Pty Ltd, recently published details of median returns on shareholders' funds for the period 1979-80. I make no apology for boring honourable senators with statistics because it seems to me that this is what the argument is all about. The returns on shareholders funds for that period were: Mining, 7.2 per cent; manufacturing, 11.9 per cent; primary production and distribution, 11.4 per cent; building and construction, 8.1 per cent; finance, 9.9 per cent; utilities, 6.7 per cent; retail-wholesale, 7.7 per cent; and vehicle distribution, 4 per cent. That is an average return of 8.36 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly there is little reason to believe that a mining company has some unique resource capacity to pay the punitive taxes which are suggested by the ALP. But sadly there seems to be a belief in the community, at least amongst those of a certain political persuasion, that if we confiscate certain illusory profits made by the mining companies we will have an abundance of wealth to redistribute amongst unidentified people who constitute another group. There is a gloomy view that one must take if one is to be realistic about the prospects of a resource tax solving the problems of government deficits. 'The Australian Mineral Industry Annual Review' of 1979 published by the Bureau of Mineral Resources provides the following statistics of mining profits, including those for oil and gas: Taxable income, $1301.7m; net tax, $588.3m; and net profit, $713m. This represents the theoretical maximum additional revenue which the Government would attract if a 100 per cent resource tax were imposed on profits.

A further survey, conducted by Cooper and Lybrand, referred to earlier, shows that for the year 1980-81 the total net profit for the whole group surveyed from a total revenue of $5,000m was $442m. In the context of the Federal Government's Budget of $41 billion it seems inconceivable that anyone could put the proposition that a resource tax will, in any way, affect or mitigate that deficit to a position where it is likely to have any beneficial influence upon public sector finances. If we reduce by 50 per cent the profit of mining companies for that one year it will represent 0.5 per cent of total revenue in the Federal Government's Budget. Perhaps the IAC best summed up the proposal of a resource rental tax when it concluded:

The Commission does not recommend the imposition of a super tax on the mining sector for several reasons. First, the effects on resource allocation of discriminatory taxation of the mining sector as a whole, or of individual industries within the sector, are unlikely to be desirable and would in all probability divert resources away from their most efficient uses. The mining sector in Australia is generally low cost and efficient, and resources should not be discouraged from moving into it. Second, the Commission accepts the view of witnesses that, because of the uncertainty in mining operations, some high returns will be necessary to offset the many losses made by mining companies: to the extent that the potential for high returns is reduced by a super tax, investment in the sector will be reduced. Third, the assessment of what constitutes excessive profits is a subjective judgment which the Commission is not qualified to make.

Let us remember that the Australian Constitution clearly leaves the ownership and control of minerals firmly in the hands of the States, not by accident but by design and perhaps contrary to the view of the centralists who make up at least half the numbers in this chamber. It is certainly a realistic proposition to put that if the Federal Government were so misguided as to seek to introduce a resource rental tax, which it would extract from the mining industry, the State governments' response would be very obvious. Of course they would raise the level of their royalties to the point where there was no income tax to be paid to the Federal Government. The net result of that would be that we would certainly not have a resource tax. We would have mitigation against the income tax paid by the mining companies. I have no doubt that the ALP has very carefully thought that through. What it would do is delete royalties as a tax deduction against net profits. That would lead to a bloodbath between the States and the Federal Government which would certainly be won by the State governments . It would leave the situation wide open and there would be no profits for anybody to take from the mining companies. I am sure there is no prospect of State governments--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh dear, oh dear!

—'Big deal', the man says. In other words, if there is no profit it is no big deal. I thought the honourable senator was hanging his hat on the income that he would suck from these mining companies that would inexorably go broke as a result of the enthusiasm of the ALP to deny them the sorts of profits that they are entitled to receive.
—Why don't you listen to someone other than mining companies?

—The moment I can find somebody on the honourable senator's side of the chamber to listen to who is more interesting than mining companies I will be all ears. It is abundantly clear that there is no prospect of mining companies--
—What price were Poseidon shares when you sold them and what are they now?
—The difference is a factor of 100.

—I do not mind engaging in dialogue with honourable senators on the other side except when occasions arise when one hears diatribes spewing from their vulgar mouths one can hardly feel motivated to engage in discussion. One thing has to be made quite clear. There is no prospect of the State governments giving away their prospects, their chances or their legitimate right to raise taxes through royalties.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last 12 months the amount of taxes paid by mining and exploration companies has increased to 60 per cent from 55.9 per cent and from 55.4 per cent the previous year. So the average mining company is paying more than 60 per cent of its gross profits in taxation. While we are all so enthusiastic about examining ways of extracting another pint of blood from the mining companies we ought to look at their profit record for the last 12 months. Alcoa of Australia Ltd had a 60 per cent drop in profits; Australian Mining and Smelting Ltd, a 100 per cent drop; Comalco Ltd, a 62 per cent drop; CRA Ltd, 93 per cent; Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd, 70 per cent; Mount Isa Mines Holdings Ltd, 48 per cent; North Broken Hill Holdings Ltd, 33 per cent; Peko-Wallsend Ltd 92 per cent, before the recent further write-off of its capital costs in a couple of mines; Renison Ltd, a 35 per cent drop; Western Mining Corporation Ltd, a one per cent profit; and EZ Industries Ltd, a 43 per cent drop for a six-month period.

If somebody can extract further profit from those mining companies and if he is sure it will not send the mining companies bankrupt I would like to know how he can do it. If he can find a way of changing the course of history in respect of taxation which will materially affect this community beyond perhaps one bottle of beer per family per year which is the 100 per cent value which could be extracted from the mining companies by way of a resource rent tax, I would like to know how he will do it. But the panacea rests on the other side with the two honourable senators whose seats are now vacant but who were so virulent a moment ago in their criticism of statistics. I would very much like to hear a substantive argument to the contrary. But of course the silence is deafening. A resource rental tax would be a diabolical and disastrous imposition upon the Australian community at present. It is a misguided belief to think that taxation can be raised for that purpose to change the budgetary position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The cumulative impact of this report by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources is, I believe, quite devastating for governments in Australia. What we have is an indictment of the national government for its passivity, and its reaction politics in the face of developers who want to use our great natural resources, whether minerals or energy. We were astounded at the way in which competitive bidding between State governments led to deals being done merely to ensure the presence of one of more stages of this industry within their borders-deals which were not to the overall benefit of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee was strongly of the view that the pace of development ought to be harnessed to serve national goals and social strategies. We were not saying in an overly centralistic, dictorial way that entrepreneurial choices should be dictated by a central government. But the Committee felt strongly, I believe, that the national government had a responsibility to harness the pace and development of this industry so that social dislocation did not occur, to put it negatively, and, to put it positively, so that the greatest national benefit could accrue to the Australian people from development. On the whole the Committee welcomed this development because of the creation of national wealth generated by an export-oriented industry. The bauxite, then the alumina, is upgraded by smelting it to aluminium. As I will point out later, this so increases the worth of that export product that the national benefit is immeasurably enhanced. Whilst we welcome this industry we were shocked by the lack of political competence and will power at the national level to become involved even in the necessary surveillance of important factors governing it.

I guess that the prime example was that of electricity tariffs. From evidence given to the Committee by Mr Monaghan of the Department of National Development and Energy, it became quite apparent not only that the Federal Government was not demanding knowledge of electricity tariffs charged by State electricity commissions to the smelters but also that it had not even made a formal request. This staggered me and, I am sure, other members of the Committee. It was the point at which I lost faith in the national Government's ability to harness this development for Australia's interests. It staggered me that State governments or electricity commissions could charge consumers a tariff which was unknown to the national Government, with all the repercussions that that may have on the profitability of the industry and the tax which the national Government might eventually be able to obtain.
We looked in vain for an overall, national policy. We made this clear on page 10 of our report where we said:
The Committee is concerned at the overall lack of clear policy on development at the Commonwealth level.

We provided chapter after chapter as evidence of that concern. I will just highlight some of those matters. I will start with the energy question. We considered it extremely important that all factors of production within Australia be brought into play-energy, natural resources and employment. We were not at all in favour of the coal and bauxite being exported separately overseas in order to be married in some overseas country. It is much better for them to be brought into co-ordination for refining into alumina and then smelting into aluminium. I can give some figures to show how important it is to our economy. When we looked at the Tomago alumimium smelter we noted that its annual export income is expected to be $330m at 1980 prices. This is 2.7 times the income which would be produced by exporting equivalent quantities of coal and alumina and more than seven times the export value of equivalent quantities of bauxite and coal. So to get that sevenfold increase in value for the Australian economy we considered it very important that our coal resources-those great energy resources with which we are blessed-be used in order to convert the bauxite to alumina and then to aluminium.

We make it very clear in our report that tariffs ought to be charged for electricity which enable the generating authority to recover the full costs of producing and transporting that energy. The generating authority ought also to get a realistic return for consumers funds which are invested by it. We found that sometimes commissions were looking to no more than 3 per cent per annum return on the capital invested in generating and transmitting capacity. We thought that a figure approaching 7 per cent would be much more realistic. In fact we thought that, in order to make very clear to the companies involved the true costs if their industry, perhaps they ought to look to providing electricity generating facilities themselves. Whilst it is true that even the largest smelters may not justify the construction of such an activity, in association with other industries in the same area it may well be that this would be a very realistic way of bringing home to manufacturers of aluminium, or other major products of the type, the true cost of producing that product.

I wish now to turn quickly to taxation. The Committee did call on the Commonwealth Government to review, once again, the possibility of imposing what is loosely called a 'resources rental tax' or some other variable tax on profits . The Committee noted that Mr Stone, the Secretary to the Treasury, in a suitably qualified answer, said that he thought it might be an area where it could probably be considered. I will read what the Senate Committee said in order to have it accurately on the record:

Where an industry's profitability provides a return on its investment significantly greater than that necessary to call forth the investment in the first place then there are valid reasons for considering a higher rate of tax on that 'excess' return on investment. This is particularly the case where, in the provision of services such as electricity to industry, there is some justification for believing that the full value of the resources used to provide that service are not being recovered from the purchaser.

Two or three points need to be made in relation to the remarks made by Senator Crichton-Browne on this tax. State governments are already levying a resource tax. They are already taking advantage of the fact that the national Government has withdrawn or abdicated from its responsibility to ensure that the wealth generated by a high level of profits above a trigger level return to the Australian community via the national Treasury. As we were completing this report we found it intolerable that, for example, the Northern Territory Government was considering levying a profits-related royalty of some 35 per cent on pre-tax net profits on various projects under way in the Northern Territory. That has been put on the back burner. But in relation to the Ashton Joint Venturers-Senator Crichton-Browne made the point in his question to Senator Carrick this morning-the Western Australian Government has established, by agreement with the Ashton Joint Venturers, a tax regime which will allow that Government to levy a 22 1/2 per cent profits-related tax once profits reach a trigger level of $20m per annum. That is a resources tax. It is a tax on profits from these highly profitable industries which are using our-'our' in the sense of 'our nation's'-great natural resources. State government after State government, in disguised ways such as special levies on the transport by rail of these products, is perceiving that where we have a highly profitable industry there is an opportunity to recover greater taxes than would simply be generated by normal company tax or simple royalty levies.

Rather than have State governments entering into an alliance with these great project developers, we are saying that the national Government has a responsibility to move into that area to secure revenue. This is only a further sharing of profits between the community and the company when a trigger point is reached. It is important to emphasise that point. However, I concede one point to Senator Crichton-Browne. A resources rent tax ought to be confined to a project by project assessment. It ought not to be levied in a way which, to my mind anyway, would be to the detriment of the national Treasury. It ought not be looked at company by company. The company would swallow up the profits, just as Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd swallows up the profits derived from Bass Strait. The profits are swallowed up in subsidising the steel division from time to time. The resources rent tax would have to be looked at project by project. The highly profitable nature of the project over a period would attract a further special sharing by the national Treasury. It is a truly progressive tax geared to capacity to pay. To that extent I think it actually has the support of most of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you make it negative?
—We would not levy a tax if no profits were earned.
—What are excess profits?
—One is not talking about excess profits; one is talking about profits above those which are normally needed to call forth investment in that type of project.
—That is a political judgment, not an economic judgment.

—Of course it is an economic judgment, one which would have to be very sensitively attuned to that project and that industry. There is no doctrinaire approach involved here. I refer, for example, to Bass Strait where huge windfall profits were generated by government decision. In such a situation it is felt that the community should share in such generation of profits beyond those which would normally be required to call forth investment decisions on those types of projects.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the question of ownership. It is very important that this Senate Committee, perhaps for the first time in this Parliament, pointed out on page 32 of its report:
Foreign ownership, particularly where the Australian branch is only part of a highly mobile transnational operation, carries with it a number of risks.

It is very important that a Senate committee has noted that risks are attached to the inviting into this country of transnational corporations to conduct part of their business. The risks, of course, are not insuperable and it should not be supposed that such transnational companies will engage in fraudulent or misleading practices such as would reduce the wealth circulating in the Australian community. There is no doubt that those who are responsive and responsible to shareholders involved in the exploration, production and further processing of these mineral and energy resources have their primary responsibility to those shareholders, although their interests may not coincide with Australia's national interest. It is as simple a proposition as that. The pace at which an industry may wish to exploit our resources may be faster than that which would best serve or coincide with the national interest.

We say that this industry with its international aspects is good for Australia. In fact, the only way that Australia can benefit from its great bauxite deposits is to become involved with these great international, highly integrated and vertically integrated corporations. We recognise that we will not have access to markets for our aluminium and bauxite unless we enter into a constructive partnership with these corporations. We are firmly of the view that participation by foreign investors in this industry is to be welcomed. Nevertheless, we believe that foreign investment guidelines need to be set in a way which encourages increasing Australian participation in those projects. This is not entirely to do with sharing in profits by way of dividends. The Committee found-it did so certainly to my surprise-that the wealth generated by way of dividends is, in fact, only a very small part of the wealth generated for the benefit of the Australian community.

We looked at the operations by Alcoa of Australia in 1980 and found that it made the following payments within Australia-I think Senator Crichton-Browne will be interested in this: Taxes and royalties, $100m; dividends, $23m; interest and other expenses, $7m and materials, wages and services, $566m. That is where the benefit to Australia lies. That is why we ought to be welcoming these great developments. In my view we should not-I think I differ with Senator Watson and perhaps with members of my party on this aspect-be overly obsessed with Australian ownership if it is thought of as a means of sharing in dividends and profits because profits and dividends are only a fractionally small part of the wealth which these great industries contribute to Australia's national well- being. We are saying that, nevertheless, the tax regime, insofar as taxation can help distribute some of those benefits away from the corporation itself or those who are lucky enough to be employed by it directly, ought to be a fair one of the nature that we have described.

On the subject of employment, the main conclusion reached by the Committee was that we ought to scotch the use of multipliers as a political argument in this country. We reached that conclusion on the basis that in their formulation one has difficulty-there is also obvious difficulty on the part of commentators-to draw any socially useful conclusions. At least that is what we found. A great variety of multipliers were presented to us. A fairly small base of jobs is created by the various stages of the industry. They peak during the construction phase, but of course construction workers move from project to project. In Western Australia in particular we had evidence that projects were being marshalled in such a way that they came on stream during the 1980s so as to allow construction workers to move from project to project. So even direct employment is difficult to assess. As I say, it may merely be that construction workers in particular move from project to project. Nevertheless, direct jobs are created once the project is fully established. There is some multiplier effect, but the Committee found the experts to be so divided as to what that multiplier number ought to be-it is a factor so evidently tempting to political manipulation-that it felt that it was better to concentrate on the sort of wealth generated overall in the economy, as I indicated a moment ago from the Alcoa figures for 1980, and to imagine that as having an effect throughout the economy in the purchase of goods and services than to try to look at multipliers from the small base of direct employment that is created.

On industrial infrastructure financing, the Committee was firmly of the view that where it can be shown that certain industrial infrastructure, transport, port facilities and so on are directly attributable to the operations of a particular project that project should pay that price. Where the facilities are shared between various projects and the general community, there ought to be a sharing of the costs between the community and the various projects involved. On the whole-this is particularly so where one has an expert-oriented profitable industry-the true costs of setting up the operation ought to be known at the beginning by its shareholders. The returns that flow to it are then true returns , and the community is not subsidising shareholders or consumers of the final product.

As to social infrastructure, we found remarkably and distressingly that at the very time that the Committee was meeting the razor gang was recommending the abolition of various regional assistance schemes established by the Commonwealth Government. We looked at the Hunter Valley and the Gladstone area. Since the report came down, I note that the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, has promised special funds for the Gladstone area in order to help build up the social infrastructure needed to service the families that have moved to Gladstone in pursuit of employment.

We believe that the Commonwealth Government's enthusiastic promotion of these industries in various regions of Australia leads to an obligation on the Commonwealth Government to provide some of the social infrastructure that is lacking in these rapidly expanding areas. The Commonwealth's positive regional adjustment policies, which included a range of schemes, have been undone by the acceptance of the razor gang's report by the Government. We believe that is the reason for some of the social disruption which has occurred to those who have already settled in the area and that the social needs of those who are moving into the area will not be adequately met. I think it is important that the social and industrial infrastructures be perceived as proper costs generated by the welcoming of these industries into an area. Finally, we dealt with the question of the environment. The Senate Committee-Senator Crichton-Browne will be pleased with this-was totally opposed to the use by Western Australian conservation interests of the courts of a foreign nation in order to pursue their protests at the degradation, as they alleged, of the Darling Ranges by bauxite mining operations there.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could not pay their court costs and they left the defendants with the costs.

—We opposed the use of foreign courts by these groups in order to achieve their ends. Having said that, the Committee was very conscious of the fact that many of these conservationists felt the need to go outside Australia because the legal and political processes within Australia were indeed inadequate. Therefore, looking at the legal inadequacies of their avenues of protest, the Committee recommended very strongly that, when the Law Reform Commission brings down its report on locus standi, as soon as possible steps be taken to liberalise the access of conservation groups to the courts so that they have a legal jurisdiction within Australia in which to make their point. I refer now to the political limbo they felt they were in. For example, in the Hunter Valley there is a question about the impact of fluoride emissions on vines. In the Darling Ranges there is grave doubt-I certainly have grave doubts after hearing some of the evidence, particularly from the proposals of the Worsley joint venturers-about the impact of the bauxite mining in those ranges on the salinity of Perth's water supply. Those projects are going ahead without those fears being allayed and without the full and complete scientific studies having been completed.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact it may be that in a sense they cannot be completed; it is only when the project has its disastrous impact, or beneficial impact as the case may be, that the proof may be there. For example, we found that the Worsley joint venturers made statements of hope about what they could do to prevent increasing the salinity risks to Perth's water supply, but the Commonwealth Department in its assessment of that project developer's report merely stated that it doubted that those hopes could be realised. The difficulty was that those Commonwealth department reports were not generally available. The Committee certainly recommended that Commonwealth Department of Home Affairs and Environment reports on these projects ought to be publicly available.

In that way, if the legal and political framework of decision making in relation to environmental concerns in this country could be liberalised, we would have access of interested parties to these forums, whether they are in the legal jurisdiction or the political jurisdiction. Also, with reports of the departments involved readily available to the community, we would have a situation in which conservationists, provided they are not obsessively or almost religiously devoted in a single-minded way to their cause, will have to accept that they have had a fair go within the Australian system. They will then have no cause to go overseas.

The Committee therefore concluded overall, I believe after a very exhaustive and worthwhile examination of this industry-I do not think I am being party political here-that the national Government had totally abdicated its proper and necessary role to harness the pace and the scope of the development of these industries within Australia in order to secure certain national and social goals . The national Government, we believed, in the end had abdicated its role and the States were competitively bidding in alliance with these great project developers. We believe that alliance cannot secure overall national goals. For that reason we hope that this report will be of benefit to the Australian community and will alert the national Government to its responsibilities. We look forward to that national Government's response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, my remarks on this report will be brief, as I am not a member of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources and have not been a member of the Senate very long. It is one of the best reports I have read. It appears to attempt to say honestly what is wrong with the Commonwealth Government's approach to industry and what is wrong with the State governments' approach to industry.
—It also said some good things.

—I am not being critical. I must say, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you and the other members of the Committee have honestly attempted to bring down a report which I think is of some value to the Senate.
—They thought nationally.

—That is right. I believe that this report does something for the Senate committees of inquiry. I really believe that it puts some basis to those committees of inquiry so that people can see that they are not party political and that they are at least honest in the way in which they attempt to bring down a report. This is better for the industry, the Government and the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to confine my remarks to one point; that is, Gladstone which is the heart of the development of alumina in Queensland. I think the previous speaker, Senator Tate, talked about industrial and social infrastructures. It appears to me that whilst the industrial infrastructure might have been served to some point in Gladstone, the social infrastructure certainly was not. If one looks at what has happened because of the industry developing in that area one will see that there is a problem of housing the people and the workers in the area. It is a really grave problem. I think the problem is probably recognised by the State Government. I noticed with some interest that former Senator Maunsell, who was a member of the Committee, has been replaced by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. I hope that that has a definite influence on what happens in Gladstone in Queensland. I hope the honourable senator has some influence on the Premier of that State in relation to the problems that exist for the social infrastructure of Gladstone.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a fascinating theory.

—It will be fascinating to see what the result is. We have a very fine industry and a very fine development in that area. But because of that development and because of the speed of the development of the industry we found that housing and the other social requirements could not keep pace. I suppose I am not telling the Committee members anything, but if they go to Queensland and inspect the housing problems there they will find two or maybe three caravans in the yard of a home. Families are living in caravans in the backyards of houses within the community there.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that if those people continue to live in those caravans in the backyards of dwellings in Gladstone there will be further problems in regard to family security and the education of children. A number of extra children in the community have to attend the school in the area. I think that is fairly clearly pointed out in one of the statements by the Committee. I know Senator Thomas was not being critical but I think he pointed out very well that the impression gained by the Committee was that the local authorities are not given sufficient support or sufficient information by the State or by the Commonwealth when negotiating with large corporations. Thus they often fail to negotiate effectively in their own right.

I think that is a truism. The Committee put a report down with a very relevant recommendation in relation to what is happening in Gladstone. The local authority cannot ever expect to receive the sort of income that it should receive by way of rates because three families live on one block of land. Rates are being paid on only one block; two families are not paying them. A strain is put on the supply of electricity and other services; for example, garbage and sewerage. The State Government is faced with a severe problem with education. These problems are multiplying. They are increasing at a greater rate than this Government, the State Government or, for that matter, the local authorities are able to handle. Unless this Government or the State Government intends to take some action on this report over and above the action on a normal basis from day to day concerning returns such as rates we will have increasing numbers of social problems in Gladstone.

Because of the schooling difficulties and other problems in relation to teenagers there will be more problems in Gladstone. We can look at crime and other problems that will develop in the area. This occurs, firstly, because of the pushing together of members of the community and, secondly, because the community does not have available to it the normal social facilities that are available to a normal community. The community receives a high rate of pay. There is nowhere where those families can spend the extra money that they have received because of their employment in the alumina plant.
