Further problems will develop in that area unless the Government takes some note of the points put down in the report of the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Overcrowded caravan parks.

—Caravan parks have developed in the area. The honourable senator is a member of the Committee and knows the problems that exist-the overcrowding, the children who run around the caravan parks and the lack of recreation facilities. This creates family problems. Unless-I say this quite clearly and openly-this Government or the State Government takes some note of the problems in Gladstone that have been brought about by the development of the alumina industry in the area we will have a multiplication of those problems. In the future the families in the area will suffer further because of the social problems. I hope that the Government takes some note of this report and the way in which it has been written. It was written in such a way as not to be party political. The report, I believe, draws some attention to the real problems that exist in the alumina industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The reason I sought leave to speak was that I discussed this matter when I introduced the report by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources some time ago. I will be very brief. It has been an excellent debate. I thank those honourable senators who have contributed. In particular, I thank Senator Jones because he was not a member of the Committee. His comments were very valid. I would like to say how much I appreciated the comments of Senator Crichton-Browne. He identified many of the problems that we came up with during the inquiry. There is no doubt that the States have a constitutional right to the resources. During the inquiry the Senate Committee was very conscious of this prior right. I hope and am confident that the recommendations that the Committee made to the Senate take account of these rights.

SPEECH.PARA: I personally-I think my views are shared by the rest of the Committee-was totally horrified with most of the Press responses to the tabling of our report. Some of the responses, as Senator Watson has identified, were fair and well balanced but a major portion of the reports was totally distorted. I personally have had a constant supply of letters from people all over Australia, and particularly from some of the companies involved in the industry, responding to Press reports of our report instead of responding to the report itself. That really is sad. I thought that as a politician I would be immune to this sort of treatment, but I guess that I have learnt all over again. It is sad, considering the work that the Committee put into this report which took a great deal of time and a lot of effort, that the report itself should be treated in such a dilatory way.

I repeat that the Senate Committee did not advocate a resources rental tax. It did not say that royalties were too low. It did not criticise any of the companies involved in the industry. The Committee's members, as other commentators have said tonight, were critical of some of the Commonwealth departments and some of their activities. We looked at the aluminium industry on the basis that it is good for Australia. It is a good industry. It is the ideal type of industry that Australia needs for the use of our relatively cheap energy and for the use of a high degree of technology which Australia is generating. In fact-I do not think this has been said tonight before-Australia is exporting trained people in this industry to other countries. We hear so often about the criticism that Australia needs to import its technology. Australia, as far as the aluminium industry is concerned, is exporting trained people to contribute in other countries. I think we should be very proud of that fact.

We conducted the inquiry on the basis that the aluminium industry is a great industry for Australia. It follows the guidelines that the Government has set for the sorts of industry that we should encourage in Australia. I make particular comment on the fact that it is an economic industry; it does not need any particular support from anybody in the way of protection or any other support. It competes on the world market. We believe that the aluminium industry is exactly the sort of industry that should be encouraged in Australia. It is also an industry that should share the benefits to all Australians as much as possible, and Senator Tate made some mention of that.

During our inquiry we recognised also that no section of the community should be particularly disadvantaged. I pay credit to Senator Jones for mentioning the point about Gladstone. I remind Senator Jones that the problems that are created in Gladstone are not necessarily created by the aluminium industry. It just so happens that the huge expansion in Gladstone-we cite the figures in the report- coincided with a huge series of resource developments in the town. This coincided with the Bowen Basin development and the building of the new power station. The shale oil deposits looked at that stage to be on stream. There was a new cement works. A whole series of developments created an unusual situation in Gladstone. As Senator Tate said, the Queensland Government has recognised this point by making quite a generous allocation of funds to that area.

Finally, I commend the report to the Senate. I trust that the Government will take this report seriously. We certainly put a great deal of effort into it. We hope that it will be considered in all seriousness by the Government. As far as the Government's consideration of this report is concerned-I think this comment could be applied to all committee reports-I hope that those departmental officers who prepared the submissions for our report are not the same people who consider the report and advise the departments when they respond to our report. It seems rather difficult for officers to have an opinion different from the one that they presented during our inquiry. I thank those other senators on the Committee who contributed to this very valuable debate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Australian Marine Science: Government Response-Ministerial Statement

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 November 1981, on motion by Senator Mason:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government's response to the Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment on Australian Marine Science reached us in the closing hours of the last session and at that stage it was not possible to deal with it. I am glad now to see that it has come up at this relatively early stage this session so that we can discuss it. The nature of the Government's response was such that I believe that it is a matter of some consequence not only for the Committee but also for the Senate and possibly even beyond that. Senator Jessop, as Chairman of the Committee, to my mind had priority to comment on this matter but since I was to speak in continuation, having taken the report in his absence, he has done me the courtesy of allowing me to precede him tonight. I know that he will be making comments later. He will, very properly I think, be commenting in detail on aspects of the Government's response whereas it is my desire to speak of it in general terms.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all I shall speak of the report on marine science, which I thought was an exhaustive report. Many responsible and informed points of view on this subject were taken into account. I am sure that all Senate standing committees take their inquiries seriously but I think this inquiry was one that our Committee felt to be of such importance that it had to be given a great deal of time, a great deal of thought and, indeed, a great deal of travel. Because of this I think that evidence was taken from more people than is sometimes the case in this sort of inquiry and that we were exposed to a much broader point of view than is sometimes the case. Part of the reason for the importance of the inquiry and, indeed, its timing was the extension of Australia's influence to the 200- mile zone and all the implications that arise from that. The report of the Committee was a unanimous one, supported by Committee members representing three parties in this chamber. It was a unanimous report which was arrived at not without a great deal of work and some agonising. I think that it has a particular value because of that. To my mind-perhaps I should not say it, being one of those who contributed; although I think it has to be said-it is a report of considerable integrity and considerable accuracy. Beyond that, having heard the evidence in most places as we travelled around Australia, I feel that this report is also a very fair representation of informed community point of view in relation to marine science and has a great value because of that.

The Government's reaction to the report has been so casual and negative as to be insulting not only to the Committee and the Senate but also to those many expert and informed people who gave large amounts of their valuable time to contribute to this process. I feel that this has once again brought the Senate to a crunch point where it must consider actively what its function is, why we have committees and why they go to this enormous amount of work and expense if the Government is going to take their recommendations and treat them with a casualness and a degree of negative thinking which I find almost indescribable. That is really what has happened in this case. The Senate committee system is of great potential value as a means of advising government on what the community wants and thinks. I would have thought that that was its major function. I believe that as far as is humanely possible this report certainly did so in relation to marine science.

I think that this matter in general terms must be considered by the Senate. The Senate must at some stage inquire into the matter-it has been raised here previously by members and chairmen of committees-of virtual Executive contempt for the recommendations of the committees of the Senate. Who is responsible for this? Is it the Executive or is it the bureaucracy? From wherever it comes, I believe that it is a situation which is so grave, so basically important and so damaging to the community as to deserve much more consideration than it has had so far in this place and perhaps also in the other place. As I have said, we are not considering our own protocol here. We are not considering our own time or our own trouble; we are considering the sincere, careful work of those people who make submissions and give evidence. They represent, through their submissions to the committees, the community at large. By being in contempt of the recommendations contained in the reports of these committees-I speak of our own committee and probably of others-which are made in a sincere attempt to represent the community point of view as accurately as possible, the Government is indeed thumbing its nose at the community at large and, where a report is on a specialised matter, as most of our reports are, it is thumbing its nose at informed and specialised opinion in the country. That, I believe, is a very serious indictment. I make it in the full knowledge that it is such, and I invite further discussion of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to refer to the response of the Government to the Report on Australian Marine Science which was presented by the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment last year. The response was made on 26 November 1981. This is the second report that the Committee has presented. Having regard to the fact that the Government had assumed responsibility for 200-nautical mile sea limit which encompasses an area of ocean of about 4.75 million square kilometres rich in resources and recognising the urgency, we felt that it was important that we present an early report demonstrating the Committee's view that substantial finance was required to exploit those resources and to ensure that a co-ordinated research program was developed at the earliest possible time.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, in responding to the Government's comments on the Committee's report, I must express extreme disappointment at the small number of recommendations that have been adopted by the Government. I have been quite impressed with the number of recommendations that have been adopted in the past from reports that have been presented by our Committee. But in this case the Committee put forward 45 recommendations, seven of which the Government chose to recognise as acceptable. These seven recommendations refer to priorities for marine science research. The Government did not accept any of the Committee's recommendations for increasing co-ordination in a fragmented and diverse field of scientific disciplines, nor did it accept recommendations put forward to assist the establishment of a marine science program for Australia.

Senator Mason has quite properly said-I am sure that Senator Mulvihill, who is the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, would agree-that the inquiry was exhaustive. We went out of our way to involve sections of the community in the scientific field, those involved with museums, conservation groups and those who have an interest in marine science and the value it has for Australia. I think it is disappointing that when we have gone out of our way to present informed, properly considered recommendations the Government has not seen fit to accept more of them. The Committee developed its recommendations after two years of inquiring into the needs of marine science-a relatively new and growing field of scientific endeavour in Australia. Because vast distances and organisational machinations serve only to disperse and fragment marine science in this country rather than to consolidate its efforts, the Committee proposed the development of an Australian Marine Science Council. This council would be an umbrella organisation utilising as much as possible existing research and service agencies in an attempt to co-ordinate diverse marine science activities. This structure is consistent with proposals put forward by the Interim Council of the Australian Institute of Marine Science, which reported to Parliament in 1970 on the need for an Australian Marine Science Council to co-ordinate marine science efforts. This proposal was never implemented.

Twelve years later the Government again rejects the formation of an Australian Marine Science Council based upon the proposal of the interim council, the structure and functions of the National Health and Medical Research Council and submissions put to the Committee by several highly experienced witnesses. The Committee's blueprint for an Australian Marine Science Council includes the preferred structure for co-ordinating the use of research vessels and other national facilities and information services. The Council's structure is based on the need for national and regional levels of co-ordination with input to a central policy-making council from regional and marine sciences committees and an advisory committee. These committees would comprise representatives of the marine science community.

The Government, in its response to the establishment of an Australian Marine Science Council, has listed its recent initiatives for developing a cohesive marine science program. However, these initiatives add nothing towards promoting co-ordination between existing research and service sectors. Instead the new initiatives only add to the research and technology strengths of existing agencies. The Committee is gravely concerned that its report, which clearly points towards providing a mechanism for co-ordinating marine science in this country; has been cast aside in preference for further piecemeal development.

I do not want to say too much more except to suggest that it would be folly for any government, of whichever persuasion, to fail to take note of the recommendations gathered as a result of public inquiries by a committee that examined the evidence of interested groups throughout Australia, the committee having considered the evidence delivered at those public inquiries, having distilled the evidence, having been quite fair and reasonable in assessing the needs within the community with respect of marine science and having brought forward a constructive proposal which can mean the formulation of a progressive policy with respect to marine science. I will certainly pursue, with the encouragement of the Committee, the course that I believe is necessary to be pursued by the Australian Government.

Recently I went to Tasmania to look at the site proposed for the establishment of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Division of Fisheries and Oceanography. That division will be functional, I understand, by June this year. I can assure the Government that my Committee will be following that development with interest. I would imagine that we would not resile from our responsibility to draw the attention of the Government to the importance of this area of scientific activity. We will undoubtedly follow up in due course the two reports that we have presented and present another one. I hope that the Government in the meantime will re-examine the recommendations that we have presented for its benefit. People sometimes are rather cynical about members of parliament and their ability to come to grips with scientific matters. But I can assure honourable senators that our Committee would probably know as much about this subject as the Government-I think more-and probably as much as the bureaucrats who dictate the terms that the Government chooses frequently to follow. I just present my feeling that this is an area of scientific development which needs to be dealt with urgently. I implore the Government to re-examine the recommendations that we have made because, if it adopts them, it will not detract from its credibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to jump on every report but I wish to raise one parochial issue during the discussion of this report. Before I raise that I must say that, after listening to the remarks of Senator Jessop and Senator Mason, some honourable senators must be somewhat amazed at the Government's inaction and non-provision of finance in relation to some recommendations made by some Senate standing committees. It seems to me that this is a problem for standing committees. It is very easy for the Senate to move to set up a standing committee. The standing committee does a lot of work enthusiastically-not on a party political basis-and brings down fruitful and energetic reports, and then we find that the recommendations are completely ignored by the Government.
—Not completely; it adopted seven.

—That is right. But this is one of the shames of the parliamentary system. I wish to make a comment in relation to this report by the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. The Committee stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Marine science includes those basic sciences concerned with the biological, chemical, geographical and physical composition of this marine environment, together with their interaction.
Marine science equally includes those applied sciences concerned with development and protection of this environment.

With those words in mind, I remind the Senate of the problems caused by the deadly box jellyfish in Queensland north of Mackay. I suppose it is like trying to get a point of view over to someone who is not listening or who has turned off his hearing-aid, but it seems to me that there certainly has not been enough money applied to looking at the problems caused by this box jellyfish. Because of the sort of tourist development which is taking place in Queensland north of Mackay and which will in turn return revenue to this Government and to the State Government, I honestly believe that there is some need for this Government to take note of the report brought down by the Committee with a view to spending an amount of money on the inspection and the classification of the sorts of problems that develop out of the deadly box jellyfish. In Queensland we are running into the tourist season when large numbers of tourists and a large amount of trade goes into the State, and again people will suffer from the problems caused by the deadly box jellyfish.

Because I am not a member of the Committee, that is the only matter I wish to speak on tonight. Because of that problem alone, I think the Government should start to take notice of some of these reports, of the amount of money that is put into them and of the amount of time put by honourable senators into the gathering of information to bring them down. We find that a report comes to the Senate, five or six senators say one or two words on it, it is put away and the Government forgets all about it. That is the shame of the system that has been developed in the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comment on the very important 1981 report of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry. The report was brought down by the secretariat of the Department of Housing and Construction. It analyses the state of the building industry and the problems facing it. It makes comments upon the problems of accommodation in Australia. In making such an objective report to the Federal Government, the national Parliament, the industry and the community generally, it does a great service to the Parliament and the country. It is a very important report because of the way in which it analyses the problems facing the industry and housing generally in Australia. It gives us an opportunity to understand the picture of housing and the industry in 1982. It has been made abundantly clear over recent times that the industry is in a state of complete disarray.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to acknowledge that housing has emerged as a major social problem and a major issue in the minds of the Australian people. It is a major problem for the national Government and for each of the State governments. The industry is feeling the effects of changes that are taking place in the Australian economy and Federal Government policies. The report provides an activity forecast for the remaining portion of 1980-81 since its preparation and 1981-82. It makes the estimate for the triennium 1981-82 to 1983-84 and gives projections of dwelling requirements to the end of the century. It analyses the factors influencing the structure, efficiency and output of the industry. It makes a very important point that this Government consistently ignores. It states:
A major issue facing the Industry during the 1980s will be the impact of the resources 'boom'.

That, of course, is exactly what the Australian Labor Party and the trade union movement in Australia have been saying. It is exactly what has been said by those associated with the housing industry at a number of seminars and conferences that have been held in the last year or two. It is not without some significance that this report from a government department and prepared by a group that has been appointed by the Government to carry out a survey and to advise it of the depths of the problems facing the housing industry in this country should make this and other conclusions to which I will refer. The scope of the report is described as follows:

Short-term forecasts of industry activity for 1980-81 and 1981-82 . . . estimates of the demand for new housing . . . and the industry's capacity to supply it . . . over the triennium 1981-82 to 1983-84 an assessment of housing requirements to the end of the century.

This is a very timely document, given the fact that every newspaper in our country has in the last couple of weeks featured a number of articles and made a number of editorial comments on this matter. I, together with my colleague, Mr Uren, and the leader of my party, Mr Hayden, have consistently said in the last couple of years that housing was moving into an acute crisis area and that the responsibility had to rest with the Australian Government to take energetic steps to recognise this fact and so to organise our economy that housing would move back to a position where market forces-if that is to be the philosophy of this Government-would not continue to depress the state of the industry. This very day there has been a meeting of the States specifically to discuss the housing crisis. No longer can it be said that only the Labor Party, the housing industry, the building unions and the homeless people are concerned about this issue. In fact, the State Premiers themselves have met to discuss the current housing crisis. Yet this Government consistently fails to accept the fact that a crisis exists in this sector of our economy.
What the report says has a lot of relevance to the Parliament itself. Page 19 of the report states:

Considerable uncertainties surround prospects for the housing industry for the remainder of 1980-81 and 1981-82. At the time of preparing this Report it was difficult to assess the effects of recent changes in interest rates on the supply and cost of housing finance, and thus demand for owner-occupied housing. Pressures exist for further adjustments. Furthermore, the direction of change in general economic and financial conditions and the increase in dwelling prices will also affect housing demand.

The report suggests that at least until the end of 1984 the capacity of housing will outstretch the demand. I do not think we need to be convinced of that. It is pretty clear on the basis of the prices of housing and the upward trend in rental accommodation that there is a market influence. The report states that it is estimated that capacity will average 144,000 dwellings a year while demand will be 141,000.

If we can assume that those figures are correct estimations-I think we can-it is clear that the Federal Government is doing nothing to overcome the backlog or the problems of housing accommodation in our country. I put it to the Senate that these figures show a degree of fine tuning which greatly calls into question our housing future. They do not give any hope that there will be any rectifying of the housing shortage. In fact recent figures suggest that the housing stocks situation will not be as favourably balanced as the report suggests. I am trying to rely on the report in the belief that the report comes from a Government department and it might have some impact upon Government thinking. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table drawn from figures supplied by the Real Estate Institute of Australia which show that in the rental market housing stock is in decline. These statistics were supplied by the legislative research section of the Parliamentary Library.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
Table 3
RENTAL VACANCY RATES
(per cent)

Source: Real Estate Institute of Australia, Market Facts, various issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The table shows that at November 1981 rental vacancy rates had fallen to half the November 1979 figure. They had fallen to half the figures suggested by the Real Estate Institute of Australia as a suitable level of rental housing fluidity. I refer to the rental market. The report before us tonight refers to a tight balance in the home buyers market , a balance that will increasingly be destabilised by rising interest rates and tighter liquidity in the finance market. No one disagrees that that is the situation that exists in the nation today. There is a shortage of credit and housing funds and, as a result, an increase in interest rates. They have been rising slowly but surely over the last couple of years. There are a number of projections that they will continue to rise during 1982. The figures that have been incorporated point to an impossible squeeze on the housing front. The report refers to the problems of housing in regional areas. It correctly points to the pressure that rapid resource development will place on housing. In particular, the report refers to the Hunter Valley resource development in my State. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major influences shaping the Australian economy during the 1980s will be the capital investment surge, particularly in resource related projects. This resource boom has direct and indirect implications for the housing industry at both the regional and national level.

The most obvious effect will be a rapid increase in housing demand in those regions where there are resource developments. In most cases the existing housing stock will be inadequate to accommodate the population growth associated with the resource projects.

So again what the Labor Party has been saying about resource development, about housing and about the pressures that will be exerted on other sectors of our economy are borne out in this report. Of course, anyone who knows of or who has seen the conditions that caravan park dwellers are forced to live in in the Latrobe Valley, Gladstone and the Hunter Valley resource development areas will know that this sort of accommodation is not good enough. I point out the stresses and strains it places upon local communities and local government in trying to provide reasonable community facilities in those areas as a result of unprecedented and unplanned growth taking place because of a direct stimulus by Federal and State governments. The housing policy of this Government and the policies of the mining companies must be brought into line. They must accept responsibility for solving these problems which will be a feature of the housing problems in these regions during the 1980s. Another section of the report deals with finance and its availability generally. In summary, the report closes on a gloomy but terse note. It says:

The council notes that in a climate of intense competition for available finance and increasing building costs, further pressures are likely on home ownership rates and hence the rental market . . . Governments--
This is particularly so of Federal governments-
should carefully examine housing programs to ensure that they are able to respond flexibly and appropriately to this emerging situation.

This report ought to be seriously considered by this Government because such reports are prepared by government agencies and placed before the Parliament for the Parliament's consideration. Governments have an obligation to take into account in the preparation of their Budgets the way these problems will influence the course of events in the economy. They must seriously consider the implications and the advice of such organisations as the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry. The Government invariably just takes notes of the paper and does not do anything to digest it or understand it, or apply the important evidence that is available to it. I conclude by referring to another section of the report which, without equivocation, endorses what the Australian Labor Party has been saying about the intense competition for funds that is taking place in Australia today for the savings of the average Australian and how these savings are being directed away from the housing industry. The report, at page 9, states:

The surge in resource investment is likely to make large demands on capital markets. While much of the capital required will come from overseas some will be drawn from household savings and it would not be possible or appropriate for the housing sector to be isolated from these developments.

I am led to believe that considerable proportions of the funds that are necessary for the resource development in our country are drawn from the domestic savings market, from our own funds in our own country. They are being siphoned off by the large international corporations that are carrying out the resource development. The report continues:

Housing finance institutions are already facing considerable competition from semi-government authorities borrowing to finance resource-related and other infrastructure. In these circumstances, it is important that the Government maintains an appropriate balance between external and domestic policies, and in turn between fiscal and monetary policy.

Of course, Senator Walsh, Senator Childs, Senator Chipp and I commented upon this in debate on the report of the Foreign Invesment Review Board. Of course the report refers to the need for the Government to have an appropriate balance between external and domestic policies and between fiscal and monetary policies. Yet obviously this Government completely ignores the evidence that is at hand. The report continues:

From the housing industry's viewpoint the worst situation would be one in which governments, unwilling or unable to control the budget deficit or the external account, relied unduly on monetary policy while artificially restraining the loan or deposit interest rates that might be offered by housing finance institutions.
The Council notes that in a climate of intense competition for available finance and increasing building costs, further pressures are likely on home ownership rates and hence the rental market.

Of course, we are aware that the percentage of home ownership in Australia in the period in which the Fraser Government has been in office has dropped from 74 per cent to about 71 per cent. We are aware of the tremendous increase, as a result of that drop, in the cost of ownership and the cost of rental accommodation which is making an impact on all of the social welfare problems that exist within our country. We have been pointing out that these are related to the un- planned development of resources which have been initiated by the Federal Government and in many cases encouraged by the State governments. There has been no central planning concept at all that would take into consideration sufficient funds for housing in a way that will not prevent the development of the resources that are necessary for our growth and which will at the same time make available to the housing industry such adequate funds to enable our people to be properly housed at a cost that makes it possible for the average Australian to be accommodated in a home and a region of his choice.

One only hopes that this report will have some influence upon the way in which the 1982 Budget is framed. If it does not, it is clear that this Government will cease to have the confidence of the Australian people because it has ignored all of the important evidence that is available to it on the sort of housing problems and plight that face Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to direct a few observations to General Business Order of the Day No. 181 which relates to the Industrial Relations Bureau. I am continuing my discussion of 19 November. I always make it a practice if I raise a matter relative to a Minister in another place-with all due respect to the Senate Minister concerned-to send that Minister an extract of what I said in this chamber. The Industrial Relations Bureau produces a mass of statistics of breaches, most of which are not diabolical or sinister. They often concern the area of small industry people who are not aware of the full impact of the industrial relations award.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to a large amount of unclaimed money lodged with the Bureau I suggested that we could utilise the ethnic Press to publicise details of the money, the people involved and, if necessary, the firm from which people could obtain that money. I make this suggestion because some years ago I was in Port Hedland, an area in which there is a fair amount of nomadic labour. People work there for a while and then move on thus creating a difficulty in tracing them. I suggested to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) that this matter ought to be taken up. It did not involve a momentous decision. It was not like the earlier matter concerning the marine science authority which may have necessitated the authorisation of big expenditure. I am still waiting for a positive response from the Minister. To me it is such a small matter and one in which we could get the ethnic Press involved. It would be a very fruitful exercise for all concerned.

Another point I raise concerns the fragmentation of industrial relations which is under the umbrella of the Commonwealth Government. We have a Department of Industrial Relations report which gives the command post, as it were, the hierarchy, of the Ministry. However, with the Industrial Relations Bureau there is no question of inspectors looking at award breaches. No doubt there are areas of State factory welfare boards which overlap in regard to industrial safety. I express the view that this should somehow be all put back under the one body. The IRB should become just a segment in the written report of the Department of Industrial Relations. It is remarkable to me how from time to time we get a pack of legislation to correct some imbalance or recurring industrial sore, but there is very little background information in the report.

I illustrate this by saying that last year during the Estimates I tried to track down the Commonwealth functions in the field of industrial safety. I remember one memorable night last year during the Estimates when, I think, Senator Baume, came in with a sort of cry of 'Eureka' because he had found the information. It was late at night and I admired his diligence. He said that responsibility for industrial safety at the Commonwealth level had been transferred from the Minister for Science and Technology to the Minister for Industrial Relations. While I applaud that decision we have not got very much information on the matter.

I repeat that when the IRB troubleshooters are in the field honourable senators would be surprised at the number of disputes that emanate from a resistance by the employee to industrial safety. Of course, as fast as we solve one problem we get another. In the 1950s there was the problem in heavy industry of ear defenders which were in their early days of development. Some of these were of bakelite composition and others were of rubber. While the worker would get protection from deafness there was a fair amount of irritation. Some people's inner ears got inflamed. These were matters on which not enough industrial safety work was done. Of course, in recent times we have seen the concept of the earmuffler at airports and at engineering establishments where people wear them when operating small or large presses. Some people argue that these mufflers give them a sort of mental isolation which makes them a bit morbid and melancholy. That is another field.

I make the point that when these areas are lumped together into the IRB or the Department of Industrial Relations we may not get the dynamic response that is necessary. We can ask the officers of these bureaus what their priorities are. We could ask them what the minimum or even maximum time is under the New South Wales metal trades award for a visit to a particular establishment. These officers might say: 'Oh, well, we get enough priority calls; others might wait a little while'. We can take the situation a little further. These officers go into highly unionised plants where there is no need for them to be at all. I think we would have a great deal more confidence if these statistics we get could be fleshed out a bit. I hope that on the next occasion we will not have matters relating to the Department of Industrial Relations in one booklet and matters relating to the IRB in another. I hope we will have them all under the one canvas as it were, so that when we deal with them we will be able to have, if necessary, an all enveloping criticism or in other cases give credit where it is due.

There is no question about it: When we look at the tremendous technological changes, the redundancies and all the rest of it we see that it is not just a matter of taking a chance. Recently I asked about the Rowntree chocolate factory which is in the confectionary field. That firm proudly said that the men over 55 years got a golden handshake. I said that that was true because there was not a big work force, but I asked what happened to those aged between 20 years and 40 years. I asked whether the firm followed through to see what industry these people went to because this could be a barometer for some other industries which might have redundancies. I will not weary the Senate now but I took as a yardstick the anticipated membership of the trade unions in the textile and rubber industries and showed how these memberships had gone down dramatically. We do not get those facts in Australia. I think that Scandinavian countries have tham. For some reason or another it is possible to get such figures from International Labour Organisation reports in some of these fields. It is much easier to get an assessment of the integration of industry in European Economic Community countries than it is in our own. I leave those thoughts with honourable senators in the hope that this will be the last occasion on which we will have the fragmentary treatment of industrial reports. In effect, if we can get them all under the one umbrella we can be much broader in our analysis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take up the point referred to by Senator Mulvihill concerning the fact that industrial relations matters are divided in a very artificial way. The role of the Department of Industrial Relations is set out in the report under the heading of 'Functions'. It includes industrial legislation, particularly the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, the provision of an effective federal industrial relations framework, an attempt to deal constructively with disputation that goes beyond the established processes, the improvement of the general industrial relations climate, and tripartite consultation to engender good employer-employee relations.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week a paper was presented by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) stating that he proposed to take new initiatives which, in my view, would affect industrial relations adversely. Honourable senators will recall that the three salient aspects of that paper were the proposals to encourage the establishment of industrial and plant unions, to abolish preference to unionists and to give employers powers automatically to stand down employees in industrial disputes. As I have said previously, this came after a statement that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) made in January in which he said that there was a need for reconciliation with the trade union movement and the various people involved in industrial relations. Of course that soft sell that I have referred to before has been changed by the Minister's recent statement to the Parliament.

The current initiative by the Government is only the most recent of a whole range of initiatives that have been taken to muddy the water of industrial relations. The fact that the Government has chosen to divide the industrial relations area into two sections only makes it more complex. It is necessary to comment on both aspects of the industrial relations area if one is to examine the actions that have been taken by this Government. It is worth looking at the initiatives that historically have been taken in industrial relations by this Government since it took office. The Liberal Government came to power in November 1975 and 16 amendments have been made to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act since. About one-third of these amendments have been of major industrial significance. One of the areas in which this Government has been particularly regressive is Public Service employment. I remind the Senate of the basic principle in the Constitution concerning the powers that we have in industrial relations. Of course I am referring to placitum (xxxv.) of section 51 of the Constitution. That has been the hallmark of industrial relations. The Constitution states:
Conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes extending beyond the limits of any one State.

The Minister is currently tinkering with this concept as he tries to by-pass ' the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes'. The constitutional concept is the basis of trade union and employer understanding of industrial relations and it is the basis for dealing with industrial disputes in this country. It is worth while remembering that the Government introduced the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act in 1977 which suspended and, where it was in the public interest, dismissed Commonwealth Government employees who took industrial action. We have had a series of measures which were all designed to curtail the activities of trade unions and trade union members and to weaken the trade union movement. It has all been part of the Government's strategy to prevent unions from gaining the advantages that they are entitled to for their employees.

The Industrial Relations Bureau has been used by the Government as an arm in preventing people from gaining the advantages that they should have. Unfortunately this has meant that the issues of the day have not been addressed. To look at the real issues it is necessary to get industrial disputes into their correct perspective. To do that we must look at the figures for the estimated cost of strikes on employment, absenteeism, injuries and fatalities. I cite the 1980 figures to show the estimated value of the loss of production. Industrial disputes caused a loss of $297m; injuries and fatalities caused a loss of $448m; unemployment caused a loss of $7,912m; and absenteeism caused a loss of $4,917m. When honourable senators consider those figures they will realise that the actual percentage of lost production caused by industrial disputes was 2.1 per cent. The percentage of production loss caused by injuries and fatalities was 3. 3 per cent. Unemployment-something the Government has done little about- accounted for a staggering 58.2 per cent. Of course I have not dealt with the hidden costs of unemployment. Absenteeism was responsible for 36.2 per cent of lost production. The significance of these figures is that the costs of industrial disputes are very small.

We are able to look at figures, some of which are amazing, which reveal the cause of industrial disputes. It is not the metal workers, whom Senator Walters is always referring to, who cause the majority of industrial disputes. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, 42 per cent of industrial disputes are management caused disputes. Another significant figure is that physical working conditions caused 21.4 per cent of disputes. Not enough attention is given to the physical conditions in which people in industry work. Unfortunately the physical conditions in industry, manufacturing industry in particular, are not looked at enough by statisticians and departments, and are not sufficiently dealt with by inspectors of the Bureau. After the Second World War many old buildings were replaced by saw-tooth, so-called modern buildings which are even more decrepit and unsatisfactory to work in. Many buildings are absolutely unsatisfactory.

I have seen people forced into taking industrial action because, for example, the temperature has gone over 30 degrees. Because of the inadequacy of the law people in many parts of Australia are forced to stop work in order to get relief from the heat in factories. The irony is that in many cases the people who stop work are not paid but they are prepared to take the decision to stop work because of the inability of inspectors to ensure that working conditions and factories are satisfactory for because State and Federal regulations are not adequate to cover the problem of working conditions in the plant.

When we realise that over 60 per cent of industrial disputes are caused by mangement provocation, the inadequacies of location or the environment of a factory we start to get industrial relations figures into a proper perspective. Managerial responsibility for industrial disputes must be taken into consideration together with the failure of this Government to do anything about industrial democracy.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Deportation of Mr Luigi Pochi and Mr Vincenzo Barbaro-Deportations to New Zealand-Queensland: Hoax-Personal Explanation

PROCTEXT.PARA: Deportation of Mr Luigi Pochi and Mr Vincenzo Barbaro-Deportations to New Zealand-Queensland: Hoax-Personal Explanation

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., in accordance with sessional orders, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make no apology tonight for taking some time to debate a ministerial statement made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Macphee, on the subject of the deportations of Messrs Pochi and Barbaro. Regrettably, there was no time, for one reason or another, including the non-co-operation of the Government, to debate this matter today. It is an extremely important matter, one which has excited a considerable amount of public attention. It is at least important that this chamber be given the courtesy of me putting my views to it-since I have certainly put them elsewhere- and, as a result, enable perhaps some short debate on the matter this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin with the proposition, which seems to have universal assent, that the Minister, Mr Ian Macphee, is a decent, civilised and honourable chap. It is a perception which I certainly personally share. But because Mr Macphee is such a person-he is relatively unique in that respect among members of the present Government-because he has said that he has wrestled with his conscience and mulled over these cases for scores of hours, because he has taken fully into account the implications for the families concerned and because, after doing all those things, he has ultimately, no doubt in good faith, come down in the way that he has, it should not mean that that is all there is to be said on the subject of whether these deportations are justified.

The decision to deport someone is a grave one at the best of times. The decision to deport two people, each with over 20 years membership of the Australian community, each with fully assimilated families and each with only minor criminal records, is a very grave one. The decision to deport someone who is in this position and who, at the same time, has a very strong opinion, on the merits, from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, supported by long and reasoned opinions of respected judges, is, to the extent that the deportation involves the overturning of such a decision, an even graver decision still. It is so grave that, in my view and in the view of the Opposition, it should be made by the Minister only when the strongest possible probative evidence is available to him of involvement by the person in an activity which is totally incompatible with that person's continued membership of the Australian community. It is so grave a decision that it should be made only when the Minister is more than merely personally satisfied. It should not be made when he is merely left-as Mr Macphee put it in his comments to the House-with a reasonable suspicion that something is amiss.

For decisions of this gravity to be justified the Minister must believe that what he is asserting is established beyond reasonable doubt. He must believe it in a way that he can communicate it, and communicate it in a way that is capable of acceptance by those who, without any axe to grind, are simply anxious to see that justice is done. The trouble with the Minister's statement on this matter and his reply to the debate in the House of Representatives is that when we look at those contributions and study the language very carefully they simply do not satisfy these criteria. In particular, in neither case is there anything added to what was before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Something should be added if the Minister and the Government want us to accept that the right decision was made and that no injustice has been perpetrated.

Let me briefly take each case in turn, beginning with Barbaro, a case which was decided in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in Barbaro's favour in March 1981 , long after the report of Mr Justice Woodward. Incidentally, it was not the Mr Justice Woodward of the Federal Court, of Australian Security Intelligence Organisation fame, of the Aboriginal land rights inquiry fame, and now the meat inquiry fame. It was a rather different Mr Justice Woodward from New South Wales , with a rather different reputation. The report from that Mr Justice Woodward was very much available to Mr Justice Fisher of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and very much taken into account by him when reaching the conclusions that he did, that Barbaro was but a big player in the Griffith marihuana exercise and not deserving of anything like the gravity of treatment that was involved in a ministerial decision to deport him.

There is no doubt that nothing at all has been added by the Minister to the information. Nothing at all was before the Minister other than the information that was before Mr Justice Fisher when he made his decision. There is no doubt that the Minister was doing no more, in reviewing the Barbaro case, than substituting his own judgment, his own intuition for that of the learned judge. Of course, the Minister is entitled to do that, as a matter of law; but we are entitled, as a matter of policy, I believe, to ask for something more than that.

The difficulty about the Barbaro case is that there is nothing in the Woodward report, and nothing certainly, it appears, in the other material available to the Minister, that suggests that Barbaro was other than the most marginal figure in the Riverina marihuana-growing operation. Certainly he was arrested on one of the plantations at Euston when he was engaged in cultivating a patch of marihuana, but that seems to be as far as his involvement went, apart from the unfortunate association of names and relationships of a family kind with other members of the Calabrian families who had come from southern Italy and settled in various parts of Australia. There is no suggestion that he had any financial involvement or that he was involved in laundering any significant sums of money. There is no suggestion other than the baldest assertion, unaccompanied in the Woodward report by any evidence whatsoever, or any discussion of any other information whatsoever, that he was a member of the so-called secret society of Calabrians, the honoured society, of which Mr Justice Woodward, and the media now, through the Minister, have made so much.

There is no suggestion whatever in the Woodward inquiry, and certainly not in the treatment accorded that inquiry in Mr Justice Fisher's decision, that Barbaro was in any way involved directly or indirectly in the events leading up to or involved in the tragic disappearance of Donald Mackay. There is nothing on the record and nothing in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal proceedings, or in the Woodward commission which, as I say, analysed very carefully those proceedings, which suggests that Barbaro has had any continuing involvement whatsoever with the people or activity that got him into trouble with the law in the first place.

The Minister, in his statement in the Parliament, said that he would be naive if he did not expect them to be continuing members of that particular marihuana cultivating and marketing organisation. But we are entitled to ask the Minister, in turn, what is the foundation for that statement? Is there any evidence whatsoever of continuing involvement by this fellow? Where is that evidence? If the Minister has it, why does he not bring it forward? Why does he not at least make a declaration that he has it without giving the details if that in turn is based on informer evidence of a kind that cannot be made public? If he does have such evidence, if there is any suggestion at all of continuing involvement by that fellow in this particular crowd and this peculiarly sordid activity, there can be no justification for pursuing this debate one second longer. The man should be out of the country. But that evidence is not there.

I want to put on the record, because I think they ought to be there for people to see for themselves, some of the relevant passages from the judgment of Mr Justice Fisher in that AAT case, the Barbaro case. Having discussed it with the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), I seek leave accordingly to incorporate the relevant passage of the decision by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Very careful and critical scrutiny must be given and much significance must attach in this matter to the nature of the crime because of the contention and the suspicion that the applicant was a member of a secret criminal organization. In fact it was alleged that he was a member of a cell of that organization which not only engaged in large scale production and trafficking in cannabis but was probably responsible for the death of Mr Donald McKay at Griffith in New South Wales. Furthermore the Report of the Woodward Royal Commission made an express finding that the applicant was such a member. The question is whether after the relatively exhaustive enquiry on this topic before me and also after hearing from the applicant his story (which advantage the Royal Commissioner did not have) I am sufficiently satisfied to assess the applicant as such a member or as involved to the extent alleged. If so, and I am satisfied his involvement is more than that of a farm labourer, the scales are weighted heavily in favour of deportation.

In essence the suspicion that he was so involved is based on four circumstances , namely his presence at Willra Station, his association with persons convicted of drug offences, the findings of the Woodward Royal Commission and the opinion of Police Officers. These circumstances are of course to an extent mutually dependent. A further matter relied upon was the inference, if any, to be drawn from the circumstances in which the applicant's bail was paid but I have already dealt with that matter.

In respect of his presence on Willra Station the applicant was, at first glance , only there as a labourer and with no involvement in the organisational or entrepreneurial activities. This was the finding of the Woodward Royal Commission. However, the contention before me was that, the plantation being so large and conducted under the auspices of a criminal organization, he would only be working there if he was a trusted member of the organization. To my mind this conclusion does not necessarily follow and there are alternative explanations. Equally if not more plausible, which receive support from the evidence. There was no evidence which even suggests he was to receive or has received any reward or benefit apart from his wages or that he had any contact or connection with the organizers other than as a labourer. More likely it is that persons in Salisbury (that is persons whom Dean Travers referred to as ''headmen'') had connections with the organizers and recruited for work at Willra. The applicant was generally known at the time to be a good but currently impecunious worker who had migrated from Calabria. His unguarded admissions when first questioned lend support to this as the more likely explanation. However subsequent to his release on bail, the applicant spent some four weeks with the co-accused on Willra Station and this circumstance could lend some support to the contention of more extensive involvement. However on the applicant's story he had not left Adelaide intending to pick marihuana and those who had involved him at least owed it to him in his impecunious circumstances to provide accommodation whilst he was liable to report daily. This is an equally if not more acceptable explanation.

Much evidence was put before me tending to establish that he is still associating with persons involved in marihuana dealings. However the crucial evidence is that he is not related to nor is he associating with persons involved in the Griffith organization. The uncontradicted evidence is that he does not know any of those persons and his trip to Euston was his first outside of South Australia. The persons with whom he mainly associates are members of the Italian community in Salisbury but the evidence is that he and his family do not restrict themselves to this community. There were three persons named who had lived in Salisbury and who had involvements in illegal marihuana activities, his brother-in-law Michael Sergi, his nephew Pietro Sergi and Rocco Carbone, the husband of a niece. The involvement of each was in South Australia and there is no evidence at all that they have any links either by marriage or friendship with the Griffith organization. The two Sergis were working as labourers on a farm at Keith and each fined $500 and released on a bond. Rocco Carbone has been charged but the matter has not yet been heard. Nor was there any suggestion that , in so far as there is in the words of Dean Travers ''a Mafia type organization in Salisbury'', the applicant or any of the persons with whom he associates are members of that organization.

For the purposes of the hearing before me I can accept all the findings of the Woodward Royal Commission in respect of the activities of the Griffith organization and the production and distribution of illicit drugs in New South Wales and Willra in particular. Furthermore there was before me no evidence which bears on the finding of links between the New South Wales organization and marihuana growing in South Australia and the Salisbury area in particular. However insofar as the Royal Commission made a finding as to the involvement of the applicant in this organization, this finding must be considered in the light of the evidence before me and the fact that the applicant was not before the Commission. I am not prepared on this evidence to proceed on the basis that his involvement was as a ''trusted member of the Griffith organization''. I must in fairness accept that he was a farm labourer and not infer more because of the fact that he is a Calabrian born in Plati. The fact that he may have lived next door to Saverio Barbaro's sister in Berri does not warrant the inference that he knew Saverio Barbaro prior to his visit to Euston and through him had links with Griffith.

A number of police officers gave evidence that in their opinion the applicant was more deeply involved at Willra and in effect was still involved in marihuana activities. These police officers have had much experience in the task of trying to stamp out these illegal activities and their opinions are entitled to careful consideration. However none of them could give me any firm basis for his opinion but relied upon information supplied by other persons including informers paid on results and the drawing of inferences from the applicant's associates in Salisbury. In my view whilst I give anxious consideration to these opinions, there is too much chance of an injustice being perpetrated if I attach much weight to them. I did in a number of instances indicate my wish for more concrete evidence if I was to give these opinions any weight, but none was forthcoming. When I put my concern to counsel for the Minister he acknowledged that it was proper for any doubts to be resolved in favour of the applicant and his family. When hearsay evidence is in question, the comments of Lord Justice Lane in R. v Hull Prison Board of Visitors [1973] 3 All E.R. 545 at pages 552-3 are in point.

Thus, after considering the four circumstances, separately and together, I am satisfied that the involvement of the applicant was probably merely that of a farm labourer and that this is the nature of his crime which I should accept for the purpose of this review.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I do not intend to read the whole of the four pages in question. Let me convey the flavour of that decision by reading two or three passages as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Much evidence-
This was said by Mr Justice Fisher-
was put before me tending to establish that he-
That is Barbaro-

is still associating with persons involved in marihuana dealings. However the crucial evidence is that he is not related to nor is he associating with persons involved in the Griffith organization. The uncontradicted evidence is that he does not know any of those persons and his trip to Euston was his first outside of South Australia.
. . . insofar as the Royal Commission made a finding as to the involvement of the applicant in this organization-
Mr Justice Fisher is there referring to the secret Calabrian organisation-

this finding must be considered in the light of the evidence before me and the fact that the applicant was not before the Commission. I am not prepared on this evidence to proceed on the basis that his involvement was as a 'trusted member of the Griffith organization'. I must in fairness accept that he was a farm labourer and not infer more because of the fact that he is a Calabrian born in Plati.
He continues:
A number of police officers gave evidence that in their opinion the applicant was more deeply involved at Willra-
This is at Euston in New South Wales-

and in effect was still involved in marihuana activities. These police officers have had much experience in the task of trying to stamp out these illegal activities and their opinions are entitled to careful consideration. However, none of them could give me any firm basis for his opinion but relied upon information supplied by other persons, including informers paid on results and the drawing of inferences from the applicant's associates in Salisbury. In my view whilst I give anxious consideration to these opinions, there is too much chance of an injustice being perpetrated if I attach much weight to them. I did in a number of instances indicate my wish for more concrete evidence if I was to give these opinions any weight, but none was forthcoming. When I put my concern to counsel for the Minister he acknowledged that it was proper for any doubts to be resolved in favour of the applicant and his family.

That is the sort of thing that goes right through the Barbaro judgment in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. There is nothing more than that on the Minister 's desk now, nor has there been anything more on his desk when he has been dealing with this particular case, looking at it, reviewing it and agonising over it, as he says, for the last few months. There is nothing more than the material that was available for that judge to produce that very meticulous decision. I keep saying that I think we are entitled to ask for more than that.

The case of Pochi-that has been the one given more prominent media attention associated with this particular matter-in some ways is a harder case and in some ways an easier case for the Minister to justify. It is harder to justify because of the threshold consideration that it is only as a result of bureaucratic bungling, as Mr Justice Deane quite explicitly put it in the Federal Court stage of this particular case, thereby referring to an unhappy course of events which is described in detail by Mr Justice Brennan at the AAT stage of the hearings, that Mr Pochi is not on fact today an Australian citizen and unable to be deported. There is an obvious element of unfairness right at the threshold before we even get to look at the merits of this particular case.

On the other hand, it is much easier for the Minister to justify, at least at first sight, the action he has taken in respect of Pochi because of not only the horticultural role that was obviously played by Pochi in the Griffith organisation but also the financial role. A very great amount of detailed attention is paid to that financial role in the AAT decision of Mr Justice Brennan where he chooses ultimately, on balance, to put it to one side and say, even despite this, that the fellow ought not to be deported. Very great, loving and elaborate detail is also given to the financial information in the Woodward report. It is a matter of very considerable interest that in the time that I have had to compare the findings of the Woodward report on these matters in relation to Pochi and the detailed information contained in the AAT judgement, in no single respect have I been able to find any significant difference of detail in the two.

What does that add up to in the case of Pochi? In the first place I suggest that, as with Barbaro, it still is possible to conclude, although no doubt with a little more difficulty, that Pochi was not other than an extremely marginal figure in the Riverina marihuana growing operation led by the Sergi and Trimboli families. I do not think there is any doubt that Pochi was involved and was seeking in some ways to get a piece of the action in 1974 and 1975. It is a matter of some regret, I suppose, for the continuing credibility of the Pochi family that they are still denying that when there is so much evidence suggestive to that effect on the record. But there just does not seem to be anywhere, when one looks meticulously at what came out before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and when one looks even more meticulously at the 40 or 50 pages of typewritten material in volume 2 of the Woodward report, to justify any more substantial conclusion than that he was a marginal figure.

He is referred to by Mr Justice Woodward at some passage of his report as being a more significant figure in the so-called secret organisation than four other named individuals. But that leads one to conclude that he is a less significant figure than the 13 or 14 other named individuals who elsewhere in the Woodward report are described as constituting the core of that organisation and who are physically based around the Griffith area. It is just very difficult, based on the bald assertions that are contained in these documents at the Woodward level, to conclude more than that it was a matter of inference based on the family ties -Mr Pochi, through his wife, with the Sergis-and of course, his involvement in the wine business through which it appears some money did in fact pass in 1974 and 1975. The evidence simply just does not go beyond that. I do not think there is any doubt that he was involved. Equally, I do not think any impartial observer could be left with any doubt that his involvement was only marginal, indirect and of a kind that was very distant from the action.

As to his possible involvement in the Mackay disappearance, which if there was a skerrick of evidence of that kind would be material of the most devastating kind for his credibility and the credibility of those who worry about what has happened, there is absolutely nothing in any of the Woodward material which even begins to draw any linkages of Pochi himself with what happened. The most that is said about the responsibility of the Griffith principles, the centrepiece of the organisation, for the Mackay death is set out on page 608 of volume 2 of the Woodward report, which states:
The likelihood is that it-
Meaning the disappearance and presumed death of Donald Mackay-
was effected by or on behalf of an organisation of persons to whom his continued existence and his attitude in relation to the drug menace in Griffith, was an embarrassment.

That is the conclusion. As I have said, it does not link Pochi with that in any other way than through the assertion that Pochi was a significant member of the organisation, which is not backed up in all the mass of detail contained in these reports by any more substantial evidence than that which was before Mr Justice Brennan of the AAT and which was meticulously considered by him. It is a very interesting question that if it is remotely believed by the Minister that Pochi may know something about the dissappearance and presumed death of Mackay, even though it also has to be borne in mind that he was in gaol at the time Mackay actually disappeared, why on earth is Pochi not being regarded as a witness of quite indispensable relevance to the forthcoming coronial inquiry into the presumed death of Donald Mackay? Why is it not that, indeed, his presence is being actively sought by the Government in order to get at once and for all the truth of that tragic matter? I suggest that the reality is that nobody seriously believes that Pochi himself had anything to do with it or that he was in any way but the most marginal way I have retailed connected with those who may well have had something to do with it.

It is said by the Minister in respect of Pochi as it was with respect to Barbaro that it would be naive to believe that he had anything other than a continuing involvement with this organisation, through which he was connected by a family relationship. But, again, where is the evidence for that? There was none whatsoever advanced by the Minister. There was none forthcoming in 1979 before Mr Justice Brennan. There was nothing in the Woodward report which came out in October 1979 to suggest any continuing involvement after the date of Pochi's original arrest back in 1975. There was nothing in the behaviour and circumstances of Pochi and his family, which have been the subject of quite elaborate and extensive affirmations and certifications by various members of this Commonwealth Parliament on both sides of politics and by members of the Canberra community who knew him well. The suggestion that Pochi continues to be some dark and sinister figure of significance in this obviously dark and sinister organisation just does not add up.

A lot more could be said about the individual cases but I do not want to burden the Senate with any more detail than that. What I think though has to be said, and said once again, about the Pochi case in particular is that there is a very misleading aspect of it contained in the Minister's statement. Coming from a man who claims the kind of credibility and integrity that Ian Macphee does, it is something that I find particularly disturbing; this is the way in which the references to the Woodward report have been strewn around this rather brief and cursory ministerial statement in such a way as to create a devastating set of atmospherics for anyone seeking to get at the truth and for anyone who seeks to argue that the case against these fellows is less than substantial. An emotional environment is created by those references which makes it very difficult to try to rationally pick apart and articulate why it is that one is still left with a lingering sense of concern.

The difficulty is that when one-I suppose I have really made these points- closely examines the Woodward report one simply does not find in it the kind of material directly linking the general assertions about what was going on in Griffith with the activities of these individuals. Of all those things I guess the worst single thing about the ministerial statement is the bald assertion in it that Mr Justice Brennan did not have the Woodward Commission report before him when he made the findings he did. That part of the statement conveying the clear implication-the intended implication-to any reader or listener that if Mr Justice Brennan only had these two massive volumes of material before him he could not have done other than find that Pochi was simply not a person of the character, the reputation, the antecedents and the likely future behaviour to justify a continuing place in the Australian community. But of course, as has been said, and must be said again for the record tonight, Mr Justice Brennan, did, as I have been saying, have the relevant part of the Woodward findings before him. So much is absolutely clear from that part of his judgment when he deals with the evidence given in camera to him by a police officer. Page 270 of the Australian Law Reports report of the case in 1979 states:
In order to strengthen the case against the applicant, the respondent-
the Minister, that is-

called Detective Senior Constable R. A. Jenkins to give evidence. Detective Jenkins is an experienced officer of the New South Wales police force who served with the New South Wales Drug Squad from 1970 to 1977 and who performed duty with the New South Wales Commission into Drugs-
the Woodward Commission-
for some 15 months.

He gave me certain information in a hearing from which the public and the applicant were excluded. Though the applicant's legal advisers were present at this hearing, they were prohibited from disclosing to the applicant the evidence then given.
Then, after some pages of procedural analysis, is the conclusion as to what was that in camera evidence from the man who was a member of the Woodward team for 15 months. Page 274 is in these terms:

In the present case, the public interest in protecting the sources of information used to combat crime was paramount, and it was necessary to ensure confidentiality of the evidence which referred to information of that kind given to Detective Jenkins. In a court of law, the evidence would not have been given at all: . . . Accordingly, the applicant and the public (but not the applicant's counsel and solicitors) were excluded while Detective Jenkins gave some of his evidence.

But the evidence given in camera before me did not live up to expectations in that it lacked the cogency which would support a finding of fact against the applicant. In part that evidence was hearsay, and hearsay inevitably lacks the cogency inherent in evidence given by a person who has personal knowledge of the facts to which he deposes . . .

It is to be noted that Mr Justice Brennan said that only in part was the evidence hearsay. There tends to be a disposition on the part of some people, lawyers and non-lawyers alike, to say that Mr Justice Brennan was being too technical in excluding ordinarily inadmissible evidence, that he was not sufficiently taking into account evidence that might have been technically inadmissible but nonetheless extremely probative.

That point has been taken but it is to be noted that Mr Justice Brennan said that only in part was the evidence of a hearsay kind. Obviously, there was more substantial evidence which would have been admissible which he did nonetheless take into account. It is very difficult to find, as Senator Durack would know as he put him on the High Court, a judge who is a more meticulous, cautious, rigorous or fairminded man than Mr Justice Brennan. He had before him all the evidence that was before the Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking. That the Woodward Commission had no more evidence about Pochi than was before Brennan appears clearly, from looking at what Woodward said, analysing evidence and what is said in the AAT case before Mr Justice Brennan. It is also clear from some throw-away lines from Mr Justice Woodward that, in effect, the evidence in question was co-extensive before both bodies. It did not vary significantly. I do not understand the Minister to believe any differencly from that.
