I do not understand him to be denying that the evidence before Woodward was in fact any different from that before Mr Justice Brennan. He chose his words very carefully indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except Mr Justice Woodward's comprehensive review of all drug matters and the taking of evidence about many related matters; a fuller perspective in Woodward's case.

—I accept that there is that, although the Woodward Commission report, I think it has to be said, is not an intellectually distinguished document. It is a wilderness of single instances. It bears a close resemblance to a bowl of spaghetti with some hundreds and thousands tipped in as well. In terms of the interconnection of the various bits and pieces, it is full of assertions that, I think, are unbacked by evidence, or assertions that such evidence exists but cannot be put on the public record. It is not an impressive document and I say no more about it than that. It is certainly a massive accumulation of a lot of evidence which, in fact, rather unequivocally states that an awful lot of people have an awful lot to answer for. I thoroughly acknowledge that and he may well be right in the conclusions he draws about the responsibility of this particular interlocking group of families and the key members of them for what was going on in Griffith, of course, and more particularly for the death of Donald Mackay. He may well be right about that. All I am saying is that there is not much in any of that which really helps establish the Minister's case that he wants to make, that is, that Pochi and Barbaro were key figures, central figures, paid-up figures, continuing members of this particular organisation. That has to be the key question for us in this Parliament, or for anyone else in this community who is concerned to see that justice is done, to confront.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a lot of other things-probably about two or three minutes worth-that can be said about the nature of these men, their individual character, the closeness of their families and the support they have had from their respective communities. Much can be said about the meticulous attention that was paid to their characters by the respective judges of the AAT. But the real question has to be reduced to that which I have been posing throughout everything I have said : What was the extent of their involvement in this activity? Was it essentially a one-off activity which ended after they were caught and for which they paid the price through our courts in the mid-1970s? Was it more extensive than that? Has it continued through to the present day such as to make these people dangerous to the extent that they are and remain continuing members of our community? That is the question that has to be answered. The question that we have to confront, if we take any of this matter seriously, is this: Has the Minister produced good enough reasons for second guessing the tribunals in the way that he has.

I make it clear that I do not object, and the Australian Labor Party does not object, to the general policy under this legislation of giving the Minister some additional discretion to make these hard decisions, responsible as he is to Parliament and running the gauntlet as he has today of criticism, such as that that has been mounted in the House of Representatives yesterday and here tonight . There may be cases when the Minister, after the AAT proceedings were all over and some rosy view of the character of the individual in question had been formed, where the Minister does get some additional evidence from sources which will not stand up to the technical rigours of admissibility criteria of courts of law. It may be that the Minister does get evidence coming into his office from people whose credibility is undoubted, evidence which is plausible, evidence which is probative and evidence which convinces the Minister beyond any shadow of doubt that the AAT missed something and that these are fellows who have to go. It is for that kind of reason, because of the importance of these matters, that the ultimate discretion is vested in the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did interview them.
—He did interview them.
—He spent hours looking at all the evidence.

—Yes, I have been through all that. I have no doubt that he wrestled and agonized with his conscience in a way that would make a Florida alligator-tamer look positively weak. That is not the point. The point is that, having done all that, having no doubt satisfied himself-I have no doubt about the good faith of Mr Macphee; I am sure he has satisfied himself-the question is whether he can satisfy anyone else that he has done the right thing. I believe the only way he can do that and the only way we, as a result, can have confidence in the fairness and justness of this system, the only way we can have confidence in the continuing existence of these institutional relationships where the ultimate discretion is vested in the Executive rather than in the courts, is if we can be satisfied that the Minister did, in fact, have further and better information, further and better reasons, than those which were fully considered, those which were meticulously dealt with by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. If he cannot produce those reasons we are entitled to remain unsatisfied. If he does not want to produce the detailed information which might exist in support of those reasons I, for one, would be satisfied by an unequivocal declaration by the Minister that he does have further and better evidence, further and better information, available to him which he cannot disclose on the public record but which has been crucial to his making up his mind.

SPEECH.PARA: No such declaration has been forthcoming from Mr Macphee. In fact, everything he said, if one analyses his statement carefully and analyses carefully what he said in the House of Representatives, is no more that the AAT Mr Justice Brennan and Mr Justice Fisher took this view of these particular facts: I, after wrestling with it, looking at it and taking into account the Woodward stuff, have taken a different view. I submit very seriously to the Senate, because no cheap, political points are to be scored obviously on a matter like this-most of the political points run the other way-that that is what is the matter with the ministerial statement that was put before us today. That is why it is that these men should not be deported until the Minister produces further and better reasons of that kind or at the very least some declaration that he does have further and better reasons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My postscript will be very limited. Anyone who had been probing the citizenship delays and bungling would know that the two applications that Mr Pochi made made him a victim of circumstances. Senator Evans mentioned that the law was changed about avoiding double penalties . I make a further observation. The population in Australia is composed of various components. When the matter of people who were involved in social security malpractices came up we made quite a fuss about people from one overseas country. But plenty of rorts were going on here.

SPEECH.PARA: We can apply this to another situation. At this time we are concerned with two Anglo-Saxons, both of whom committed serious crimes. One person was concerned with drugs. The Attorney-General, Senator Durack, is in the chamber. I wonder whether he was aware of this situation when he visited New Zealand. There is a fair clue to be found, but I will not mention the two cases in detail. There is some problem because the Government wants to deport one person who was convicted of a serious crime. I agree with the Government I know there is difficulty about whether New Zealand will accept that person. These people were born in the United Kingdom, lived in New Zealand and came here. The other person is a New Zealand national. I round this off by saying that we should prove to Australia at large that we are all equal. If a person is an Anglo-Saxon we might hold the deportation order and if he is not we might apply that order more quickly.

I have had a high respect for the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Macphee, as a Minister and as a man. But I seriously wonder about what will happen in the cases that I am talking about. What will happen if we take the plunge in the cases of the two people who have been mentioned tonight and the two whom I am thinking about and deport them? One could say that a person, whether he be a Latin or an Anglo-Saxon, is treated the same. There is a delay in the decision on whether New Zealand will take one or both of the people in the cases I am talking about. Surely this matter could be cleared up. But leaving aside the argument that Senator Evans has raised, all people whether they happen to be born in Britain, New Zealand or Italy should be treated the same when deportation decisions are being made. Leaving aside the matter of drugs I think the Minister ought to look twice at the varied components of our population. It may be that the two people I am thinking of will leave shortly too. One of them may appeal and I think the other appeal is over. One of them has drug connections. I make the point that we should adopt and evenhanded system in respect of deportations. I just add that postscript to the very lucid exposition produced by Senator Evans tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to add a degree of bipartisanship in the Senate to the question of the deportation of a person who has been an Australian resident-I suppose one could say nearly an Australian citizen-with an Australian family for a very considerable period. I have not the slightest doubt that everyone in this chamber would want to see either deported or in gaol any person whom it can be shown has been involved in one of the most despicable activities that can be engaged in by man-the drug trade. But there are processes and I find it very difficult to understand-unless either the processes can demonstrate through the legal system that the person ought to be gaoled or alternatively that the person is a visitor who has misbehaved while he is here- why he should be subjected to what might appear to be a somewhat arbitrary treatment.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not go so far as advocating some of the suggestions made by Senator Evans but I just would like to suggest that it concerns me that a person who has a family in this country and who but for a bureaucratic bungle would be an Australian citizen and therefore not subject to deportation but subject to the due process of law, should appear to be subject to what might be regarded as an arbitrary whim unless there is demonstrable evidence to substantiate the very severe action which has been taken. I say that out of concern not for a person who has been convicted of an offence, which as I said I would regard as a rather despicable trade, but rather for a person who has been accepted by a community as a resident citizen who has an Australian family. I just join in expressing a concern that due process in a free country should appear demonstrably to have taken place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope not to keep the Senate too long following the discussion that has taken place on deportation. I would like to draw the attention of honourable senators to the callous activities of a group that is racist and is currently infesting this country. I was startled by a letter that has been sent out to people in Queensland. The letter is headed 'The Australian Department of Commonwealth Relations' and is signed 'Al Grassby, Commissioner for Community Relations'. I am not suggesting that that person signed the correspondence. What I am suggesting is that the correspondence has been doctored. The top and the bottom of the letter have been changed. The letter has been sent out to people who have been taken aback and upset by the correspondence.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I would like to read into the record the text of the letter that has been sent out. I have only the transcript of the letter. I promise the Senate that I will have a State member in Queensland send me a copy of it. I believe that some action should be taken to publicise or investigate what seems to me to be a racist activity which is using a Commonwealth instrumentality and the name of Al Grassby, the Commissioner for Community Relations. The letter reads:

As part of our program for fostering greater world understanding, and with the knowledge of your deep feeling for coloured persons, the Australian Department of Commonwealth Relations has selected you as a participating household in our new 'Lend a Helping Hand Plan'.

You will be pleased, we are sure, to know that we have assigned a typical ( difficult?) family group from Sri Lanka to be guests in your home for the next few months. These people have suffered tremendous upheaval and it will take some time for them to adapt to our way of life.
We are sure that you will do everything possible, even if it means some minor reorganisation in your home and in your personal habits.

To ensure you are able to make the necessary accommodation arrangements the family will consist of father, mother, five children, wife's brother, husband's grandmother and her sister. Tents and stretchers, also portable toilets are available at a modest rental from F. Walker and Co., Melbourne, and these may be erected in your back or front yard. Necessary approval will be obtained from your local council by the department.
Within the next week you will hear from our head office regarding the arrival date, routing and the name of your selected family.

We shall include some recipes from Sri Lanka so that you may prepare their favourite dishes. So as not to inconvenience you, we will provide adequate supplies of curry powder, rice, chicken and powdered goats' milk.
If approval can be obtained from council, we hope to be able to provide you with two milking goats so fresh milk can be made available for the family.
Free immunisation will be given for you and your family against typhus, cholera , tuberculosis and leprosy.

No doubt you will wish to meet them at the airport. We suggest you hire a minibus or similar for this happy occasion as they will be bringing some of their possissions. While this may seem like a small gesture to you, we are convinced that it is only by such brotherhood that Australia will become one big , happy, multiracial country.
Bless you,
Yours in Friendship,
Australian Department of Commonwealth Relations,
Al Grassby. (Commissioner for Community Relations)

The original letter is in the possession of a State member of parliament to whom I spoke on the telephone tonight. He will forward a copy of the letter to me. I shall forward a copy to the Minister so that he may investigate to ensure that copies of that letter do not go to too many households in the Brisbane community .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal firstly with the matter raised by Senator Jones. It is certainly desirable for that matter to be investigated. I hope that the sort of hoax that is being perpetrated by material of that kind can be publicised so that no more people will be upset by the receipt of such letters. I look to Senator Jones to pass the information to my office. I will have the matter investigated.

SPEECH.PARA: The major subject of discussion in the adjournment debate tonight is the decision of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee), which he announced in another place yesterday, to deport two persons following their conviction for drug offences. I do not propose to reassert at this hour the case that the Minister gave for the decision he made. He has given, I believe, a very clear account of his reasons to the Parliament. It appears, however, that Senator Evans is critical of the reasons behind the decision. That is a matter for the record. I am pleased that he has not suggested that the Minister perhaps came to a conclusion which, on the evidence, was not justified. Senator Evans has acknowledged that the Minister approached the matter with a good deal of care and anxiety and even anguish and that he has made a decision in a perfectly bona fide way. As I see it, the Minister made a decision which it was well within his power to make. I do not understand Senator Evans to have said that it was not within the Minister's powers to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whether it is constitutional is another question.

—Anyway, it was within the powers assigned to him by this Parliament. The comments Senator Evans made tonight seem to have overlooked certain facts. I am pleased that Senator Evans acknowledged that it was a desirable policy for the Minister to make such decisions and that the making of actual decisions in such matters should not be assigned to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Minister, in making such a decision, should not be bound by the sort of legal strait-jacket which at times I have the feeling Senator Evans would like to impose upon him. The Minister has to look at all the facts and circumstances and to exercise a judgment in relation to all those matters. Again, I think Senator Evans acknowledged that the Minister could take into account matters which, for one reason or another, may not have been given weight by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. That would not necessarily be confined to what lawyers regard as fresh evidence, although I thought that Senator Evans, from the view he expressed, would so confine such matters. Maybe I misunderstood him, but I thought he felt the Minister was restricted in that way. I do not believe that that is so. It is a matter of his powers.
—Not as a matter of law but as a matter of policy.

—I do not think that even as a matter of policy the Minister ought to be restricted in that way. As I said, the Parliament has assigned that wide discretion to the Minister. Of course, the Minister must exercise the discretion in the way that is well known. Judicially he may be corrected if he does not do so. But he does have that very wide discretion which is not necessarily exercised in the same way as a judge would exercise it.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, in this case the Minister believed that the findings of the Woodward Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking had supplied him with a background to the activities of those people which, in at least one case, had been denied the judge who dealt with the matter. That perhaps provided the Minister with a setting which was not available to the judge, even though the evidence that was before the Woodward Commission in relation to that person may have been before the judge as well. But the Woodward Commission investigated the issue on a broader scale. I think it would be fair to say that it did provide a setting in which the activities of certain people, such as the two people concerned, could be judged. However, I think that the issue is different again from the perspective Senator Evans sought to put on it. The Minister has a very firm policy in relation to the deportation of serious drug offenders. That policy is that, unless there are very special circumstances, he will find in favour of deportation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were not convicted of serious drug offences.

—I used the word 'serious' and the policy is in broad terms. It does not have to be classified as a particular offence only; the policy is in broad terms. Those who are convicted of drug trafficking must know, and should take account of the fact, that they are most likely to be deported. We could argue that there may be special circumstances and so on, but in the end these are matters which are assigned by this Parliament to the Minister. No one has suggested that the Minister has done anything other than act in a bona fide, careful and thoughtful manner, even though opinions may differ as to the decision he should have made. Obviously Senator Evans and, I gather, Senator Peter Rae would have come to other decisions, but they were not in the position of the Minister with all the material before them that the Minister presumably had.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that anything further can be said or done in relation to this matter. The Minister has made his decision and announced it to the Parliament. In one case further legal proceedings are taking place. There does not seem to be anything further that I am required to do in relation to the comments that have been made on this subject this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the other two?

—I have not forgotten the honourable senator's point. I have no doubt that Mr Macphee will be interested in the comments that have been made in this place this evening. I am well aware, as I am sure those honourable senators who have spoken are, that he has given this matter a great deal of thought and has been very concerned about it. He has formed a view and made his decision, but I am sure that that does not mean he will not take account of and be particularly interested in the comments made by honourable senators who spoke on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mulvihill's point, although perhaps inspired by the statement of the Minister, deals with another matter altogether. With such knowledge that I have from dealing with questions of parole for a large number of these people who are deported, I would not have any reason to believe that there is any discrimination on the basis of the origins of people in relation to their deportation. The matter is decided on the nature of the offence and on all the circumstances. Of course, people who come into the country for a brief period only have very little case against deportation. I see no evidence to suggest that any greater sympathy is given to people of Anglo-Saxon origin. Certainly a great number of people from New Zealand are deported to New Zealand. I am not aware of the particular cases that Senator Mulvihill mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The initials are G.S. That ought to give you a lead.
—I am not concerned directly with the deportation of people. I am speaking only on the basis of my own indirect knowledge.
—We are having talks with New Zealand on it and you did go to New Zealand. I thought as Attorney-General you might have been in the discussions.
—No, I was not. If the honourable senator passes the names to me I will see that they and his comments are brought to the attention of Mr Macphee .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I do not wish to detain the Senate but I think the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) may have misunderstood my intervention in the debate. He concluded that I, amongst other speakers, may have come to a conclusion different from that reached by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee). I would not wish it to be thought that I would have come to a different conclusion. I was talking about due process. I was not talking about the conclusion of the process. There is a vast difference between the two. I was not in any way suggesting that I would not have come to the same conclusion had I been in the position of having all of the facts available to me.
—Nor were you suggesting that you would come to that conclusion.

—No, I was not making a suggestion either way. I was simply talking about what I regarded as the Parliament's responsibility to ensure due process, particularly in the circumstances of what amounts to an Australian family, by accident, being subject to deportation. I went no further than that. I would not wish it to be felt that I had in any way expressed a conclusion on the facts of the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.26 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Government accept the proposal of the Review of Commonwealth Functions that there should be a reduction of one per cent in the differential between the Wheat Board's commercial borrowings and its Reserve Bank borrowings.
(2) As a result, did the Treasurer write to the Reserve Bank and suggest that the interest rate on funds from the Rural Credits Department should rise by one per cent.
(3) Has the Reserve Bank replied to the Treasurer's letter.
(4) If the Reserve Bank agrees to the Government's request, will a great many rural industries other than the wheat industry also be affected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer gave an answer to a similar question in the House of Representatives on 9 September 1981 (Hansard, page 1133 ). The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government, by its decision announced on 30 April 1981, formally accepted the Review of Commonwealth Functions decision that the differential between the interest rate on commercial borrowings by the Australian Wheat Board and that applicable to borrowings from the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank should be reduced by one percentage point.
(2) The Treasurer formally conveyed the Government's decision to the Governor of the Reserve Bank on 27 May 1981.

(3) The Reserve Bank has the statutory responsibility to determine Rural Credits Department interest rates, although the practice has been for the Treasurer of the day to be consulted. The Treasurer's communication of the Government's decision to the Governor was part of that consultative process. It did not, therefore, require a formal reply.

(4) The Reserve Bank decided to increase Rural Credits Department interest rates on loans of more than $100,000 by one per cent per annum as from 22 June 1981. This was a general increase which was not restricted in its application to the Australian Wheat Board.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many people are on the Occupational Superannuation Task Force.
(2) What are their names.
(3) How often has the Task Force met between 12 July 1979 and 30 September 1981 .
(4) When does the Government expect its report.
(5) When will its findings be reported to Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As indicated in the Treasurer's press release on 12 July 1979 the Task Force on Occupational Superannuation is chaired by an officer of the Department of the Treasury and includes officials drawn from the Departments of Finance, Prime Minister and Cabinet, Social Security and Industrial Relations, the Taxation Office and the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat.
(2) It would not be appropriate to name the individuals who actually attend the meetings as they do so not on a personal basis but as representatives of their Departments or Offices.

(3) The Task Force met on 12 occasions between 12 July 1979 and 30 September 1981. In addition, three technical sub-committees established by the Task Force with private sector representation met on a number of occasions during that period.

(4) and (5) There are some aspects on which the Task Force is in need of further Ministerial guidance with regard to its future work and this matter is currently being examined. Pending the outcome of that examination I am unable to give any firm indication of the likely time of completion of the work of the Task Force.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: If Budget forecasts are correct, what reductions in income tax would have been implemented and approximately how much would they have cost the Taxation Department in forgone revenue in the financial year 1982-83.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am not clear what information is sought by this question. Any new taxation measures affecting the revenue in 1982-83 will be announced at the appropriate time, and cannot be foreshadowed at this stage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government intend to act on the 1980-81 report by the Insurance Commissioner, Mr Kirkpatrick, in which he warns that a number of general insurance companies may in the future be unable to meet outstanding claims.
(2) How does the Minister for Finance explain the Government's failure to guard against the over-extension of insurers.

(3) What guarantees does the Government intend to provide to the public if insurers fail in the areas of workers' compensation, comprehensive vehicle, compulsory third party motor vehicle and public liability insurance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Insurance Commissioner has expressed his concern over developments in provisions for outstanding claims in the liability classes of business. He has expressed the expectation that some companies will be required to increase such provisions in the face of deficiencies perceived. The situation of individual companies will, of course, be kept under review in the context of the provisions of the Insurance Act 1973.

(2) and (3) The general purpose of the Insurance Act is to establish a system for the financial supervision of general insurance companies with a view to maintaining overall financial soundness and stability in the industry. The Act does not, however, purport to guarantee that an insurer will not fail. No system , however detailed and costly, could provide such a guarantee. Such a course would in any case tend to bring with it undesirable consequences in terms of lessened competition within the industry including in the provision of services and, in some degree, in the proper functioning of the economy generally. With regard to workers' compensation insurance and compulsory third party (motor vehicle) insurance it is relevant that the States and Territories have important responsibilities in these areas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 11 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Treasurer aware of weekend press reports in the Brisbane Sunday Sun ( dated 8 November 1981) that the Soviet Government is poised to participate directly in Queensland's resources boom as a joint partner with private enterprise in a feasibility study into a $1.2 billion coking project at Mackay, which is intended to convert coal from the Central Queensland Gregory South Mine into coke for export. Is there a participation by the French Socialist Government in the proposed mining, milling and export of uranium at Ben Lomond, in North Queensland. Are any other Eastern Bloc countries gaining a measure of control over Australia's resources in Queensland, or any other States, as so many Western countries have already.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It is understood that the Queensland Government has had discussions with a consortium comprising Kennecott Copper Corporation of the USA and two Australian companies, New Hope Collieries Pty Ltd and Minerals and Energy Development NL, about the possible construction of a coke plant at Mackay based on coal from the Gregory South coal deposit. The project is at a very early planning stage and a feasibility study has been commenced. Soviet technology is being considered for use in the proposed plant but there has been no proposal for the Soviet Government to become a joint venture partner or take up an equity position in the venture.

The Ben Lomond uranium deposit in North Queensland is owned by Minatome Australia Pty Ltd, which is owned 50 per cent each by two Franch companies, the Total group of companies and the Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann group. The French Government has equity and voting power in Compagnie Francaise des Petroles, the holding company of the Total group of companies. At the end of 1979, the French Government held 96 per cent of the B shares and had 40 per cent of total voting rights in the company. Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann is a private group of companies, and the French Government is at present understood to be involved in negotiations to nationalise the group. The Ben Lomond project is still at the feasibility study stage and Minatome Australia Pty Ltd is aware that it will need to meet the Government's foreign investment policy requirements before the project proceeds to development. Under the Government's policy, new projects for the mining and production of uranium are expected, as a general rule, to have 75 per cent Australian equity and to be Australian controlled.
From studies undertaken by the Foreign Investment Review Board, there is no direct investment by Eastern Bloc countries in Australia's mineral development and other natural resources.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps, if any, is the Government taking to maintain statistics on foreign investments and ownership in Australia, now that the Australian Bureau of Statistics no longer collects or collates these figures.

(2) Is it proposed to give the Foreign Investment Review Board increased powers to monitor foreign ownership and control in Australia and to enforce the stipulated Australian equity levels; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Considerable information on the levels and flows of foreign investment in enterprises in Australia is already available to the Government through the existing data collections of the Australian Bureau of Statistics and through the Foreign Investment Review Board. To supplement that information, the Treasurer has, as announced on 20 January 1982, asked the Bureau to reintroduce surveys measuring more specifically the extent of foreign ownership and control in sectors of the Australian economy.

(2) If Australia is to take advantage of the benefits of foreign investment, a balance needs to be struck between, on the one hand, protecting the legitimate interests of Australians in participating in national economic development and, on the other hand, allowing businesses having foreign interests adequate scope and flexibility to make investment and other decisions that are essential if that development is to proceed.

In cases where a foreign investment proposal is approved by the Government subject to future increases being achieved in the level of Australian ownership and/or control of an enterprise or new venture the Foreign Investment Review Board maintains regular consultation with the parties pending fulfilment of the conditions regarding Australian ownership.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are Australians generally investing sufficiently in Australia's resources and development; if not, what action is being taken to encourage Australians to invest more in their country.
(2) Why is the Government vigorously encouraging foreign investment in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government's economic policies are designed to establish conditions that are favourable to investment by Australians in the development of this country's resources and industries. The level of investment being undertaken by Australian investors is indicative of the success of these policies.

(2) The Government welcomes foreign investment because of the contribution it makes to the development of Australia's industries and resources and because it enables a higher rate of economic growth. At the same time, the Government, through the examination of proposals under the foreign investment policy, takes steps to ensure that the foreign investment that is undertaken is on a basis that is consistent with the national interest.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action is the Government taking to monitor and control foreign ownership in Australian companies through nominee holdings.
(2) To what extent is the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd owned by foreign interests either overtly or through nominee companies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Information as to the beneficial ownership of nominee shareholdings in companies is sought in those cases where such information would be of significance in the consideration of a foreign investment proposal under the Government's foreign investment policy.

(2) A study by Mr Peter Davies for the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System estimated that, in 1979, 22 per cent of shares in BHP were held , directly or through nominee companies, by foreign residents.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it possible to quantify the average tax paid by Australian families; if so, what has been the average tax paid per Australian family in each year since 1970 -71 in actual and 1980-81 terms.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: There are no official figures available to indicate how total tax paid by Australian families would have changed between 1970-71 and 1980-81.

The amount of personal income tax paid by households earning various levels of income is available for 1975-76 from the Australian Bureau of Statistics' household expenditure survey. However, details of the effect of taxes other than personal income tax on families are not available; nor is there any consistent statistical information on the number of families or households in Australia between 1970-71 and 1980-81.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Department of Social Security have parliamentary liason officers; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 August 1981 (Hansard p. 385) Senator MacGibbon asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer in the Senate, a question without notice concerning the allowance for income tax purposes of gifts to the 1982 Commonwealth Games Foundation.

ANSWER.PARA: I undertook to refer the matter to the Treasurer, who has provided the following response to the question:

The Commonwealth is already making a substantial contribution to the Games in a number of ways, including a grant of $10m towards the cost of capital facilities; and additional $2.7m for extra accommodation at the Games Village; $20.6m to enable the ABC to act as host broadcaster; a grant of $1.5m in lieu of revenue from the marketing of commemorative coins; at least $2m in administrative and other support by Commonwealth Departments; $0.7m for pre- event training for the Games and for the staging of trial Games in 1981; $0.6m for the Commonwealth Games Arts Festival; and $1.2m assistance for upgrading some sports facilities. Against the background that gifts to assist the financing of international sporting or athletic events have never before been allowed tax deductibility, the Government decided, some time ago, that gifts to the Foundation should not be deductible. In the light of the Government's direct assistance, I see no reason now for changing that decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1802) Senator Evans asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the marketing of short term life insurance bonds.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question.

Officials from Treasury and the Australian Taxation Office have for some time been conducting a review of the taxation position of short term life insurance bonds. Because of the complexity of the issues, and the pressures of other work on the officers concerned, this review has not yet been completed. The Government will in due course consider the results of the officials' work and take appropriate action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2265) Senator Coleman asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of recent reports that claim that large numbers of prisoners are being held by the Ugandan military police without charges being laid? Is she aware that according to one report the prisoners' ages range from 12 to 80 years, they are dressed in rags, are allowed no visitors, are locked up 24 hours a day and are being denied medical treatment? Will the Minister advise whether there has been an expression of concern by the Australian Government that human rights are being denied by the Ugandan Government especially in relation to the young and the aged? In particular, will the Minister establish the exact whereabouts and physical condition of two former Ministers, Jaberi Bidandi-Sali and the Reverend Christopher Okoth, last heard of in Luzira Prison in August this year?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

According to information the Australian High Commission in Nairobi has been able to obtain there is a considerable number of prisoners detained in Uganda, but the High Commission has been unable to establish the actual number, the conditions under which they are being held, and by what procedures they have been placed in detention.

Concerning the particular enquiry as to the whereabouts and physical condition of two former Ministers, the Australian Government has information that Mr Jaberi-Sali was arrested an 10 February 1981 in Kampala and most probably remains in detention in Luzira prison. The Reverend Christopher Okoth, according to information, was arrested on 16 February 1981 and remains in detention in either Luzira prison or at the Kampala Central police station.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2506), Senator Hearn asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The Treasurer referred in his Budget Speech to correcting anomalies and inconsistencies in the administration of sales tax. Included in items previously not taxed but now to be taxed at 17 1/2 per cent are motor vehicle seat belts. How much revenue does the Minister anticipate will be raised from this tax on safety?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The sales tax revenue that will result from the taxing of motor vehicle seat belts, in the same way that other components of the vehicles are taxed, has been estimated at $7m per annum.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 February 1982 (Hansard, page 75) Senator Lewis asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a question without notice concerning the National Australia Day Committee's proposed seminar on national identity.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am informed that the statements made by the Chairman of the National Australia Day Committee were based to some extent on the findings of a study conducted for the Committee in September 1980, which revealed significant variations in the attitudes to their country of many Australians. the personal observations of the Committee members, who are drawn from all States and Territories and many walks of life, also confirmed a need for informed public discussion of our national identity.

The honourable senator will be aware that, as well as promoting the observance of Australia Day, the Committee's terms of reference include the responsibility to report on steps which might be taken to foster national pride. In conducting the seminar on National Identity, the Committee hopes to obtain valuable information to assist it in reporting to the Government on this matter.
In relation to the cost of the seminar, the Committee is hoping that all expenses will be met from private sponsors.
